story:
Once Upon A Time… 
Two young dancers dreamt of going to New York City.

Thank you so much for taking the time to read about our campaign to help Eden and Sarah go to New York City next summer! My name is Stephanie Harper and I am the Artistic Director and Owner of Harper&I. Before we go into the details of our campaign you should know a bit about our studio to find out what we are all about and why this trip is so important!

Harper&I is located in Bellingham, WA and is all about giving back. The studio was created with the goal of bringing a challenging and professional class atmosphere for all ages with one very important concept: the experience had to be positive and enriching. It is all about the instructor being there for the student as a role model, mentor and positive inspiration. More than anything, it is about our students coming away from each and every class motivated and feeling good about themselves.

About Eden and Sarah…

This campaign is about two of my students: Sarah and Eden. Both dancers have been with Harper&I since it first began and joined the studio in hopes of becoming better, more versatile dancers and seeing where the road could take them. Both are very interested in furthering their careers as dancers and are ready to work as hard as they have to in order to make their dreams come true!

Taking a peek back into their first few months with me: these girls had to work very, very hard to be where they are today! The weekly improvement was astounding- I have actually cried a few times watching them dance because of how far they have come in their dancing. It is truly amazing and beautiful to witness! Read their bios below:

Sarah
I have been dancing for over 13 years and plan to pursue professional dance or theater. Every year I participate in the school musical and have also begun teaching ballet, tap, and hip hop at Harper&I this season. I love to dance because it makes me feel a special way that I can't feel doing anything else; in a way it completes me. I have wanted to experience New York's dance scene since I was little and it would mean the world to me- a direct doorway to all of my dreams!

Eden
I began her dance career with ballet over 10 years ago and fell in love with it immediately. Dance has always been a part of me as I have moved all around the world from New Zealand to Australia to Washington. I've always dreamed of New York City, since it really is the center of the performing arts world and would be a priceless experience to be immersed into the real world of professional dance. I would be able to learn from the best and see first hand what it takes to make it as a dancer. Besides working on becoming a stronger dancer, I'm also dedicated to doing my best academically to go to a good college that feeds both my intellectual and creative sides. Growing up on the other side of the world, I could have never imagined that this opportunity would arise, and I'll do whatever it takes to make this dream a reality!

Helping Make This Dream A Reality

When I first began Harper&I I had to ask myself what my main goals were for the studio. Creating a safe haven for dancers and movers from all walks of life was a big goal. A challenging, positive and professional curriculum was also a big one. Something that kept coming to mind was the opportunity for the dancers to travel. Traveling has given me so much perspective as to the kind of individual, artist and mentor I want to be. I want to be able to provide similar opportunities for my dancers and so I made a promise that I would do my absolute best to make a trip to New York City happen. I really hope you can help me keep that promise!

Why New York City? We are located in Washington and are lucky to have Seattle close by but New York would be a once in a lifetime opportunity. The professional dance world is right at your fingertips and the chance to take classes with companies like Alvin Ailey and witness a Broadway musical firsthand would just be extraordinary. This trip is meant to inspire Sarah and Eden and instill a confidence in them that they are able to pursue their dream in any way, shape or form that they would like! And I (and you!) will be here to help them along the way. 

The opportunity to take the girls to New York City would be an amazing experience. If for some reason this campaign does not meet its full goals, I will do everything in my power to make the trip happen regardless!

The Details of Our Journey!

We hope to embark on this adventure in Summer of 2014 for five days.
(This campaign will cover Eden and Sarah's costs only. I will be covering my own costs through teaching, choreography projects, etc.)

  • Airfare: This of course depends on when we buy the tickets but it will be around $1,000-$1,200 for both dancers.
  • Lodging: We will probably stay in a hostel in downtown Manhattan that is just $60/person/night. Around $600 for five days
  • Classes: Most drop-in classes are $18-$20/class and we hope to take classes in all styles: Ballet, Modern, Contemporary, Broadway, etc. If each dancer takes 10 classes during those 5 days it will cost around $400
  • Performances: Our main goal is to have the ultimate class-taking experience but depending on funding we would love to see a ballet performance and Broadway musical if possible! Around $200-$300 for both dancers.
  • Food/Misc Costs: If we do not meet our funding goals our bake sales, car washes and other fundraisers will hopefully help cover these costs!

If our campaign does not meet its goal all funds will go towards a summer intensive for both dancers that is closer to home!

You Will Influence the Fate of Two Dancers!

Any support you give will directly influence the lives of these two talented dancers! How amazing is that? They will be able to step out of their comfort zone and go to a completely new city, into a completely new studio and discover new aspects of their dancing that they didn't realize before! They will be surrounded by dancers from around the world and will be able to make new friends and connections that will help inspire them even further.


How Else Can You Help?

We understand you're on a budget! We are too and so even just spreading the word about this campaign will make a difference. 

"Share" this on Facebook and Twitter! Email it to your friends! 

"Like" Harper&I on Facebook and with enough handwork and community support we can all watch this dream come true! Thank you, thank you, thank you!


**Special thank you to Katie Ikehara (Harper&I's wonderful event manager) for putting this campaign together and Vincenzo Frattarola for his work on our video! http://vintagefoto.net**

story:
USC’s Musical Theatre Repertory has been preparing for our fall production of Dirty Rotten Scoundrels, book by Jeffrey Lane, Music and Lyrics by David Yazbek. The rehearsal process is in full swing and the show is getting ready to go, but now we need some support from you! All money donated will go directly to all production costs for Dirty Rotten Scoundrels, including costumes, our set, and performance space. The show opens on Thursday October 10th through Sunday October 13th in the Massman Theater on the USC campus. We can’t wait to show you all what we’ve been working so hard on. Thank you all so much in advance for your support, and we will see you at the show!

Musical Theatre Repertory at the University of Southern California was established in 2005 and is dedicated to enriching students’ lives through the production of quality musical theatre. Our goal is to provide students with the opportunity to participate in musical theatre pieces supplementary to those produced by USC. Explore our website [www.uscmtr.com] for general info about the company, ticketing details, upcoming events, production stills, and even a few production videos! Thank you for supporting the arts and we can't wait to see you at our upcoming shows!

We are very excited to be working with the following cast members in this production, so far their work has been impeccable and we can't wait to share their extraordinary work with an audience as they tell this amazing story.

Dirty Rotten Scoundrels

Book by Jeffrey Lane

Music and Lyrics by David Yazbek

Based on the film "Dirty Rotten Scoundrels" Written by Dale Launer and Stanley Shapiro & Paul Henning

Licensed by Musical Theatre International 


The Massman Theatre
October 10th - October 13th

Cast

  • Lawrence: Andrew Schmidt
  • Freddy: Drew Klopfer
  • Andre: Erik Vogt-Nilsen
  • Christine: Jennifer Kranz
  • Murial: Adrienne Visnic
  • Jolene: Caroline Spinola
  • Ensemble: Arielle Fishman, Sami Nye, Carlye Porrazzo, Brooke Lewis, Molly Chiffer, Henry Boyd, Kevin Paley, Sandy Reed, Erik Hu, Tucker Aust

CREATIVE TEAM:

  • Directed by Brandon Baer
  • Musical Direction by Anthony Lucca
  • Choreography by Sarah Fanella
  • Produced by Arielle Fishman & Kevin Paley
  • Stage Managed by Lea Branyan
  • Scenic Designed by Selby Souza
  • Technical Direction by Madigan Stehly
  • Sound Designed by Danielle Kisner
  • Lighting Designed by Austin Allen 
  • Costumes by Marly Hall
  • Props Master: Summer Grubaugh
  • Production Managed by Alice Pollitt
  • Box Office Manager: Alyssa Breda


Email uscmtr@gmail.com to get involved!


About the show...

Based on the popular 1988 film, Dirty Rotten Scoundrels centers on two con men living on the French Riviera. Lawrence Jameson makes his lavish living by talking rich ladies out of their money. Freddy Benson more humbly swindles women by waking their compassion with fabricated stories about his grandmother's failing health. After meeting on a train, they attempt to work together only to find that this small French town isn't big enough for the two of them. They agree on a settlement: the first one to extract $50,000 from a young female target, heiress Christine Colgate, wins and the other must leave town. A hilarious battle of cons ensues that will keep audiences laughing, humming and guessing to the end!


The creative team has been working really hard to make this production as wonderful as possible. The collaboration is amazing and the process has been going smoothly thus far. To fulfill the vision and dedication of the creative team we now need funding and support from you! Thank you so much for supporting this production and we hope you get a chance to see the show!

story:
This campaign is about...

MORE THAN A STAGE

This campaign is about securing the future of Montreal's:  



HELP US BUILD A NEW STAGE! 

To us, Shakespeare-in-the-Park is about…

MORE THAN A STAGE. Shakespeare-in-the-Park is about supporting and developing creative communities. We bring live, classically based theatre to Montreal and Quebec communities for free. We do this because we believe in strengthening the relationship between art and public space.  We make live theatre accessible to the general public because we believe that everyone "profits" from creative, culturally vibrant communities. 

Click here to watch Artistic Director Paul Hopkins and CBC Montreal talk about the campaign. 

HOW CAN YOU HELP?  

We're looking to raise 10,000 dollars to build a new stage. Our current stage has been with us for 16 years and it is quite literally on its last legs. We need to build a new stage that is durable, flexible and safe. You can help by donating to our MORE THAN A STAGE campaign. We realize that 10,000 dollars seems like a lot but if 300 people-our average attendance at a show-- give 20 dollars-the cost of an inexpensive live theatre ticket-we would already be reaching half of our proposed goal! That is pretty exciting!



10 REASONS TO GIVE TO SHAKESPEARE-IN-THE-PARK 

1)  Give because you believe that everyone profits from a creative community
2) Give because you know the impassioned struggle of being a non-profit 
3) Give because you believe in the relationship between public space and art
4) Give because you know us and you love our shows 
5) Give because you've fought hard for something you care about
6) Give because you're an artist and you believe in mentorship programs 
7) Give because you're a parent and you believe in arts education initiatives that enrich youth's creative autonomy
8) Give because you love theatre and Shakespeare 
9) Give because you want to. 
10) Give because you can. 

Everyone who gives to the campaign receives a mailed letter of acknowledgment from Repercussion Theatre's Artistic Director Paul Hopkins. 

This letter will be proof of your contribution to the company as a Stage Sponsor. 

Here are some other ways you can help!

Share our Campaign Page on social media by clicking on the Facebook and Twitter Widgets located at the top of the page. 

Make a donation for a Perk of the Week by e-mailing us at dev@repercussiontheatre.com 

Use #morethanastage so that we can keep track of your support to thank you. 

Show your support for
Shakespeare-in-the-Park.  
Help build.

story:
Short Summary

In 1997 I decided to start my own theatre company. It began as outreach improv for at risk woman and was called Venus Envy. In 2001 we dropped the Envy and incorporated as a nonprofit called Venus Theatre. In 2006, after producing through DC and 4 states we signed a lease for a storefront in Laurel, MD and called it the Venus Theatre Play Shack. At the close of this calendar year, we will have produced 50 scripts that empower women as a nonprofit and spent 8 years in the-house-that-love-built (formerly a Chinese Restaurant). 

  • My name is Deb Randall. I'm the founder of Venus and have been producing scripts that empower women for decades now. 
  • Producing 50 new plays that empower women is not about winning awards or securing a title. It's about doing the work. In order to do the work at night, we need electricity.
  • Venus has been producing professional women's theatre on a $40,000 annual budget. We have seen scripts we've premiered get published, get productions around the globe and at times off broadway, and have documentaries created around them.

It's time for us to put the power of female theatrical artists at the center of economic development. We want to grow from paying a stipend to our professional artists to paying them a living wage. But first, we need to pay our utility bills.

What We Need & What You Get

The more we dive into the work the more we need your help:

  • For a fraction of the the industry standard we produce quality theatre that is rarely seen anywhere else on the globe. 
  • Some of these plays are 13 years old when we give them first productions. And, the power of producing them can lead to a whole new life.
  • We are reaching out now for help paying the utilities and day to day bills for the rest of the 2014 calendar year, so that when we get to fifty plays at the end of November we will not be in debt. And from there, our new board will thrust us into a thriving future that supports our current bar of standard for the creative work.They will launch new business planning for the future beginning 2015.

The Impact

Even $5 or $10 can help us keep the lights on:

  • When we no longer have to worry about the lights staying on or the water running, we can focus on the work at hand and give more women more jobs in the theatre (and some amazing men too!).
  • A few years ago we did a Shacky Chic makeover and last year our Pay-The-Rent for a year campaign allowed us to get ahead for the first time in our history.
  • We can do a whole lot with very little resource. We need you to invest what you can so we can grow forward at a rapid rate with our efficiency at the center. In this way we can give more jobs to more women. And with the new chapter ahead, we can make those jobs pay living wages. But first, we have to get to 50 and keep the lights on and the water flowing. Actors get thirsty and can trip in the dark.

Risks & Challenges

You may have already heard some rough statistics about women in the theatre world. Jobs are scarce. You may also have heard, seen, experienced, inequity in terms of the way women are treated in our culture as a whole. And, with these two things in mind, you may correctly assume that my journey has been an uphill battle. Never wanting to stage the same show twice and constantly embracing diversity in the female perspective means we can't guarantee box office. That's not how most theatres operate. But, what would be the point in compromising our central objective?

Our agreements are still set up so that I have three months to pay my people contractually. This is based on 20 years as a waitress. I want to be sure to pay everyone on time so it's set up so that if I need to go back to serving milkshakes to pay people, I can. My new board members are teaching me to reach forward now. So, I have to figure out how to get from scarcity to abundance. 

  • With our new team we have new skill sets at the table that will allow for these shifts to occur.
  • Although I'll have produced 50 plays  http://www.venustheatre.org/production_history before I turn 50 years old, I don't have the energy to wait tables and work side jobs while reading 200 plays a year and producing 4 or more. I'd like to see a secured future for myself and my artists through Venus Theatre. One that includes lots of qualified people.

Other Ways You Can Help

Come and see a show or send someone in your stead:

  • All of our income goes to artists and overhead. I'd like to continue to maximize social media outlets so that our resources stay where they belong,in the pockets of our artists and on the stage for our audiences.
  • PLEASE use the Indiegogo share tools often and help spread the love!

Never wanting to stage the same show twice and constantly embracing diversity in the female perspective means we can't guarantee box office. That's not how most theatres operate. But, what would be the point in compromising our central objective?
 Our agreements are still set up so that I have three months to pay my people contractually. This is based on 20 years as a waitress. I want to be sure to pay everyone on time so it's set up so that if I need to go back to serving milkshakes to pay people, I can. My new board members are teaching me to reach forward now. So, I have to figure out how to get from scarcity to abundance.  
With our new team we have new skill sets at the table that will allow for these shifts to occur. Although I'll have produced 50 plays  http://www.venustheatre.org/production_history before I turn 50 years old, I don't have the energy to wait tables and work side jobs while reading 200 plays a year and producing 4 or more. I'd like to see a secured future for myself and my artists through Venus Theatre. One that includes lots of qualified people.
 
  Other Ways You Can Help Come and see a show or send someone in your stead: 
All of our income goes to artists and overhead. I'd like to continue to maximize social media outlets so that our resources stay where they belong,in the pockets of our artists and on the stage for our audiences. PLEASE use the Indiegogo share tools often and help spread the love!

story:
About Us

Cottonwood Center for the Arts is a 501c3 non-profit dedicated to advancing arts and culture in Colorado Springs.  We have two primary goals: the first, to show and exhibit art at its highest and most developed level, the second, to invite artists of all genres to participate learn, grow, and experience art in our facilities regardless of level.

Located in the Cottonwood Arts District of eastern downtown Colorado Springs, Cottonwood is a community of more than 90 studio artists. Community growth is fostered through the creation of art, classes and workshops, monthly gallery exhibitions, and special cultural events including our “Day of the Dead” open house. Professional growth is fostered through mentoring, group critiques, and creative leadership.

At Cottonwood, we don’t just create art for ourselves – we use art to elevate our community! Whether it’s using art as rehabilitation for trauma survivors, PTSD patients, and veterans’ groups; offering classes to students from varying socio-economic backgrounds of all ages and skill levels; or partnering with the Adduce foundation to help high school students create and explore the arts, we’re using our power for good, and that's good for business too. In fact, the only way to keep talented younger people in a city is by offering a variety of culture. We want to be THE place people turn to see what's on the cutting edge and what talents might just be lurking within them, undiscovered. 

About the Beautify Studio B Project

Studio B In Its Current State

For the past few years, Cottonwood's main focus has been visual arts. Through our partnerships with local organizations like Craft Production Theater, Hear Here, the Colorado Springs Dance Theatre, the Colorado College Summer Music Festival, and Toastmasters we have seen a need for a dedicated performance space in our building. Studio B is currently used as a partial storage space, partial classroom and we are excited by the opportunity to expand our programs and our outreach by developing this large space into a performance venue for theater, dance, music, poetry, and more.

    The Impact

    Children's Poetry Night Hear Here
    Colorado Springs Dance Theatre CC Summer Music Festival

    This project will be invaluable to us with new opportunities to open up our building to musicians, dancers, and performers and continue to expand arts and culture in Colorado Springs. As we broaden our work with children and schools through visual arts we are excited by the opportunity for additional children's programming by growing our children's poetry night, adding children's music and performances to our current dedicated student art shows - the Congressional High School Art Competition, the Young Peoples' Art Exhibition, etc., and developing classes and workshops for children in the performing arts.

      What We Need

      Our goal is to raise $5,000 to renovate and remodel Studio B. This funding will allow us to develop a 75 seat theater with a stage, green room, pipe and drape, risers, seating and flooring. Any funds raised beyond our initial goal will go to lighting, electrical, sound, and a front foyer for the performance space.

      What You'll Get in Return

      All donations will go directly to Cottonwood Center for the Arts and our redevelopment of Studio B. All donors will have potential use of this new space, access to exciting performance opportunities in town, and the knowledge that their donations are going to an organization with a tried and true track record of excellence in the arts over the past few years. 

      Donors at various levels have the option of selecting art pieces as seen in the side bar to the right. In order to thank you for your donations our studio artists have donated the following pieces.

      $20 - Jim Lummel Mug $30 - Hand Knit Cowl
      $30 - Necklace $50 - Bag
      $100 - Hand Painted Watercolor $125 - Textile w/ Bead Embellishments
      $150 - Abstract Pastel $400 - Abstract Textile

      $450 - Amazonite Necklace $1500 - The Liberation of Carmen

      Thank You For Your Support!

      We are excited to take this next step and continue Cottonwood's expansion in the community. Please help us by spreading the word to your family and friends. Every dollar helps us make this project a reality!

story:
In April 2015, USC Dance will present a unique and unprecedented concert to showcase the talent and productivity of its own legacy - the USC Alumni Choreography Showcase. With hopes to turn this inaugural event into an annual concert, USC Dance has chosen a select few of its alumni choreographers to present their work in this concert, including 2012 graduate (and recipient of the USC Dance Director’s Award) Caitlin McCormack. Caitlin has been recognized for her creative approach to choreography and staging not only during her tenure as a USC student, with four pieces presented in USC Dance concerts, but also since her graduation in regional festivals, showcases, and performing companies, including Dance Canvas (Atlanta, GA) and Dance Augusta (Augusta, GA). As inventive as her choreographic style, Caitlin is innovative in her approach to collaboration and rehearsal for her works, and has often worked with dancers both on-site and long-distance in order to incorporate the talent and quality of movement that best reflects her vision. Of her participation and selection as a featured Choreographer for this concert, Caitlin says "I’ve been given an exciting opportunity to choreograph on the University of South Carolina Dance Company for their first ever Alumni Showcase, and I’ll be using 17 current USC dancers alongside 5 Alumni dancers: Jackie Ball, Tricia Koch, Paige Maxwell, Katie Owerbach, and Taylor Ferguson. This will be a true representation of USC Dance with current majors sharing the stage with alumni dancers who have gone on to dance professionally." 

In the spirit of showcasing and honoring the success of USC Dance and its alumni, Caitlin’s goal is to fully fund the travel costs of these alumni dancers, who will be traveling to Columbia from multiple locations- Atlanta, Philadelphia, Orlando, and Charleston to participate and perform in this exciting collaboration. All donations will exclusively support travel costs for these dancers, and any additional funds raised will compensate them for their performance work, which each dancer has generously committed to regardless of support outcomes. Thank you for your consideration and willingness to donate and support the arts in this personal and exciting way!

story:
Link To The Show:

https://youtu.be/0QsZObeTMc0

Support New Work And The Barbershop Theater!

This February 27th come see the Youtube premiere of Commitment at The Barbershop Theater! The show is free to all! Every dollar donated will be split 50/50 between The Barbershop Theater and the cost of new sheet music for Commitment. If we reach the goal of $1200 everything over the top will go 100% to The Barbershop Theater!

What Is Commitment?

Liam Searcy's Commitment is a song cycle headed to NYC at 54 Below this June.  This new work explores modern relationships and the way we perceive commitment. . . or lack thereof. Through this collection of individual stories commitment is found to be just as dangerous as it is beautiful. 

Check the upcoming NYC concert here: https://54below.com/events/commitment-a-song-cy...

What Is The Barbershop Theater?

The Barbershop Theater is a blackbox in Nashville TN. Their Mission: 

"To provide an affordable space for Nashville theatre companies and other artists to rehearse, perform, and exhibit their work"

In March of 2018 Nettie Kraft and Graham Mote bought the Barbershop with the goal of sharing this space with the performing artists and art lovers of Nashville.

Find out more at: http://thebarbershoptheater.com/

story:
Summary

Always Plenty of Light at the Starlight All Night Diner is a SUPER queer time travel adventure. WITH DINOSAURS. Dangerous Play is PUMPED to have been accepted into All Out Arts' 2016 Fresh Fruit Festival this summer - it means our show will get to travel to NYC in all of its time traveling GLORY and QUEER ROMANCE for 3 whole shows! But although the Festival covers many costs (venue, marketing, tech support etc.) we need your help to come up with the rest. Time Travel ain’t cheap and neither is theater, but with a little help, we can all get to where we need to be- whether it’s the Fresh Fruit Fest this July, or SIXTY FIVE MILLION YEARS IN THE PAST (no refunds.)

What We Need 

Dangerous Play is dedicated to paying our artists for their ART. We are hoping to raise $2,000 through this campaign. This will allow us to:

  • Pay our creative team (director, actors, stage manager, designers)
  • Pay for our rehearsal space
  • Purchase appropriate costumes, props, set pieces
  • Reimburse our artists for their travel expenses!
  • Care and keeping of dinosaurs

The Show

Always Plenty of Light at the Starlight All Night Diner will be presented at the 2016 Fresh Fruit Festival at the Wild Project Theatre in Manhattan. There will be performances on:

Monday, July 18th: 7pm
Wednesday, July 20nd: 9pm
Friday, July 22th: 9pm

Buy tickets here: https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/cal/527

The Impact

Dangerous Play is committed to producing new, risk-taking works that are immediate in nature and diverse in voice. By supporting Dangerous Play and Always Plenty of Light at the Starlight All Night Diner you’re helping to bring queer voices to stage. In addition, we support the work of a diverse group of artists underrepresented in the theater community. By supporting us, you’re supporting change onstage and behind the scenes.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know all too well that sometimes donating money just isn't a possibility. But that doesn't mean you can't help! If you support our project, please consider:

  • Sharing the news about our project and our campaign!
  • Coming to see our show!
  • Supporting our art! Visit Dangerous Play on Social Media and like or follow us.
  • Stay tuned for more projects!

Even if you can only donate a few bucks, every dollar helps us get closer to our goal!

Thank you so much for reading, and for your support! 

Sincerely,
Darcy Parker Bruce and J. Mehr Kaur

story:
Jacob Marley's Christmas Carol is the premiere production of Ensemble Theatre Company. This one man show written by Tom Mula is a new twist on the holiday classic A Christmas Carol, told from a fresh perspective. This family friendly show will be playing at North Carolina Stage Company December 19th through December 30th. For more information and to purchase tickets, please visit www.ncstage.org or call 828-239-0263.

 

Ensemble Theatre Company's Mission is to provide high quality, artistically rewarding theatrical productions that challenge, enlighten, engage and entertain audiences. From new works to classics, we will focus on the ensemble and the collaborative process as vital factors for artistic success and integrity. It is our hope to bring diverse artistic expressions together as a single voice.

 

How can you support us?

First and foremost, spread the word!! Word of mouth is the best publicity that we can get.

Second, buy tickets!! You won't want to miss this high quality holiday production.

Third, donate!! Indiegogo allows for supporters from across the world to support projects that are important to them. If you'd like to invest in ours (and we hope you do!) we'll thank you with fantastic gifts.

 

 

What impact will my donation have?

Your generous support will help to fund every aspect of producing a professional theatrical performance, as well as the beginnings of a unique theatre company. From the sound and the lights to the videos and the rights, producing a top quality play is a formidable undertaking. Every contribution will bring us a step closer to realizing our vision for professional theatre in Western North Carolina.

 

Every dollar makes a difference, but if a financial contribution is not a possibility for you, please spread the word!!

story:
About The Agency

The Agency Theater Collective is a non-profit theater company whose mission is to produce new and under-produced plays in Chicago. Since 2011, we have produced seven world premieres, including the acclaimed I Wish To Apologize To The People of Illinois and the Jeff nominated Truth in Context.

About The Play

Hellcab portrays the story of a cab driver in for the longest night of her life as she transports a bizarre and mysterious array of customers through the gritty streets of Chicago. Playwright Will Kern draws from personal experience as a former cab driver to create this alternately frightening, hilarious and poignant journey. Set during a bitter cold Christmas in 1992, Hellcab presents a look at humanity that is just as vital today as it was 20 years ago.

What We Need & What You Get

Producing a play of any size is a major undertaking. Your contribution will help in offsetting those costs and allow us to bring the granular realism from the page to stage. Specifically, your donation will help us pay for: theater rental, costumes, set construction, lighting equipment, sound equipment, marketing costs, and paying our artists and crew. 

Perks you can receive with your contribution include a personalized video message, an autographed poster, acting classes, and more!

Other Ways You Can Help

We are sincerely grateful for any donation you can make to support our project. In addition to a donation, you can also help by sharing this campaign with your friends, family and co-workers. Also, we hope you'll come see our show!

story:
DONATIONS and PERKS:

Your donation goes directly to indiegogo.com, which will make a single payment to The Old Globe, and it is not tax-deductible as a charitable donation.  We thank you from the bottom of our hearts!

All promotional items provided directly by Mr. George Takei as a gift to fan supporters.  The Old Globe is not responsible for providing any of the stated perks.


Our Story

On February 19th, 1942, President Roosevelt signed Executive Order 9066, which authorized the removal and relocation of all Japanese Americans from the West Coast. Thousands of families, like George Takei's, were forced from their homes and sent, sometimes hundreds of miles away, to live in barricaded camps behind walls of barbed wire. This often "overlooked" injustice forever changed the lives of over 120,000 people.

Allegiance is an epic story of love, war and heroism set during the Japanese American internment. It tells of the Omura family in the weeks and years following Pearl Harbor, as they are relocated from their home in Salinas, California to the Heart Mountain internment camp in the wastelands of Wyoming. It seeks to shine a bright light on such a dark chapter of America's history.


The Impact

Using Musical Theater as a medium, and with the help of the international influence of our lead actors George Takei and Lea Salonga, Allegiance plans to spread this message to the world. We won't stop until as many people as possible  know of this story, and take the time to learn more about what happened during this time. This will also be the first time that Asian Americans will be represented to this magnitude on the stage.  While only approximately 2% of Broadway roles are made for Asian Americans, Allegiance utilizes over 70% Asian actors.


What We Need & What You Get

Allegiance is at a crucial time in its development.  It has been offered a world renowned regional theater stage on which to fully mount this work for the first time. It will finally be given the sets, lights, and costumes that a show of this magnitude requires.  For the first time, hundreds of people will be able to sit, every night, and watch this groundbreaking musical. But we need your help!


The Old Globe is the theater in San Diego, California that has agreed to mount the World Premiere of Allegiance.  Your contribution will play a key role in the financing of such a large undertaking. With your donation, large or small, you will pledge that you believe, like us, that this story must be told.  By supporting us, you will become a member of the ever-growing Allegiance family, and you will stand beside us as we spread our message.


In recognition of your support, certain "perks" will be made available.  Everything from recognition on our highly trafficked website to VIP tickets to the opening night of Allegiance are available as a thank you for your contribution.  Please, pledge today.  We deeply appreciate your help.


Other Ways You Can Help

Talk about us!  Learn about the internment, and talk about the show and its message with your families and friends.  Please visit our website (http://www.allegiancemusical.) to learn more about the show and watch some videos, and see just how incredibly powerful this story truly is.  We can't spread our message with out your help.  Pledge your Allegiance today!

Talk about us!  Learn about the internment, and talk about the show and its message with your families and friends.  Please visit our website (http://www.allegiancemusical.) to learn more about the show and watch some videos, and see just how incredibly powerful this story truly is.  We can't spread our message with out your help.  Pledge your Allegiance today!

story:
Flamenco Latino Mission

We were founded  to explore and expand the Ida y Vuelta or “Round Trip” genre of Flamenco dance. This genre reflects an influence of Afro Hispanic movement, rhythm and melody on Spanish dance and music during the 18th century. This process continues in contemporary flamenco, and Flamenco Latino’s perspective brings a unique brand to the art form. Over 35 years, the mission has evolved to include instruction in all aspects of traditional flamenco, as well as providing students with a pathway from the classroom to the stage.

Flamenco Latino Programming

Our programming includes flamenco dance, guitar and cante instruction to adults and children year-round, outreach programs to underserved communities, workshops with guest artists from Spain, and on-site concerts and recitals. Very few NYC dance studios permit flamenco, so we are home to other independent artists who rent down time in our studios.

Preserving Our Unique Space

Since acquiring our Midtown West space in 2006, we have transformed it for dual use as a dance studio and theater. Since 2014, our space cost has represented 65% of the annual budget, requiring a large focus on studio rentals to cover expenses. Many studio rentals have not been for flamenco, limiting us in developing more mission-based income and support.

During the Fall of 2015, a studio rental client using 18 hours/week left unexpectedly, leaving us $25,000 short in the annual budget, or about $2,500 per month. In a way, this was a push for us to start developing more mission-based income and support, but it will take us at least 6 months to make headway.

We have applied for grants to expand our programming, and develop alliances and partnerships during 2016. If we can supplement about half of the lost income through this funding campaign, we can eventually become more self-sufficient.

What We're Asking and How It Will Be Used

The $6,000 funding will provide for 50% of the lost studio rental income for 5 months from Jan. 15-June 15, 2016 (about $1,200 per month). Over this term, it will help to pay about 10-20% of the following expenses:

$1,000, Artistic Director Aurora Reyes' salary.

$1,000, Music Director Basilio Georges' salary.

$3,600, rent.

$230, electricity and phones.

$70, maintenance.

$100, liability insurance.

Perks

Flamenco Latino has set 9 levels of donation values, along with perks ranging from mp3 downloads, discounts on group classes, discounts on upcoming Dec. and June concert tickets, copies of two different CDs, and attendance at an exclusive Meet the Artists Reception for “Flamenco Gumbo II,” taking place in late July 2016.

If the Funding Goal Is Not Reached, Then What?

If the full goal is not reached, any portion raised will be applied to the same needs. Flamenco Latino’s lease runs through July 2018. The Board is strategizing a plan for self-sufficiency in the present space. Funds raised by this campaign will allow the planning process to take place with less financial stress. If Flamenco Latino did not undertake this campaign, it would have to consider leaving the space before the lease is up.

The Impact

Our annual budget is $162,000. We are small and lean. A successful campaign will increase our total donation level by 40%, and strengthen our financial profile when we apply for future grants. Being able to show a healthy percentage of donation income on grant applications is a huge plus for showing organizational stability.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, you can help us out by sharing this link with your own contacts through emails and social networking. Check out our social networking links at FaceBook, YouTube, Twitter, and ReverbNation, and pass them around.

story:
This is a call to action, for your generous support which will aid Jocelyn Tan and Neo Jialing, two Singapore-based, independent artists towards co-producing and presenting a new, original collaborative work.

We’ve had the wonderful honour of being selected and invited by MOTUS Danza Compagnia for a 10-day residency programme for young creatives, in Siena, Italy, as part of the company’s bi-annual Move Off Spring Dance Festival 2019. As relatively young artists, this marks our first collaborative, overseas residency opportunity, which will culminate in a premiere of our new original creation on an international platform.

Having first met at and graduated from LASALLE College of The Arts, both Jocelyn and Jialing have been consistently keen on creating multi-disciplinary, exploratory works together. As a collective, we’ve had the chance to create and perform together for the past 3 years on different platforms, taking the chance to experiment and explore on our genuine curiosity of the potentialities of what we believe music and movement can extend to. Working together, there was always a indescribable workflow where we both felt challenged and pushed by the other to expand (and expend) on our personal limitations of our own artistic disciplines.

Therefore, with this residency in mind, we decided to take the next big leap on our collaborative journey, and use this as a chance to further push the boundaries of own artistic capabilities. Both of us intend to spend these few months leading up to the residency - in addition to the actual residency itself - developing a working methodology across music and movement that would aid in our own practice as artists, and also efficiently generate artistic material that truly encapsulates the stories and ideas that we want to share.

In short:

With the notion of “what is most personal is most universal” (Carl R. Rogers, On Becoming A Person) -- we will attempt, through this new work-in-progress, to harness a deep personal impetus and eventually create a raw yet distinctively challenging piece where the elements of music and movement co-exist in a symbiotic relationship. Ultimately, we hope to elicit a visceral response from audiences, and inspire retrospection.

WHAT IS THE RESIDENCY ABOUT?

Offered by MOTUS Danza Compagnia, this residency is an opportunity for us to spend 10 days in Siena, Italy, to workshop and further develop our work-in-progress under the mentorship of Simona Cieri, artistic director of MOTUS. The residency will eventually culminate in the premiere of our work in the Castelnuovo Berardenga Theatre (Teatro Alfieri). Through this opportunity, we hope to bring greater awareness to Singaporean multi-disciplinary work, as well as make a statement about how independent and relatively small-scale collectives are able to make a huge creative impact as well!

MOTUS is a dance company based in Siena, supported by Tuscany Region and Siena City, with artistic residencies in Italy (Castelnuovo Berardenga, Sovicille) and abroad. Featuring a repertoire rich in collaboration with composers and artists, the company has embraced the search for new vocabularies where the body language is used to address arguments of social impact.

We are fortunate to have been kindly provided with food and accommodation throughout the 10-day duration of our residency by MOTUS, in addition to rehearsal and production support.

However, the total estimated cost of the travel expenses as well as pre-trip preparation is slightly beyond what we can afford at this stage of our careers. Hence, we would be super stoked if you could help us!

HOW CAN YOU HELP?

Every cent, dollar and non-tangible form of support is greatly appreciated!

Even if you may not have the means to support us monetarily, just the act of sharing this page, generating buzz about our work, or giving us moral, emotional and mental support will really help us snail our way towards our hopes and dreams.

To illustrate (and keep things transparent!) why we need the amount as stated in this campaign, here is a breakdown of our projected spending:

BUDGET BREAKDOWN

Trip Expenses

  • Airfare (round-trip): SGD$3600
  • Transportation : SGD$240
    (land - to/fro airport)
  • Living expenses: SGD$1000
  • Insurance: SGD$300
    (personal/ instrument/ equipment)
  • SIM card: SGD$60

Creative Expenses

  • Studio rental: SGD$2400
    (for rehearsals prior to the duration of residency)
  • Props: SGD$80
  • Recording equipment: SGD$730
    (e.g. microphone, video recorder, etc. - for documentation purposes)
  • Electronics: SGD$850
    (for musical creation, e.g. vocal effects processor)
  • Costumes: SGD$150

ESTIMATED TOTAL SPENDING: SGD$9410

However, we feel that it’ll only be prudent for us to request for only a portion of the full amount stated - essentially, the basic expenses that will bring us to and sustain us in Italy, which amounts to SGD$7000 (USD$5500).

Why do we need so much?

This is an amount that we tabulated, taking into consideration of whatever we are fortunate enough to raise, would still be subjected to Indiegogo’s platform commission and costs:

5% of amount raised SGD$7000 x 5% = SGD$350
3% + .30 credit card fees
$25 international transfer fee

In the awesome scenario where we hit our goal, an estimated $500 of that would be used to repay indiegogo for giving us this platform to share about our work and process.

WHAT YOU GET IN RETURN

Our eternal gratitude and acknowledgements in the credits of our artistic output!

In addition, we have listed some perks/ gifts which we can humbly offer at this time, from our own efforts and side-interests of craft-making, so depending on the amount you donate, you'll receive a little handmade token from us. <3

Also, in the event that we reach our goal, we intend to donate the surplus we garner to The Business Times Budding Artist Fund (https://baf.sg/), as we truly share their vision that "no child, regardless of personal circumstances, should be denied the opportunity to pursue the arts". If possible, we too, want to share the privilege that your generous support gives us.

WHY IS THIS IMPORTANT TO US, AND TO YOU?

As independent artists, we firmly believe in continually pushing ourselves to generate work that is both fulfilling with regards to our personal growth and artistic integrity, as well as to provoke emotional and visceral responses to art. By collaborating across our disciplines, we hope to examine how reaching beyond our own scope of creating art can generate more possibility for growth and learning as individuals and practitioners. Also, we trust in the generous help of all our supporters to launch our dreams into a reality, proving that small collectives like us can go far too!

After this residency, we plan to give back to the Singaporean arts scene by presenting a local showing of our original work, as well as organise workshops to share the experience/ methodology generated from this entire journey.

Further details on the plans we have for our sharing workshops/ showings along the way would be posted up as we progress -- supporters of our project can look forward to being invited to participate/ watch, as guests and perhaps even, critics of our work to help us learn and improve. 

Thank you for reading your way this far, and if you have the time, do watch the video above to get a glimpse of an excerpt of a past work we've worked together on.

With much appreciation,

WHO ARE WE?

jocelyn tan

An aspiring multi-disciplinary artist whose instrument specialties include the sheng, gamelan and piano. Jocelyn graduated from LASALLE College of the Arts with a BA(Hons) in Music (Composition), and her musical language is deeply influenced by Asian traditional music styles. She enjoys creating works that incorporate ethnic instruments into non-traditional genres and configurations, as well as working with artists across varying disciplines.

Click through to her bio to find out more!

neo jialing

A BA(Hons) Dance graduate from LASALLE College of the Arts, Jialing has a strong penchant for somatic, improvisational and creative movement techniques in dance.  Driven by the belief that dance is a visceral medium of expression, she hopes to be able to share her passion for movement with bodies beyond the dance landscape. Most recently, Jialing had her work selected to be featured in the M1 Contact Contemporary Dance Festival 2018, on the Off Stage work-in-progress platform. When she's not dancing, she enjoys staging mini showdowns in the kitchen where the pasta and potatoes play the lead roles.

Click through to her instagram to find out more!

story:
Summary

We are a small group of creatives bonded together by the desire to tell interesting and profound stories. We have been doing theatre in Houston for a short time, but we have all come from a background of performance, art, and storytelling. We are excited to bring the story of Delilah front and center on the stage straight from the page. 

As people who populate this earth, there are many times we feel silenced as people as if someone else has taken the liberty to tell our story for us. It is this exact thing that happens to Delilah. Her story is told in the bible by a writer who is not her, and whose primary focus is on that of her husband, Samson, leaving much to be speculated about what happened to Delilah. Here in the pages of Lock by Lock Delilah finds her voice, and finds a way to have her say and tell her story the way she knows it. This story of love, strength, and redemption tells an important message: through the telling of this story we want you to know that there are always many sides to every story, and your perspective on your story is always important and invaluable. 

By helping us launch the Lock by Lock project, you help ensure the telling of an important and profound story about faith, hope, and love. We hope to encourage and inspire others to tell their own stories, make their own art, and boldly share their unique perspectives and poignant truths with the world. 

What We Need & What You Get

Ultimately, we need money for paying all the wonderful people on this team for their labor and for the materials in order to create the pieces that come together to form the story we are telling. Your money will go to the paying of the venue, the labor and time of the people working on this project, the making of props, set, costumes, promotional materials such as posters and social media logos,  and of course our perks! 

With every increase in monetary donation, you get not only the perk you qualify for but every perk that comes before it. For example, should you donate $15 to become a Character Reference, you will not only receive a thank you note from someone on our team, but also a social media shoutout, and a spot on our acknowledgment wall. Our perks are broken down as so: 

$5 and up-  Friend of the Show- receive a social media shoutout from us when we share how thankful we are for the contributions made that day. 

$10 and up- Public Defendant- have your name displayed in our acknowledgment wall. Your name will be written into a lock of hair on our commissioned silhouette of Delilah. This will be displayed on the gallery wall during the run of the show. 

$15 and up- Character Reference - you will receive a thank you note from someone on our team thanking you for your contribution and expressing our gratitude for your help in telling this story. 

$20 and up- Exhibit A - You will receive a printed out 5x7 promotional photo of the show 

$40 and up- Exhibit A, Cont. -  You get a matted 5x7 (up to 8x10) promotional photo. The matting will be signed by the cast and crew.

$50 and up- Evidence Log - You receive a Signed edition of Lock by Lock with a personal note from our writer, Katherine Mulvaney. 

$100 and up- Jury Summons - VIP seat (24 available in Houston, 12 available for the Beaumont show) There is a limited amount of jury VIP seats, 12 for every performance, and the people in these seats will be directly addressed by Delilah, possibly even handed props and asked to interact with the show at certain points. This is a wonderful opportunity to not only contribute to a worthwhile project but also engage in the show in a special way. 

$250 and up- Opening Night Angel (6 available for opening night) Opening night angel seats can be for any night, though we would love if you came to the show on opening night. You receive 2 VIP seats for you and a plus one, and an invitation to the opening night after-party with the cast and crew.

If we do not reach our goal, the money we do get will go to paying the hardworking talent that is making the show happen as well as to the venue so that we can use their facilities. 

The Impact

Lock by Lock was originally written as a novella in poetic verse. It is a retelling of the biblical story Samson and Delilah from Delilah’s point of view, thus giving Delilah a voice she doesn’t have in the Old Testament. Delilah tells her story in the past tense, giving the reader the sense that she is telling her story on the day of judgment. The story has never been staged until now. This show is extremely important to the people on our team for many reasons, and this project has made a huge impact on our lives already. We are all passionate people who are all connected by our passion for telling unique stories. Here are some quotes from the members of the team on why this project is so important: 

“ As a kid, I was always fairly shy and I didn’t speak very often. At least, I never felt like I spoke all that much--not in such a way that people heard me or listened. For this reason, I have always been drawn to stories about the disenfranchised and the silenced. Projects like these are the reason I went into theatre. I found my voice in performing and storytelling, and it is why I want so badly to give a voice to those who don’t have one. This project tells the story of a silenced woman who refuses to be silent any longer, and I find that absolutely inspiring.” - Teresa Stranahan, Director and Producer 

 

“I went through a period of writing where all I seemed to do was make Biblical women sass people, and while all the one-woman shows I started writing during that period eventually got absorbed into other projects, it feels like Lock by Lock is getting back to its roots by going onstage.  I have a complex relationship with my faith and the Catholic church’s approach to women, and the chance to take back Delilah’s story from those who read it as hating women, hating foreigners, or devaluing human connection as a distraction from devotion to God was too good to pass up. Once I started the work, however, I became all the more frustrated with those limited, hateful readings of the story.  The story is even more remarkable through Delilah’s eyes, without turning Samson into the “real” villain of the piece like some Disney remake. Now I forever see this Bible story as proof that our hate and intolerance keeps us from seeing the true beauty at the core of our world.” - Katy Mulvaney, Writer of Lock by Lock

“It’s never been a secret that written history is not a collaborative project. The story of Samson and Delilah is functionally a history for major religions across continents, written with only Samson’s journey in mind. Theatre is the ultimate collaborative project - a bond is created with the creative team, the actors, and the audience, and we all get to participate in the journey of the story each performance. I am glad we get to give a voice to functional voiceless, to collaborate in our history this time.” - Victoria Hidalgo, Stage manager

 

Risks & Challenges

Putting on a show is not easy work. Ther are many moving parts and many people that have to be taken into account. Primarily, getting people in the door to see this show will be our greatest obstacle. Second is collecting the funds, part of the solution being this campaign. 

Ticket Sales- Getting people in the door will be the most difficult part of our job. We plan to put our show on every free event calendar that caters to the Houston area, build relationships with independent writers and bloggers, head an excellent social media campaign, and partner with local businesses and other theaters and other grassroots creatives to get the word out about our show. Should we have 1 or 100 audience members, we will still deliver quality performance and profound storytelling. 

Money is tight- Our group consists of a professional actor, a teacher, a sales clerk, a paralegal, and a barista. We are all fairly young and not making enough money to have disposable income in investing in projects like these. This provides us a very small amount of buffer should this campaign not be as successful as we hope. However, we do not despair. We are resourceful. We plan to tackle the possibility of a lack of funds with innovation. Props can be made, costumes sourced from our connections, and people found. We are tenacious and eager. These things count for a lot. Plus, there is a small gathering of funds that have been set aside should anything drastic occur throughout this process. We hope to not have to use it, but should the occasion arise, we will do what needs to be done. 

Our team has worked in Houston together for a short time, however, we have all had projects we have done on our own be it art gallery shows, developing cosplay characters, publishing books, or staging other shows. We have accomplished great things on our own, and we are excited to see what we can accomplish together. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Because we are all in the business we are in, we completely understand that it is not always possible to financially contribute to a project like this one. If you find yourself drawn to this project and wish to make a meaningful contribution, there are many things you could do to make sure this show becomes a success: 

 

Share this Page- Word of mouth is invaluable in crowdfunding campaigns, and this show could use all the help it can get. If you know of anyone who may want to contribute, no matter how small the amount, we are grateful. You can use the Indie Gogo share tools to get the word out about this show and this funding effort. Every penny counts for us! 

Share our social media pages - as always marketing is invaluable, and social media helps us get the word out. Find us on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter. Give us a like, follow us, and share our content. 

Join our team- We have most of the roles fulfilled, but we are looking for ushers and ticket takers for the day of as well as folks who are willing to distribute advertising materials around the city. Each volunteer usher, poster distributor,  and/ or ticket taker will get to see the show for free! 

Become a partner- We are looking for folks who are willing to put up posters in their businesses, churches, and other community spots to put the word out about the show. If you have a place for us to advertise, please reach out to us. We would love to give you advertising materials to put up in your community.
story_txt: SummaryWe are a small group of creatives bonded together by the desire to tell interesting and profound stories. We have been doing theatre in Houston for a short time, but we have all come from a background of performance, art, and storytelling. We are excited to bring the story of Delilah front and center on the stage straight from the page. As people who populate this earth, there are many times we feel silenced as people as if someone else has taken the liberty to tell our story for us. It is this exact thing that happens to Delilah. Her story is told in the bible by a writer who is not her, and whose primary focus is on that of her husband, Samson, leaving much to be speculated about what happened to Delilah. Here in the pages of Lock by Lock Delilah finds her voice, and finds a way to have her say and tell her story the way she knows it. This story of love, strength, and redemption tells an important message: through the telling of this story we want you to know that there are always many sides to every story, and your perspective on your story is always important and invaluable. By helping us launch the Lock by Lock project, you help ensure the telling of an important and profound story about faith, hope, and love. We hope to encourage and inspire others to tell their own stories, make their own art, and boldly share their unique perspectives and poignant truths with the world. What We Need & What You GetUltimately, we need money for paying all the wonderful people on this team for their labor and for the materials in order to create the pieces that come together to form the story we are telling. Your money will go to the paying of the venue, the labor and time of the people working on this project, the making of props, set, costumes, promotional materials such as posters and social media logos,  and of course our perks! With every increase in monetary donation, you get not only the perk you qualify for but every perk that comes before it. For example, should you donate $15 to become a Character Reference, you will not only receive a thank you note from someone on our team, but also a social media shoutout, and a spot on our acknowledgment wall. Our perks are broken down as so: $5 and up-  Friend of the Show- receive a social media shoutout from us when we share how thankful we are for the contributions made that day. $10 and up- Public Defendant- have your name displayed in our acknowledgment wall. Your name will be written into a lock of hair on our commissioned silhouette of Delilah. This will be displayed on the gallery wall during the run of the show. $15 and up- Character Reference - you will receive a thank you note from someone on our team thanking you for your contribution and expressing our gratitude for your help in telling this story. $20 and up- Exhibit A - You will receive a printed out 5x7 promotional photo of the show $40 and up- Exhibit A, Cont. -  You get a matted 5x7 (up to 8x10) promotional photo. The matting will be signed by the cast and crew.$50 and up- Evidence Log - You receive a Signed edition of Lock by Lock with a personal note from our writer, Katherine Mulvaney. $100 and up- Jury Summons - VIP seat (24 available in Houston, 12 available for the Beaumont show) There is a limited amount of jury VIP seats, 12 for every performance, and the people in these seats will be directly addressed by Delilah, possibly even handed props and asked to interact with the show at certain points. This is a wonderful opportunity to not only contribute to a worthwhile project but also engage in the show in a special way. $250 and up- Opening Night Angel (6 available for opening night) Opening night angel seats can be for any night, though we would love if you came to the show on opening night. You receive 2 VIP seats for you and a plus one, and an invitation to the opening night after-party with the cast and crew.If we do not reach our goal, the money we do get will go to paying the hardworking talent that is making the show happen as well as to the venue so that we can use their facilities. The ImpactLock by Lock was originally written as a novella in poetic verse. It is a retelling of the biblical story Samson and Delilah from Delilah’s point of view, thus giving Delilah a voice she doesn’t have in the Old Testament. Delilah tells her story in the past tense, giving the reader the sense that she is telling her story on the day of judgment. The story has never been staged until now. This show is extremely important to the people on our team for many reasons, and this project has made a huge impact on our lives already. We are all passionate people who are all connected by our passion for telling unique stories. Here are some quotes from the members of the team on why this project is so important: “ As a kid, I was always fairly shy and I didn’t speak very often. At least, I never felt like I spoke all that much--not in such a way that people heard me or listened. For this reason, I have always been drawn to stories about the disenfranchised and the silenced. Projects like these are the reason I went into theatre. I found my voice in performing and storytelling, and it is why I want so badly to give a voice to those who don’t have one. This project tells the story of a silenced woman who refuses to be silent any longer, and I find that absolutely inspiring.” - Teresa Stranahan, Director and Producer  “I went through a period of writing where all I seemed to do was make Biblical women sass people, and while all the one-woman shows I started writing during that period eventually got absorbed into other projects, it feels like Lock by Lock is getting back to its roots by going onstage.  I have a complex relationship with my faith and the Catholic church’s approach to women, and the chance to take back Delilah’s story from those who read it as hating women, hating foreigners, or devaluing human connection as a distraction from devotion to God was too good to pass up. Once I started the work, however, I became all the more frustrated with those limited, hateful readings of the story.  The story is even more remarkable through Delilah’s eyes, without turning Samson into the “real” villain of the piece like some Disney remake. Now I forever see this Bible story as proof that our hate and intolerance keeps us from seeing the true beauty at the core of our world.” - Katy Mulvaney, Writer of Lock by Lock“It’s never been a secret that written history is not a collaborative project. The story of Samson and Delilah is functionally a history for major religions across continents, written with only Samson’s journey in mind. Theatre is the ultimate collaborative project - a bond is created with the creative team, the actors, and the audience, and we all get to participate in the journey of the story each performance. I am glad we get to give a voice to functional voiceless, to collaborate in our history this time.” - Victoria Hidalgo, Stage manager Risks & ChallengesPutting on a show is not easy work. Ther are many moving parts and many people that have to be taken into account. Primarily, getting people in the door to see this show will be our greatest obstacle. Second is collecting the funds, part of the solution being this campaign. Ticket Sales- Getting people in the door will be the most difficult part of our job. We plan to put our show on every free event calendar that caters to the Houston area, build relationships with independent writers and bloggers, head an excellent social media campaign, and partner with local businesses and other theaters and other grassroots creatives to get the word out about our show. Should we have 1 or 100 audience members, we will still deliver quality performance and profound storytelling. Money is tight- Our group consists of a professional actor, a teacher, a sales clerk, a paralegal, and a barista. We are all fairly young and not making enough money to have disposable income in investing in projects like these. This provides us a very small amount of buffer should this campaign not be as successful as we hope. However, we do not despair. We are resourceful. We plan to tackle the possibility of a lack of funds with innovation. Props can be made, costumes sourced from our connections, and people found. We are tenacious and eager. These things count for a lot. Plus, there is a small gathering of funds that have been set aside should anything drastic occur throughout this process. We hope to not have to use it, but should the occasion arise, we will do what needs to be done. Our team has worked in Houston together for a short time, however, we have all had projects we have done on our own be it art gallery shows, developing cosplay characters, publishing books, or staging other shows. We have accomplished great things on our own, and we are excited to see what we can accomplish together. Other Ways You Can HelpBecause we are all in the business we are in, we completely understand that it is not always possible to financially contribute to a project like this one. If you find yourself drawn to this project and wish to make a meaningful contribution, there are many things you could do to make sure this show becomes a success:  Share this Page- Word of mouth is invaluable in crowdfunding campaigns, and this show could use all the help it can get. If you know of anyone who may want to contribute, no matter how small the amount, we are grateful. You can use the Indie Gogo share tools to get the word out about this show and this funding effort. Every penny counts for us! Share our social media pages - as always marketing is invaluable, and social media helps us get the word out. Find us on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter. Give us a like, follow us, and share our content. Join our team- We have most of the roles fulfilled, but we are looking for ushers and ticket takers for the day of as well as folks who are willing to distribute advertising materials around the city. Each volunteer usher, poster distributor,  and/ or ticket taker will get to see the show for free! Become a partner- We are looking for folks who are willing to put up posters in their businesses, churches, and other community spots to put the word out about the show. If you have a place for us to advertise, please reach out to us. We would love to give you advertising materials to put up in your community.

story:
said&done

 

We are a young professional theatre company established in 2012 and based in Liverpool, England. Our aims are:

 

  • to create powerful theatre that explores challenging themes
  • to provide sustainable employment for both established and emerging artists
  • to develop new audiences within the North West.

 

who we are

 

said&done was founded in 2012 by us: Gillian Lemon and Samantha Meisner.

 

Gillian is a freelance director and head of an acting course at The Liverpool Institute for Performing Arts (LIPA). She has worked for ATG and the National Student Theatre Company and has directed in various theatres across the UK. Her production of Hedwig and the Angry Inch for Lodestar Theatre Company, in 2010, won two Daily Post Awards.

 

Australian actor, Samantha graduated from LIPA in 2011. In training, she performed in numerous productions including Loyal Women, The Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe, Sweeney Todd and Les Liaisons Dangereuses. Since graduating, she has performed in Dirt [contained]’s production of new play, The Last Eden, several short films including Khalil the Great and Cut and said&done’s debut production of bash: latter day plays.

 

 

what we’ve done before

 

In June 2012, we produced our premier production, bash: latter day plays by Neil LaBute, at the Unity Theatre to a fantastic response. It was a small scale production with a minimal design concept that really allowed LaBute’s terse and tense text to come to the fore. The production was hailed as a production that  “pulls you in and keeps you in a state of quiet contemplation long after you’ve made your way home.” (The Public Reviews)

 

reviews for bash:latter day plays

 

http://madeup.lv/review-bashlatter-day-plays-unity-theatre

 

http://www.thepublicreviews.com/bash-latter-day-plays-the-unity-theatre-liverpool/

 

http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-entertainment/echo-reviews/2012/06/21/theatre-review-bash-the-latter-day-plays-100252-31228451/

 

the project

 

In collaboration with Unity Theatre, Liverpool, we’re staging a production of When the Rain Stops Falling by Andrew Bovell in June 2013.

 

This is an epic play, spanning eight decades, four generations and two hemispheres – two hemispheres that could not be further apart, not only geographically but also in their nature. The claustrophobia of London juxtaposed with the vast expanse of the Australian Desert; from the stifling heat of Alice Springs to the cold damp of London’s streets, from 1959 to 2039, from the extraordinary summit of Uluru to the ordinariness of a grimy London flat, we follow Gabriel Law as he retraces the paths of his ancestors, on a journey to piece together the jigsaw puzzle of his own identity.

 

why this play?

 

We’re really passionate about this play! As company founders we have a strong interest in its geographical roots, a love of two countries and two cultures, one of us from each (Britain and Australia). But really, it’s the universality of this story that excites and touches us most of all.

 

It’s a story of family and the struggles we face as descendants of a clan. It explores our ability to accept and to forgive the imperfections of our loved ones, an unconditional tie, and a bond that cannot be broken. And what are the consequences when we cannot accept and we cannot forgive?

 

The play looks at our histories, how our identities are shaped by events in our past, how these events play into our future. The question is, do we have a choice? Do we have the freedom to forge our own path or are we held ransom by the decisions and mistakes of our ancestors? And what happens when pieces of our past disappear, when people go missing and we lose a sense of self? Can we be whole without our history in tact?

 

The play also deals with subject matter that is often considered taboo: alcoholism; dementia; abuse and mental illness. It unearths the idea of loneliness in its many guises: how we can feel alone in a crowded city; alone in an intimate relationship; in the maze of our own diminishing mind; at the bottom of a bottle; in a desert town. Loneliness is a state of mind rather than a state of being. It is psychological, less physical.

 

For us, education and audience development are important parts of our work, so as well as producing this play, we will be providing opportunities for disadvantaged young people and carers of people who suffer from mental illness, to not only see the play but to take part in specially designed workshops with our actors.

 

the money

 

Where will your money go? If we raise £2000, it will pay salaries for two of our eight actors. Cuts in arts funding means that we have to be more resourceful and tighten our belts. Some companies choose to forgo paying their artists as a result. We shouldn't exploit their daring to live hand to mouth in order to tell the best stories. We shouldn't expect them to 'do it for the love of it'. We should be supporting and nurturing them for they are the future. We are a non-profit organisation who will bring you quality theatre. We are a small company but we will not ask actors, technicians or designers to work for free.

 Like the sound of this and want to be part of the big dream?

 

Support our work by donating. No matter how small or large the amount we raise, it will always go towards paying our artists.

 

what’s in it for you?

 

There are all kinds of goodies and acknowledgements up for grabs if you donate £10 or more to our campaign. See the ‘perks’ section for all the juicy details!

 

If you can’t afford it…

 

No worries! We totally get that. We’re starving artists too. If you can’t afford to give but you like the look of us and what we’re doing, please spread the word! Use the Indiegogo share tools and social media sites to tell all your friends! The more people that know about us and our project, the better.
