story:
**UPDATE 6/5: During our campaign, we received check donations totaling $725. After our campaign has ended, we have continued to receive donations directly at our Fractured Atlas site totaling $180. So the amount we raised is actually $905 higher than the total listed on the right!

If you'd like to contribute, it's not too late: https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/prof...

 About “The King’s Whore”

We are thrilled to be embarking on the journey to bring history alive with our theatrical production of "The King's Whore: The Anne Boleyn Story." The play is both compelling and historically accurate, including chunks of actual letters and speeches from Miss Boleyn. It is a modern theatrical re-telling of Anne's story that examines the political, religious, and human conditions that allowed a 16th-century woman trapped in a man’s world to change that world forever.

We have plans to give this sweeping story life with lavish and accurate period costumes, set in a high-quality off-off-broadway house (Walkerspace is officially booked!) under the AEA showcase code, and with skilled professional actors and top-notch direction.

Your contributions are what will make this project reach its full potential. We have already raised almost $15,000 in personal contributions, but need this additional $10,000 to finally bring this project to life.

********************************

“The actor is the athlete of the heart.

         -Antonin Artaud

The impressive feats of Olympic strength and skill are rivaled only by the arresting feats of the soul arising from the most daring acting. I am drawn to creating shared theatrical experiences that lead both audience and artists on a cathartic and ephemeral emotional journey together. Bravery, open-mindedness, and honesty from both parties are required to achieve this.

I choose to give breath and spirit to stories that profoundly move people, challenge deeply-entrenched stereotypes, and contextualize our modern day experience through an understanding of the past. Audiences are drawn to my vivacious energy and layered performances.

Illuminating the Anne Boleyn story for a modern audience was an obvious choice for someone so drawn to both the artistry of theatre and the machinations of politics. This immersive play shows how Anne moves passionately through a man’s world, refusing to bow to the accepted female behavior of the time. In doing this, she alters the course of English history, and even more importantly, of Western religious history as a whole. I have done my job if the audience leaves finding history half as accessible, vital, and compelling as I do.”

– Kate O’Phalen, Producer

********************************

Why Do You Need So Much Money?

The short reason is: producing theatre, especially in NYC, is very expensive! This is a very ambitious production that includes 10 actors and authentic Tudor costumes. We want to do this lavish period piece and beautiful story justice! These are just a few of our major expenses:

  • Theatre Rental: $15,000
  • Actor and Designer Stipends: $5,000
  • Period Costumes: $2,000
  • Rehearsal and Audition Space: $2,000
  • And much more!

Why This Play?

Anne Boleyn is a fascinating historical figure, as evidenced by the fact that we are still telling her story 500 years later. She was the first female commoner to ever be made a noble in her own right, and she rocked a nation by capturing the heart of a man who threw the Pope out of England for her.

Who will love this story besides Anne Boleyn aficionados?

  • Political aficionados will find the story of court politics shockingly similar to the issues of power and manipulation we deal with in the modern U.S.;
  • British expats and their American descendants will relish in an opportunity to process a crucial part of their cultural history onstage;
  • Feminists will love this depiction of one of the earliest women to challenge society’s standards for acceptable female behavior;
  • But most importantly, the play is compelling, engaging, and human enough to hold the interest of all lovers of drama.

Our Team of Professionals

Kate O’Phalen (Actor/Producer) is a passionate theatre artist, who has already found much success as a professional actress and theatre blogger.

Graduating from Hofstra University with both a B.F.A. in Theatre Arts and a B.A. in Political Science, with minors in English and European Studies, Kate has a unique combination of artistic talent and passion for the machinations of history and politics.

Kate has had the honor of working at many professional theaters as an actor, including in a production of Christopher Durang’s “Betty’s Summer Vacation” at Bay Street Theatre last year that featured three Tony-nominated actors, one of Off-Broadway’s busiest directors, and Mr. Durang himself in the rehearsal room.

Kate looks forward to repeating the success she found with her senior thesis production of Diana Son’s “Stop Kiss,” an artistically challenging and fulfilling piece that she both produced and starred in. She also looks forward to incorporating her strong social media presence into this production, utilizing both the facebook and twitter pages she has already set up for “The King’s Whore,” and her already-popular showbiz blog, GreenRoomBlog.com.

Kate is a proud member of Actors’ Equity Association, taking an active role in her union and the artistic community by serving on two committees and helping to negotiate contracts, define the new media landscape, and protect the rights of her fellow actors.

Jen Wineman (Director) is a director of theater and opera, living in New York City. Credits includes the upcoming Off Broadway production of David Eric Davis and Sam Forman’s F#%king Up Everything opening at the Elektra Theater in March, Donald Margulies’ Shipwrecked! An Entertainment (Triad Stage, Greensboro, NC); Roller Disco The Musical! (American Repertory Theater’s OBERON stage, Cambridge, MA), which she co-wrote with Sam Forman and Eli Bolin and also choreographed; Sarah Gancher’s Wake Up (Telluride Theatre, Telluride, CO), and the world premiere of José Rivera’s Lessons for an Unaccustomed Bride (59E59, NYC). She has also developed and directed work at New Georges, Dixon Place, Ars Nova, New York Stage and Film, the Experimental Theater of Vassar College, Manhattan School of Music, Williamstown Theatre Festival (workshop), and WordBRIDGE. Jen is a co-founder of Studio 42, a New York-based theater company that focuses on producing “unproducible” new plays by emerging artists. She is an affiliated artist at New Georges and was a member of Soho Rep’s 2011-2012 Writer/Director Lab. Up next for Jen is a new production of Naomi Iizuka’s play Aloha, Say the Pretty Girls for Theatre Vertigo in Portland, OR. Education: B.A. Vassar College, M.F.A. Yale School of Drama (Julian Kaufman Directing Prize). www.jenwineman.com.

Rob Santana (Playwright) studied playwriting/directing with Gene Frankel, 1980-83. He’s a graduate of the Center for the Media Arts (film & television writing) 1986. He also attended The NY Institute of Photography (motion picture production unit) 1969-1975. He worked with Richard Pyatt as an Asst. production Mgr for WNYC Radio (1969-75).

His play BOMBER JACKETS, was produced by Miriam Colon of the Puerto Rican Traveling Theatre, in April, 1996. (47th St. Theater) and is now a feature film making the festival rounds. His other plays professionally produced are: The Queen Bee’s Last Stand, produced by Frances Hill, Urban Stages, 1999-2000, and Chained Dog, produced first at Teatro La Tea (in english) then revived as Marido Encadenado at Repertorio Espanol by Rene Buch and Robert Federico in 2004-5. He has won several playwright awards, including the Julie Harris Competition in 1994, and Emerging Playwright Award in 2000 (Urban Stages).

Rob has written/directed three feature films: Bomber Jackets, Spanglish Girls, and Un-American, a 9/11 drama. He has many short films to his credits, including “5 Minutes with Frida”, an official selection of the 2011 Soho Film Festival. You can find NY Times and New Yorker reviews of his play, Bomber Jackets. His web site is: www.robsantana.org and he’s also listed on IMDB.

Lynde Rosario (Dramaturg) received her MFA from the American Repertory Theatre/Moscow Art Theatre Institute for Advanced Theatre Training at Harvard University and her BA from Hofstra University.  Her most recent credit as Dramaturg include the A.R.T.’s production of Chekhov’s Seagull and she is currently working with theatre youth groups on Long Island.   Her latest endeavor is as a blogger for the Green Room Blog, where she discusses the Dramaturg’s journey in the professional world.

Daniel O’Phalen (Casting Director) is a graduate of Hofstra University with a B.A. in Theatre Arts. He put acting behind him after catching the casting bug while interning with Liz Lewis Casting in 2008 and has been hot on the casting trail ever since.

He has worked on casting for television, film, theatre, and voice over work for offices across New York City such as Elissa Myers Casting, Downstairs Casting, and Small Pond Casting. He now runs his own casting agency called Hats Off Casting, in addition to a full-time position at Central Casting, where he works on TV shows such as “White Collar” and “Blue Bloods.” Daniel combines his intimate knowledge of the actor world and his perceptive understanding of people to bring about the best casts possible.

 

Can’t afford to donate, but still want to help?

If you just can’t spare the cash at the moment, you can definitely still help!

  • Forward this campaign on to a few friends and tell them why you think this is a worthwhile project.
  • Post about the campaign on your facebook wall.
  • Tweet about the campaign on twitter.

Word of mouth is one of the best ways to ensure our fundraising success -- so thank you!
story_txt:
**UPDATE 6/5: During our campaign, we received check donations totaling $725. After our campaign has ended, we have continued to receive donations directly at our Fractured Atlas site totaling $180. So the amount we raised is actually $905 higher than the total listed on the right! 
If you'd like to contribute, it's not too late: https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/prof...

 About “The King’s Whore”
We are thrilled to be embarking on the journey to bring history alive with our theatrical production of "The King's Whore: The Anne Boleyn Story." The play is both compelling and historically accurate, including chunks of actual letters and speeches from Miss Boleyn. It is a modern theatrical re-telling of Anne's story that examines the political, religious, and human conditions that allowed a 16th-century woman trapped in a man’s world to change that world forever.
We have plans to give this sweeping story life with lavish and accurate period costumes, set in a high-quality off-off-broadway house (Walkerspace is officially booked!) under the AEA showcase code, and with skilled professional actors and top-notch direction.
Your contributions are what will make this project reach its full potential. We have already raised almost $15,000 in personal contributions, but need this additional $10,000 to finally bring this project to life.
********************************
“The actor is the athlete of the heart.
         -Antonin Artaud
The impressive feats of Olympic strength and skill are rivaled only by the arresting feats of the soul arising from the most daring acting. I am drawn to creating shared theatrical experiences that lead both audience and artists on a cathartic and ephemeral emotional journey together. Bravery, open-mindedness, and honesty from both parties are required to achieve this.
I choose to give breath and spirit to stories that profoundly move people, challenge deeply-entrenched stereotypes, and contextualize our modern day experience through an understanding of the past. Audiences are drawn to my vivacious energy and layered performances.
Illuminating the Anne Boleyn story for a modern audience was an obvious choice for someone so drawn to both the artistry of theatre and the machinations of politics. This immersive play shows how Anne moves passionately through a man’s world, refusing to bow to the accepted female behavior of the time. In doing this, she alters the course of English history, and even more importantly, of Western religious history as a whole. I have done my job if the audience leaves finding history half as accessible, vital, and compelling as I do.”
– Kate O’Phalen, Producer
********************************
Why Do You Need So Much Money?
The short reason is: producing theatre, especially in NYC, is very expensive! This is a very ambitious production that includes 10 actors and authentic Tudor costumes. We want to do this lavish period piece and beautiful story justice! These are just a few of our major expenses:

Theatre Rental: $15,000
Actor and Designer Stipends: $5,000
Period Costumes: $2,000
Rehearsal and Audition Space: $2,000
And much more!
Why This Play?
Anne Boleyn is a fascinating historical figure, as evidenced by the fact that we are still telling her story 500 years later. She was the first female commoner to ever be made a noble in her own right, and she rocked a nation by capturing the heart of a man who threw the Pope out of England for her.
Who will love this story besides Anne Boleyn aficionados?

Political aficionados will find the story of court politics shockingly similar to the issues of power and manipulation we deal with in the modern U.S.;
British expats and their American descendants will relish in an opportunity to process a crucial part of their cultural history onstage;
Feminists will love this depiction of one of the earliest women to challenge society’s standards for acceptable female behavior;
But most importantly, the play is compelling, engaging, and human enough to hold the interest of all lovers of drama.
Our Team of Professionals

Kate O’Phalen (Actor/Producer) is a passionate theatre artist, who has already found much success as a professional actress and theatre blogger.
Graduating from Hofstra University with both a B.F.A. in Theatre Arts and a B.A. in Political Science, with minors in English and European Studies, Kate has a unique combination of artistic talent and passion for the machinations of history and politics.
Kate has had the honor of working at many professional theaters as an actor, including in a production of Christopher Durang’s “Betty’s Summer Vacation” at Bay Street Theatre last year that featured three Tony-nominated actors, one of Off-Broadway’s busiest directors, and Mr. Durang himself in the rehearsal room.
Kate looks forward to repeating the success she found with her senior thesis production of Diana Son’s “Stop Kiss,” an artistically challenging and fulfilling piece that she both produced and starred in. She also looks forward to incorporating her strong social media presence into this production, utilizing both the facebook and twitter pages she has already set up for “The King’s Whore,” and her already-popular showbiz blog, GreenRoomBlog.com.
Kate is a proud member of Actors’ Equity Association, taking an active role in her union and the artistic community by serving on two committees and helping to negotiate contracts, define the new media landscape, and protect the rights of her fellow actors.

Jen Wineman (Director) is a director of theater and opera, living in New York City. Credits includes the upcoming Off Broadway production of David Eric Davis and Sam Forman’s F#%king Up Everything opening at the Elektra Theater in March, Donald Margulies’ Shipwrecked! An Entertainment (Triad Stage, Greensboro, NC); Roller Disco The Musical! (American Repertory Theater’s OBERON stage, Cambridge, MA), which she co-wrote with Sam Forman and Eli Bolin and also choreographed; Sarah Gancher’s Wake Up (Telluride Theatre, Telluride, CO), and the world premiere of José Rivera’s Lessons for an Unaccustomed Bride (59E59, NYC). She has also developed and directed work at New Georges, Dixon Place, Ars Nova, New York Stage and Film, the Experimental Theater of Vassar College, Manhattan School of Music, Williamstown Theatre Festival (workshop), and WordBRIDGE. Jen is a co-founder of Studio 42, a New York-based theater company that focuses on producing “unproducible” new plays by emerging artists. She is an affiliated artist at New Georges and was a member of Soho Rep’s 2011-2012 Writer/Director Lab. Up next for Jen is a new production of Naomi Iizuka’s play Aloha, Say the Pretty Girls for Theatre Vertigo in Portland, OR. Education: B.A. Vassar College, M.F.A. Yale School of Drama (Julian Kaufman Directing Prize). www.jenwineman.com.

Rob Santana (Playwright) studied playwriting/directing with Gene Frankel, 1980-83. He’s a graduate of the Center for the Media Arts (film & television writing) 1986. He also attended The NY Institute of Photography (motion picture production unit) 1969-1975. He worked with Richard Pyatt as an Asst. production Mgr for WNYC Radio (1969-75).
His play BOMBER JACKETS, was produced by Miriam Colon of the Puerto Rican Traveling Theatre, in April, 1996. (47th St. Theater) and is now a feature film making the festival rounds. His other plays professionally produced are: The Queen Bee’s Last Stand, produced by Frances Hill, Urban Stages, 1999-2000, and Chained Dog, produced first at Teatro La Tea (in english) then revived as Marido Encadenado at Repertorio Espanol by Rene Buch and Robert Federico in 2004-5. He has won several playwright awards, including the Julie Harris Competition in 1994, and Emerging Playwright Award in 2000 (Urban Stages).
Rob has written/directed three feature films: Bomber Jackets, Spanglish Girls, and Un-American, a 9/11 drama. He has many short films to his credits, including “5 Minutes with Frida”, an official selection of the 2011 Soho Film Festival. You can find NY Times and New Yorker reviews of his play, Bomber Jackets. His web site is: www.robsantana.org and he’s also listed on IMDB.

Lynde Rosario (Dramaturg) received her MFA from the American Repertory Theatre/Moscow Art Theatre Institute for Advanced Theatre Training at Harvard University and her BA from Hofstra University.  Her most recent credit as Dramaturg include the A.R.T.’s production of Chekhov’s Seagull and she is currently working with theatre youth groups on Long Island.   Her latest endeavor is as a blogger for the Green Room Blog, where she discusses the Dramaturg’s journey in the professional world.

Daniel O’Phalen (Casting Director) is a graduate of Hofstra University with a B.A. in Theatre Arts. He put acting behind him after catching the casting bug while interning with Liz Lewis Casting in 2008 and has been hot on the casting trail ever since.
He has worked on casting for television, film, theatre, and voice over work for offices across New York City such as Elissa Myers Casting, Downstairs Casting, and Small Pond Casting. He now runs his own casting agency called Hats Off Casting, in addition to a full-time position at Central Casting, where he works on TV shows such as “White Collar” and “Blue Bloods.” Daniel combines his intimate knowledge of the actor world and his perceptive understanding of people to bring about the best casts possible.
 
Can’t afford to donate, but still want to help?
If you just can’t spare the cash at the moment, you can definitely still help!

Forward this campaign on to a few friends and tell them why you think this is a worthwhile project.
Post about the campaign on your facebook wall.
Tweet about the campaign on twitter.
Word of mouth is one of the best ways to ensure our fundraising success -- so thank you!

story:
Shared joy. Flights of fancy.

This August, Midsommer Flight will produce it's first production, an outdoor performance of William Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream.  We are thrilled and excited to present this Shakespeare in the park experience for FREE to our audiences - but that means we need your help to make it happen.

Please consider donating the cost of an average theatre ticket (anywhere from $50 to $20) to help us reach our $1,000 goal. Any money raised above this goal will be spent to improve production values, increase marketing efforts, and support other joyful things.

The play is directed by Midsommer Flight founder Beth Wolf. The stellar cast features Brit Cooper Robinson, Jared Dennis, Ross Patrick Frawley, Adrian Garcia, Jr., Monica Gilley, Adam Habben, Caroline Kingsley, Anne Korajczyk, Jason Markoff, J. Preddie Predmore, Jeannie Saracino, and Stephanie Shum. Additional production staff includes Zachary Justus and Ross Lemmon.

Midsommer Flight is a Chicago theatre collective dedicated to producing outdoor performances of Shakespeare’s plays. Our goal is to share our passion for Shakespeare and theatre with our community. Shakespeare is cool. The plays are beautiful and exciting, full of love, lust, sorrow, revenge, magic and joy. Performing these crazy-amazing works under the open sky only heightens the emotion and the sense of adventure shared by the actors and audiences during a performance.

We envision local residents, families, Shakespeare lovers, and Shakespeare newbies all to come out for a picnic and to enjoy a free performance in the fresh air of a Chicago summer. Creating and sharing this experience sounds like a wonderful way to spend our summer. If you agree, please support the production and come check out the show in August!

Please visit www.midsommerflight.com for performance details, rehearsal notes, and artist biographies.

story:
What is MKE Follies?

MKE Follies is an every-other-month variety-styled show.

Rhyme and Zakrzewski (co-founders of Dance Revolution Milwaukee) aim to encourage collaboration between the arts community of Milwaukee by presenting shows that involves dancers, musicians, actors, and more!  MKE Follies gives performance opportunities to local artists who are pining to share their work with you.

The next Follies is scheduled for Saturday, January 12th, 2013 at the Carte Blanche Studios in Milwaukee, WI.

We will be presenting the 4th edition of MKE Follies in March of 2013.  In order for Dance Revolution Milwaukee to continue providing wonderful performance opportunities to Milwaukee artists... WE NEED YOUR HELP! 

 

MKE Follies... You never know what you'll see next!

 

What We Need & What You Get...

MKE Follies needs your contributions! Your donation will be used in the following ways:

  • $225: rent Carte Blanche Studios for dress rehearsal and performance.
  • $150: promotional items: postcards, flyers, photography, ect.
  • $100/act: pay each of the variety acts for their hard work, artistry, and performance (6-8 acts).

 

What you'll get...

  • Take a look at our perks! We'd love to send you a shout-out, either online or at the show, for your contribution.
  • Your generous donation will allow Dance Revolution Milwaukee to continue to present MKE Follies.  By supporting this campaign, we can hire local Milwaukee artists to create and perform. And YOU'LL be able to have the opportunity to support that effort!
  • If you're in the MKE area, you can physically SEE how your donation is supporting the arts. Come to an MKE Follies show to see the artists you have supported.

 

The Impact

Your contribution to our campaign is going to a great cause! Growing the arts community in Milwaukee is a valuable effort... and your contribution helps artists share their work.

The previous MKE Follies show, which was hosted on November 3rd, 2012, was a huge success and a step in the right direction.  We can use your help to be able to keep the momentum going, continue providing performance opportunities to local MKE artists, and create quality shows.

We'd love to spread the word of MKE Follies and pay contribuiting artists more then we are able to now!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute to our campaign right now, you can still help!

  • Come to the MKE Follies show: Saturday, January 12th, 2013, 8pm @ Carte Blanche Studios in Milwaukee WI.
  • Join our MKE Follies facebook group & events.
  • Share our campaign with your friends.

story:
Big Update

Thanks to many generous contributions outside of this Indiegogo campaign, we are proud to announce that our new goal is only $75,000!

We are very,very close. Join us today!

"…a heart-wrenching, lean and graceful plunge into the deep end of truth."

– The Huffington Post

 

 

"I would have to say that they extend beyond dancers; they are flat out artists… They are disgustingly perfect and somehow both ethereal and absolutely raw."

– 303 Magazine

 

Our Journey

Over the course of five years, the artistic vision of Garrett Ammon and Dawn Fay has helped define Ballet Nouveau Colorado (BNC) as a creative leader in the state of Colorado and a force to be recognized in the world of dance.

By collaborating with artists across a spectrum of mediums, they have created transformative experiences that upend notions about how dance can be created and shared in the community.

To continue to move this vision forward and free it to blossom into its full potential, the structure surrounding this innovative work and the brand that captures its essence must be built anew.

The visionary dance company, Ballet Nouveau Colorado, is transforming into Wonderbound.

In the upcoming season, Wonderbound will lean into our collaborative capacities to produce world-class, locally minded art and help transform our new community into a lively, beautiful and sustainable place, with the arts at its core. The artists of Wonderbound will strive to provide innovative programming that fosters interaction among community members, arts organizations and artists.

Our new location will play a large role in the far-reaching impact of this new American dance company. By taking advantage of the building’s original design and unassuming personality, we can literally “throw open our doors” and engage the surrounding community. Wonderbound will use our new home as a gathering place and nerve center to animate the area with ongoing creative energy.

Our New Home 

To complete our transition, Wonderbound needs a new home in Denver...

A home where the organization can grow, thrive and inspire audiences globally, while mobilizing and invigorating our local community.

You play an integral role in propelling this train of energy, hope and wonder forward as every dollar contributed will go towards the Wonderbound transformation!

Wonderbound has already garnered significant support from the Denver community. Leading the charge is the highly prestigious arts advocate Bonfils-Stanton Foundation, who has awarded the company a generous multi-year financial commitment, as well as the David and Laura Merage Foundation and the Kenney Brothers Foundation.

At present we're over half way there – in terms of funding – to make the transition. Wonderbound thanks all of our incredible supporters for gettting us to this point, and would also like to ask for your help in funding the move into our new home! 

Our Immense Gratitude

To show our deep appreciation for your support in this artistic adventure, we’ve curated twelve unique tokens of thanks created exclusively for Wonderbound patrons. And, as Wonderbound (aka BNC) is a 501c3 nonprofit organization, a large percentage of your donation is tax deductible.

Your perks aren’t limited to tangible gifts! Each donation is a gift that means the world, and we’ve created a brilliant Benefactor Board that gives Wonderbound investors the public praise and kudos they deserve! Simply donate $10 or more and you will receive a thank you email from us with instructions on where to email your picture and preferred name spelling. Or, come to a show and have your close-up taken on the spot! We’ll post your smiling face on the Board and showcase it for the world to see in the lobby during performances and in Wonderbound's new downtown home.

The bottom line is - We want you to feel special, because you are!

Check out big pictures of the perks below in our Indiegogo Gallery.

Check out big pictures of the perks above in our Indiegogo Gallery.

Your Support is Building Our Future: 

•  Dance Studio: Sprung floor, marley, barres, mirrors, sound system.

•  Heat (kinda important!) and Cooling.

•  Office: Staffing, computers, desks, printers, phones, internet, filing cabinets.

•  Kitchen: Fridge, microwave, dishes, sink, washer, dryer, the ever-essential coffee pot.

•  Dressing Rooms: lockers, benches, carpet (to keep those feet toasty!)

We Cannot Do This Without You

By the close of the decade, Wonderbound will be celebrated as a treasure in the international dance community and will be a crown jewel in Denver’s artistic landscape. We will define Denver as a cultural capitol in the world. You make this possible!

Help Spread the Word

Money isn’t the only thing that makes dance thrive, and there are plenty of ways to help our momentum bound!

•  Help make this campaign viral using the Indiegogo share tools! Our art is by no means limited to our zip code, and Wonderbound was formed with the intent of sharing contemporary dance with the world.

•  If you know someone who would be thrilled to support our vision, please send them this link, put them in touch with us or invite them to a performance.

•  Keep sharing the wonder… 

From all of us here at Wonderbound, we humbly thank you for your support. Welcome to our family!

won•der•bound |ˈwəndərˌbound|

definitions | noun

a leaping movement into an unfathomable sensation.

verb

a dance of remarkable beauty and delight.

adjective

1 heading toward something beautiful, unexpected, unfamiliar, or inexplicable.

• destined to have a beautiful, unexpected, unfamiliar, or inexplicable experience.

2 (of a person) enveloped in a feeling of awed delight or astonishment.

3 on a journey instigated by a desire or curiosity to know.

4 strongly attached to (a person or place), through a feeling of admiration and amazement.

story:
Enjoy a Sampling of Fantasy Weavers’ Fare!

Eve Edwards performs an aria from “Sephro: the Vengeance”

(Words and music by Kate Quinn © 2012)

Philadelphia’s 2012 “Fringe Festival” provided the backdrop for the opera’s much anticipated premiere. Sephro: the Vengeance is one of the most innovative and thought-provoking operas of its time.  In concert with the science fiction/fantasy genre, the story centers on the alliance between righteous witches from Earth and the magical inhabitants of planet Sephro.  They join forces to battle a terrible “evil” that finds it roots in the violation of a young maiden. “The Vengeance” and its predecessor, “Sephro” both center on powerful adult themes that illustrate the deleterious effects of abuse while underscoring the healing power of faith, trust, inner strength and wisdom.

 Lyrics (c) 2012, by Kate Quinn:

Lean on me, Darling, and look in my eyes,
You don't have to suffer in this world of lies.
I'm one with you and I'll help you to stand on your own!

I want to give you what no one else dared,
Reason to love you, though they never cared
You are just one of the many who's fled from their home.

But Truth Says, "I love you,
I'll never leave you”!
Mountains may crumble and oceans may rise!
Winds may run rampant and stir up the fires!
Castles may come crumbling down,
Worlds may collide but there's love by your side,
I am here!"

As a child, the composer/author of Sephro and Sephro: the Vengeance personally experienced the victimization brought to light by this bold and groundbreaking foret into the previously unexplored realm of reality-based fantasy.  The major impetus and inspiration for bringing these works into the public consciousness was to fulfill the composer’s desire to right the wrongs of her youth and to conciliate past conflict with present understanding.

For more information on Sephro, visit www.fantasyweavers.org

To learn about the novels "Sephro," and "Sephro: The Vengeance," volumes 1 and 2 in "The Sephro Chronicles", please visit www.fantasyweavers.org/Gifts.html.


What We Need and What can Benefit You by Helping Us

To continue producing the innovative opera and children’s works that have made Fantasy Weavers one of the most “talked about” theater companies in the region, we need your heartfelt participation and support. 

Our next children’s production (“Cat Land”) is scheduled for completion in early 2013.  This will not be possible without your help.  Catland is an important allegory about sharing and loving one’s neighbor. It teaches children to care about their fellow human and to share what they have with others who are less fortunate. It is a tale about a land where cats reign supreme and where they are magically blessed with the nine lives that have inspired human wonder and awe for centuries.  Catland is the place that cats go when they dream.  Children will be entranced with the color and beauty of Catland and will learn the essential life lesson that it is far better to compromise than to dominate.

The author created Catland to bring to fore her painful childhood experience with bullying, deprivation and sibling rivalry.  The story leads the audience down the same path that the author took in her desire for vindication and the resolution of early trauma.

Fantasy Weavers is registered by the state of Pennsylvania as an official “not for profit” organization.  All donations are tax deductable.  With your gift, you will be supporting the continued exploration of the unexamined, original themes and stories that define the Fantasy Weavers experience…themes and stories that will expand the minds of Philadelphia audiences and will teach our children about kindness and the true value of the golden rule.

The Impact of Fantasy Weavers on Society as a Whole

Fantasy Weavers was created to expose “at risk” and disadvantaged youth and adults to the enchantment and beauty of the performing arts by offering free or low-cost access to original opera and children’s musical productions…productions with a message. Our shows enrich the lives of these vulnerable members of our community by providing joyous, enlightening entertainment that instructs as well as entertains. In addition to the color and magic that is Fantasy Weavers, our shows provide children with invaluable “life lessons” that support development of the “moral compass” that is required to navigate life’s winding road.

“Becky Butterfly and the Story of the Wayward Wasp” is a musical about healing the wounds that “bullying” can inflict.  The show introduces a male worker wasp named “Kevin” who suffers under the abuse of his peers because of his differences.  The story line demonstrates that differences can be wondrous things.  As the show concludes, the audience learns that diversity must be embraced if there is a desire to evolve and grow as members of a community.  The other wasps learn that they must appreciate the talents and abilities that make us all special no matter how those talents and abilities are packaged. As mentioned above, the message contained in our new children’s musical “Catland” serves as a metaphor for the true meaning of compromise.  Children learn that giving is far better than having and that sharing is at the root of all human experience.

Unique to the Fantasy Weavers’ mission and purpose are adult-themed productions that expose the audience to controversial topics not traditionally explored by live musical performance. By experiencing these topics in the context of musical entertainment, audiences are encouraged to submerge themselves into the sometimes murky reality of the human condition and are provided the opportunity to confront today’s issues with new understanding and deeper insight.

 Other Ways You Can Help…

SPREAD THE WORD!!!

Tell everyone you know about Fantasy Weavers’ mission to share the beauty and excitement of live theater and opera! Encourage them to give abundantly!  We exist only because of your generosity and the generosity of our loyal contributors but we cannot make it without the support of community.  As a famous lady once said, “it takes a village!”

SPECIAL OFFERS!

Also, please check out the perks offered on the right of this page.  For just a small donation, you will be provided the wondrous opportunity to journey through space and time to be swallowed up into an alternate reality…a reality where aliens and witches travel the void to save their world and to embrace the journey of their souls.

GET INVOLVED!

If you would like to volunteer your time by working with the stage crew or in another capacity to help us bring Fantasy Weavers’ next show to fruition, please contact Kate Quinn at 610.389.9572.  We truly appreciate your participation and desire to support Fantasy Weavers and its mission.

 

Kate Quinn
Artistic Director/President
Fantasy Weavers
www.fantasyweavers.org
610-389-9572
story_txt:
Enjoy a Sampling of Fantasy Weavers’ Fare!
Eve Edwards performs an aria from “Sephro: the Vengeance” 
(Words and music by Kate Quinn © 2012)
Philadelphia’s 2012 “Fringe Festival” provided the backdrop for the opera’s much anticipated premiere. Sephro: the Vengeance is one of the most innovative and thought-provoking operas of its time.  In concert with the science fiction/fantasy genre, the story centers on the alliance between righteous witches from Earth and the magical inhabitants of planet Sephro.  They join forces to battle a terrible “evil” that finds it roots in the violation of a young maiden. “The Vengeance” and its predecessor, “Sephro” both center on powerful adult themes that illustrate the deleterious effects of abuse while underscoring the healing power of faith, trust, inner strength and wisdom.
 Lyrics (c) 2012, by Kate Quinn:
Lean on me, Darling, and look in my eyes, You don't have to suffer in this world of lies. I'm one with you and I'll help you to stand on your own! I want to give you what no one else dared,  Reason to love you, though they never cared You are just one of the many who's fled from their home. But Truth Says, "I love you,  I'll never leave you”! Mountains may crumble and oceans may rise! Winds may run rampant and stir up the fires! Castles may come crumbling down, Worlds may collide but there's love by your side, I am here!"
As a child, the composer/author of Sephro and Sephro: the Vengeance personally experienced the victimization brought to light by this bold and groundbreaking foret into the previously unexplored realm of reality-based fantasy.  The major impetus and inspiration for bringing these works into the public consciousness was to fulfill the composer’s desire to right the wrongs of her youth and to conciliate past conflict with present understanding.
For more information on Sephro, visit www.fantasyweavers.org
To learn about the novels "Sephro," and "Sephro: The Vengeance," volumes 1 and 2 in "The Sephro Chronicles", please visit www.fantasyweavers.org/Gifts.html.What We Need and What can Benefit You by Helping Us
To continue producing the innovative opera and children’s works that have made Fantasy Weavers one of the most “talked about” theater companies in the region, we need your heartfelt participation and support. 
Our next children’s production (“Cat Land”) is scheduled for completion in early 2013.  This will not be possible without your help.  Catland is an important allegory about sharing and loving one’s neighbor. It teaches children to care about their fellow human and to share what they have with others who are less fortunate. It is a tale about a land where cats reign supreme and where they are magically blessed with the nine lives that have inspired human wonder and awe for centuries.  Catland is the place that cats go when they dream.  Children will be entranced with the color and beauty of Catland and will learn the essential life lesson that it is far better to compromise than to dominate.
The author created Catland to bring to fore her painful childhood experience with bullying, deprivation and sibling rivalry.  The story leads the audience down the same path that the author took in her desire for vindication and the resolution of early trauma.
Fantasy Weavers is registered by the state of Pennsylvania as an official “not for profit” organization.  All donations are tax deductable.  With your gift, you will be supporting the continued exploration of the unexamined, original themes and stories that define the Fantasy Weavers experience…themes and stories that will expand the minds of Philadelphia audiences and will teach our children about kindness and the true value of the golden rule.

As mentioned above, the message contained in our new children’s musical “Catland” serves as a metaphor for the true meaning of compromise.  Children learn that giving is far better than having and that sharing is at the root of all human experience.

story:
Our Story

In 2011, two playwrights-- Gahl Pratt Pardes and Emily Talia Sztabzyb-- listened to the stories of women from Calgary, Canada who had survived violence in their relationships with husbands, boyfriends, children, grandchildren, and caretakers. Their stories inspired a play that is at once gritty in its capturing of the frightening reality of abuse (a reality faced by 1 in 3 women in North America), and surreal and captivating as it explores the complex inner lives of the women who leave, and the women who stay. 

Gahl and Emily are producing a professional, Equity staged reading of this play, scheduled for 7:00pm on June 4, 2012 at the Cardel Theatre in Calgary. Ticket sales will go directly to fund Na'amat, which is an organization that aids and empowers women and children. Many of Calgary's most celebrated actors have already participated in development workshops for this play, and have pledged interest in participating in a production. We are trying to raise the funds to pay the actors, a director, a stage manager, a musical composer, and a low-tech designer to produce a polished, well-staged reading for this play.

 

The Impact

It is our hope that by staging a captivating production of this play, and subsequently giving further life to this project in Calgary and beyond, these difficult and beautiful stories can be told, and that the vital conversation around this issue is ignited. Additionally, along with 100% of the ticket sales, a large portion of the money we are raising will go directly to Na'amat, which runs projects and programs that empower women and children internationally.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $7,000 to adequately pay the actors, director, stage manager, and honourariums for other artists involved. This sum would allow us to produce a show with a week's rehearsal and fairly polished production values.

We need about $1,000 for materials (simple furniture set pieces, lighting and sound equipment).

We are trying to raise an additional $2,000 to go directly to Na'amat, along with 100% of the ticket sales, sponsorships, and program ad sales.

This is a fundraising challenge, and in the event that we do not raise all of the above-mentioned funds, we would be able to produce a bare-bones production, or unstaged reading. We believe the impact of the piece would be much greater, and the message much more accessible to a wider audience if the production were to be well-polished. That's where you come in!

By donating to this endeavour, you help spread the message that domestic violence is a social issue that affects us all, and you help spark interest in the community, while providing vital funds to an organization that helps victims.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether or not you are able to donate "green energy" to this campaign, spreading the word is another awesome way you can help! Share this link with your e-mail, Facebook, or blog contacts, and see if you can show 5 people this page. Thank you so much!

story:
The Wonderettes Are Graduating!

Our favorite song leaders are back and they need your help! Roger Bean has created a new musical, The Marvelous Wonderettes: Caps & Gowns, and we want to create an original cast album featuring the four gorgeous voices from the World Premiere at the Laguna Playhouse. 

We need our fans' support to produce a smash recording and get it out to the world. Our team will receive perks that range from advance downloads of the album to show tickets and one eager Chipmunk will even receive a copy of Roger Bean's personal show script, complete with scribbles and director's notes!

Graduation Requirements

Our budget for the project is $25,000. All money raised will go toward paying our talented singers, musicians, and studio engineer, as well as studio rental, music royalties, and production costs. 

To thank you for your support we are offering one-of-a-kind treats, like a limited edition Wonderettes: Caps & Gowns t-shirt designed especially for this campaign, VIP show tickets and dinner with creator Roger Bean.

If we fall short of our goal the project will still go forward, but the original cast recording will have to be released on 8-track and we may have to bring in Principal Varney to sing Missy's part.

Worldwide Wonderettes

The Marvelous Wonderettes are famous for bringing the music we love to theaters all over the world. By helping us produce this album and get it into the hands of our thousands of fans you will be making the world more marvelous!

Spread the Word

We hope that you'll make a contribution, but even if you can't, please share our campaign with your friends and tell everyone that the Wonderettes are back and they are looking for boosters. Go Chipmunks!

The Hits

These are the songs you'll get...

The Music of The Marvelous Wonderettes: Caps & Gowns

"At The Hop"

"Baby, I Love You"

"A Brand New Me"

"Dancin’ In The Street"

"Dedicated To The One I Love"

"Ding Dong"

"Don't Mess With Bill"

"Good Lovin’"

"Graduation Day"

"Hold On I'm Coming"

"Hooked On A Feeling"

"It's Gonna Take A Miracle"

"It's Only Make Believe"

"Just One Look"

"The Look Of Love"

"May You Always"

"My Boy, Flat Top"

"Mr. Touchdown"

"Oh Boy!"

"(You've Got) Personality"

"River Deep, Mounatin High"

"Rock and Roll Waltz"

"Rock Around The Clock"

"Rockin' Robin"

"Sealed With A Kiss"

"Springfield High Alma Mater"

"Teacher, Teacher"

"V-A-C-A-T-I-O-N"

"Wishin' And Hopin'"

"When You Walk In The Room"

"(What A) Wonderful World"

"You Gotta Be A Football Hero"

"You Keep Me Hangin' On"

story:
The Campaign

We are MarianaMalena, a female-led theatre company based in London. Since 2016, we’ve been creating work through interdisciplinary and horizontal collaboration. We aim to give voice to Latin American stories that have yet to inspire London audiences.  

This campaign will help us fund The Two of Us, a theatre piece in which Mariana retraces a series of major events in her grandmother Blanca's life. She is trying to understand how her female ancestors' experiences of love, frailty, joy, and pain have shaped her own experience and left a mark on her identity as a Latin American woman.

With The Two of Us, we want to create a landscape of Latin American families and traditions using music, languages, and movement.

The funds obtained through this campaign will help us, as a company, take this show to the next level and turn what is now a work-in-progress into a full-length production. 

After a very successful work in progress at the Actors Centre, we have been programmed by Theatre Deli to share a full version of The Two of Us, in March 2020.

This show has been an opportunity for us to grow, not only creatively, but also professionally. We are now working with a group of collaborators, on a bigger scale, with larger audiences, and more ambitious aesthetics. 

Having the funds to approach this project financially will allow us to produce a higher-quality, more entertaining product, which is truer to the way in which we understand Blanca’s life, as well as our own. 

The Performance

The Two of Us will be performing at Theatre Deli (Broadgate) from 10-13 March 2020 at 7:30pm.

The Venue: Theatre Deli (Broadgate), 2 Finsbury Ave, London EC2M 2PF

The Costs

Our biggest expense will be the wages for our collaborators, which will be covered by another grant.  To take The Two of Us to the next level creatively, we are aiming to raise £4,500 through this campaign to cover remaining costs in two key areas:

- Rehearsal Space. We need a studio that allows us to explore Blanca’s story, and make The Two of Us into a full-length show.
- Set and Design. We are working towards improving the aesthetics of the play, and therefore the quality of the audiences’ experience.

The Team

Mariana Aristizabal Pardo

Mariana is a Colombian performer, director, clown, and facilitator. She trained as an actor at the Universidad Distrital Francisco José de Caldas, in Bogotá, and at the Royal Central School of Speech and Drama, London. She is currently developing the Organic Rhythm training approach, exploring the intersection between organic movement and music. Mariana works extensively as a theatre facilitator for young children, in London. Her Acting credits include Variette Libertad (Colombia) and Cansancio Tears (Brink Festival, Performance Philosophy Biennale), Last Rehearsal (Brighton Fringe Festival) amongst others. Directing and assisting directing credits include Thebes Land at The Arcola Theatre, I Occur Here,  CASA Festival at The Southwark Playhouse, sanguine Night, at Rada Festival, Loose lips, from The Big House.

Malena Arcucci

Malena is an Argentinean theatre designer and costume maker. Malena holds a Bachelor’s degree in Visual Arts and Sculpture from the University of Argentine Museum, and a certificate from the Argentinean National Opera. Malena graduated from the University of the Underground and the Sandberg Instituut. Malena has been selected as one of the 20 Best Design Graduates in the world, by Design Indaba. She has exhibited internationally and has given lectures in venues like the Palais de Glace in Buenos Aires, The Space in London, and the Performance Philosophy Biennale in Amsterdam.  Malena uses devised and physical theatre techniques, in combination with her background and interest in costume making and sculpture to explore new forms of storytelling. She has worked extensively as a theatre-maker and costume designer for companies in Buenos Aires and London. Some of the venues include Teatro del Pueblo in Buenos Aires, and Southwark Playhouse, Bush Theatre, Oval Space and the Arcola in London. 

Katie Melton

Katie is a creative producer and project manager from the U.S. Based in London, she is a multidisciplinary artist who has worked in theatre for over 14 years in both the U.S. (the award-winning Trinity Shakespeare Festival, Circle Theatre, & Casa Mañana) and in London (BRINK Festival & CoLab Theatre).  Beyond producing, she has worked as a director, designer, performer, stage manager, technician, researcher, and administrator. She received her MFA in Performance Practice as Research at the Royal Central School of Speech and Drama and her BFA with an Emphasis in Theatre Studies from Texas Christian University. Additionally, she runs her own professional development business for early-career, offstage artists, writes for Backstage UK’s online magazine, and is a member of the Young Vic Directors Programme.

The Collaborators

(Left to Right: Santiago Peluffo, Writer; Bryan Munoz, Musician/Deviser; Andrea Spisto, Dramaturg; Christian From, Movement Director)

 

The Ways You Can Help

We understand that donating is not always a possibility, and we really appreciate that you scrolled this far!

There are other ways to help us get this show on it's feet:

- Share this campaign with your friends/family and on social media. By doing so, you are helping us achieve our goals 

- Spread the word about the 'The Two of Us' 

 

THANK YOU!

story:
About Lineage Dance Company

Lineage Dance is a contemporary dance company dedicated to raising support and awareness for nonprofit organizations, as well as to making the arts accessible to audiences of all demographic and socioeconomic backgrounds. 

The purpose of Lineage Dance is:

  • To produce and present works of dance by resident and guest artists for the benefit of others.
  • To provide educational workshops, residencies, assemblies, master classes and dance festivals for the benefit of students, teachers, dancers and community members.

Lineage Dance is known throughout our community for artistic excellence as well as giving back through dance. We strive to build community through the arts – reaching across barriers of age, ethnicity and ability. One of the most important components of our mission is to make the art of dance accessible to every age and stage of life. We want to develop audiences that feel fully engaged in dance by offering opportunities to deepen understanding through education and participation.

 

About the Pasadena Dance Festival

The Pasadena Dance Festival is an award winning, week-long dance festival that highlights the greater Pasadena/Los Angeles dance community, featuring top teachers and inspiring performers. Scheduled for April 21-27, 2013 at Lineage Performing Arts Center (LPAC) and the Pasadena Civic Auditorium, the event will once again feature an array of dance classes, workshops, seminars and performances. We launch our 6th Annual Pasadena Dance Festival on Sunday, April 21st, with the Festival Kick-Off Concert. On Thursday and Friday, April 25th and 26th, LAPC will host two different evening programs of Emerging Choreographers Showcases. The culminating day of the Pasadena Dance Festival will be Saturday, April 27th at the Pasadena Civic Auditorium. This day will feature 40+ different dance classes throughout the day for all ages and abilities. This will include free sample classes of our outreach programs; Club 21: Dancing with Down Syndrome, Dancing with Parkinson’s and Dancing Through Cancer. At 2:00pm, invited student groups from area high schools and colleges will perform on the Civic Auditorium stage. At 8:00pm, the Professional Evening Concert, featuring Lineage Dance Company and special performances from Lil’ C of  So You Think You Can Dance and “Queen of Krump” Miss Prissy will cap off the 6th annual event!

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $3,250 to provide 50 full scholarships to our 6th Annual Pasadena Dance Festival for students age 12-18 who wouldn’t otherwise be able to attend due to financial circumstances. Scholarships will be distributed in partnership with Pasadena Unified School District, Pasadena Education Network, local dance studios and community organizations. Students can apply for scholarships by visiting our website at http://www.lineagedance.org/festival/. With any additional funds raised we will award up to 75 full scholarships. Any funds raised beyond that will be contributed to our Community Ticket Program to provide free and discounted tickets for the Pasadena Dance Festival Concert. For your contribution, you will get a personal thank you letter and the giving level gifts you see listed to the right. 

What’s the Impact?

Even though “Dancing with the Stars” and "So You Think You Can Dance" has brought dance into many homes, the cost of dance instruction and dance attendance is still far out of reach for many. Your contribution will support students between the ages of 12 – 18 who wouldn’t otherwise be able to attend the Pasadena Dance Festival due to financial circumstances. Students will have the opportunity to experience a wide variety of dance classes from Ballet to African to Bollywood and more. They will also attend various performances from professional dance companies, student groups and emerging choreographers. 

Every year, Lineage Dance aggressively pursues opportunities to make the festival as accessible as possible, and for the past four years, Lineage has offered tickets and scholarships at no cost to the community.  The opportunity to experience dance live dance can be a life-changing experience. We have seen the transformative power of this event.  From a few previous scholarship students:

I probably would not have been able to go without the scholarship.  The scholarship allowed me to have an amazing day of dance.  It was one of the most fun dance experiences I have ever had.  It opened my eyes to new kinds of dance, and that ballet is not the only one I enjoy.  I never would have thought of taking a Bollywood class or a modern partnering class, and they turned out to be my favorites.  Thank you!  – Jackson Bradshaw

Hi my name is Edgar Ramos and I enjoyed going to the Pasadena Dance Festival.   It was great and I enjoyed all the dances that I got to see and the ones to try.   I met some really cool people, but what it meant to me, going through a scholarship…well it was ok, I just wish I could have paid for it myself. I’ve also learned that there are all sorts of unique styles of dance & expressions that go as they flow through the body & mind.   They paint a picture in my mind & a story that goes with every dance and emotion.  Overall, it was fantastic to have seen all of that and well thank you for everything and for also making a great event thank you all.  – Edgar Ramos

 

Beyond the Festival, students will have opportunities to continue their affiliation with Lineage, seeing performances and attending classes on scholarship throughout the year.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute? That doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Help us spread the word by using the Indiegogo share tools. Update your status, Tweet your followers and email all your friends. The more this goes viral, the more money we can raise.

 

Want to do more?

  • Volunteer for the Pasadena Dance Festival. Please email Elisha.lineage@gmail.com for additional information on volunteering.
  • Buy a ticket to one of our performances. Tickets can be purchased at http://www.lineagedance.org/festival/sales/
story_txt:
About Lineage Dance Company
Lineage Dance is a contemporary dance company dedicated to raising support and awareness for nonprofit organizations, as well as to making the arts accessible to audiences of all demographic and socioeconomic backgrounds. 
The purpose of Lineage Dance is:

To produce and present works of dance by resident and guest artists for the benefit of others.
To provide educational workshops, residencies, assemblies, master classes and dance festivals for the benefit of students, teachers, dancers and community members.
Lineage Dance is known throughout our community for artistic excellence as well as giving back through dance. We strive to build community through the arts – reaching across barriers of age, ethnicity and ability. One of the most important components of our mission is to make the art of dance accessible to every age and stage of life. We want to develop audiences that feel fully engaged in dance by offering opportunities to deepen understanding through education and participation.
 
About the Pasadena Dance Festival
The Pasadena Dance Festival is an award winning, week-long dance festival that highlights the greater Pasadena/Los Angeles dance community, featuring top teachers and inspiring performers. story:
I'm Justin McLachlan, and I'm the creator of Sight. It's based on a short story I wrote for an anthology by an indie scifi and fantasy publisher I cofounded in DC. The story is called 'Superhero' and it's about a guy who becomes a street-prowling, crime fighting vigilante. Why? Well, he knows when he's going to die—he has a second sight—which means he also knows when he's not going to die. Sight picks up where the short story left off.

In 2012, I received a small grant from the city of DC to write Sight, eight 15-minute episodes in all, and present them as a stage reading with DC actors. We're just wrapping that up as we launch this campaign because, we hope, with your help, we'll actually get to produce the full first season.

WHAT WE NEED

These are our preliminary budget estimates.

  • The cast is our largest expense, a full 20 percent of our budget. We're not derferring any of their fees. The Camera is the next bigggest expense, either renting or buying (we've priced both options—we could rent a higher end camera or buy a lower end model for slightly less) and includes the cost of lenses and other required accessories (a screen, mounting bars, etc.)
  • While shooting digital means we don't need to buy film or pay for processing, we do need a place to store all our footage. Shooting at film resolution means we're talking totals in the double-digit Terabyte range to store all of Sight's footage through post-production.
  • Legal costs include script and title reports that some of our insurance carries will require. We have to make sure we have licenses in place for any third-party content that might end up in the show.

Even if we reach our goal, the budget is going to be tight. And what if we don't reach our goal? We'll produce as many episodes of the first season as we can, even if that's just the pilot. 

Some of the cast rehearsing for the stage reading, an event funded in part by the DC Commission on the Arts & Humanities. 

YOUR IMPACT

Sight began because of the contribution of the DC Commission on the Arts & Humanities to fund the writing and stage reading. Part of the grant was to have a local impact: it was an opportunity to work with DC actors and crew, and we're excited to keep doing that. Your contribution will have a HUGE impact on the cast and crew, ensuring that they're paid for their work.

We're still casting and attaching key production personel, but here's how things are shaping up:

Producers: Scott Sparks, Lena Winter, Craig Alan

Editor: Arnulfo Moreno

Cast: Justin McLachlan, Christine Alexander, Joe Feldman, Chris Stinson, Tegan Cohen, Chris Haley, Alison Daniels

Many of us got a chance to work together in DC's 48 Hour Film Project earlier this year. We were given specific requirements (a genre, dialogue, a prop) and 48 hours to produce a film. The result, a seven-minute suspense story called "The Closet"—that's a behind-the-scenes shot above—was chosen as one of the best of DC this year.

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP

Contribute. Just pick a contribution level on the right. If you have any questions about any of the rewards or the show, just get in touch and we'll answer you right away.

Other ways to help

  • We know it's not always possible to contribute financially. But you can still help, just by shareing the campaign with your friends and family! (There are buttons below the video at the top to help you do this).
  • Have a web site? You can also embed the campaign to share it with your readers.
  • Like our Facebook page and ask your friends to like it to: http://facebook.com/sightwebseries. Our like goal is 5,000 by the time series premieres next year.

Like our Facebook page and ask your friends to like it to: http://facebook.com/sightwebseries. Our like goal is 5,000 by the time series premieres next year.

story:
The Show...

 'Little Drops of Poison' is a dance-based theater piece, set in the dark world of Tom Waits. The show follows Bud - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JD27y8Q3AhE  as he stumbles his way through Waits' world of dancers, looking for his lost love. 

The show will feature some of Boston's finest dancers, as well as actor/musicians from around the country.  

 

How it started...

The idea for the show came about in September 2012. It started from my discovering blues dancing and exploring Tom Waits’ music at around the same time. To me, if Waits’ voice could dance, I believe it would do so like these dancers, in this style. A subtle, slow-dragging jook joint dance, with deep American roots, and full of improvised feel.. Once I saw it, I was desperately curious to see what these dancers would do if put in Waits’ world.

This idea also came during early autumn in New England, where I live. I remember Waits’ once describing a lot of his music as ‘Halloween music’. We saw the show thriving in that setting, so we chose Waits’ songs of that nature and tone, – some of his darker, scarier, yet fun and theatrical material. Feeling it’s potential as a theater piece, and a story growing, this evolved into the inclusion of Chad Hauge (Chicago based actor) and his clown character ‘Bud’.

6 months later, the show has grow into this wonderfully strange mix of theater, dance, music, clowning and story.

 

Where it's going...

The show has grown in strange and wonderful ways. We are very excited to debute this idea and share the experience with you! Though this first inception of the show is happening on March 30th, we hope this will just be the beginning. The shows intended setting is Halloween, particularly in New England. Come fall, we will be restaging the show in a range of different spaces and venues, specific to this show and the time of year. We hope to let the show thrive and be enjoyed by those who won't get a chance to see it the first time around.

 

How your support will help...

Your generosity and financial support will be going directly to three things: The artists, the space and Tom Waits himself

THE ARTISTS: The talent we've been lucky enough to bring together for this show is staggering. renowned dancers, actors, musicians, designers, and the list goes ever on. Their skills are worth paying for. 

THE SPACE: We're very excited to be putting on this show at the Julie Ince Thompson Theatre in Cambridge, MA. Not only is the theater ideal for dancers, but it's age and feel give it a wonderful character; perfect for a show exploring the world of Waits.

TOM WAITS: We were again very lucky to be given grand rights approval from Mr. Waits and his record label, to use his material exclusively. This is a rare occurance that an artist will grant this type of permission and we are honored to be able to create and riff off of his genius work. A percentage of the donations and box office will go to him and his co-writer, Kathleen Brennan.

 

-- You can also support us by simply spreading the word and coming to the show!

You can purchase advanced tickets here - http://littledrops.brownpapertickets.com/

 

Thank you for your interest and support of this project. We hope very much to see you at the show!

-Jesse Armerding and the 'LDOP' team.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Terry Hatfield. I have been working as a Butoh artist for 24 years. I founded the Butoh Co-Op Thailand in 2005. I have produced 8 International Butoh Festivals in Bangkok, Thailand with the help of B-Floor Theatre, Crescent Moon Theatre, and Democrazy Studio. I am currently seeking support to produce, BUTOH FEVER: THE 9th INTERNATIONAL BUTOH FESTIVAL THAILAND 2014. I have invested my life savings on producing this annual event. Since 2005, the Festival has grown beyond my means; therefore, I am seeking other means of funding this project which is very close to me. Plus with the current coup d’état in Thailand, it makes it difficult to get local support. Most of our support comes from tourists. This year’s Festival is sponsored in part by the Bangkok Arts and Culture Centre (BACC) as part of their Performative Art Festival #3.  BACC has given us space to work, perform, and exhibit. Your contribution would help to pay for technician fees, equipment rentals, partial artist fees, and accommodation fees for international artists.

What We Need & What You Get

We need a total of $3,940 to meet our budget items. $1,500 covers technician fees and equipment rentals. $1,240 covers accommodation fees for international artists, $800 covers partial artist fees, and $400 covers catering cost during the rehearsal process.

Anyone who supports will receive their name in the program under different levels of support (see perks for descriptions). Contributors will receive their name in the program and performance tickets,  Sponsors will receive  VIP passes to all events and their logo will appear in all publicity, media, and promotion materials connected with the festival and are permitted a booth at all events to promote their product.

All funds raised will go directly to the festival. If we do not make our goal, the festival will continue. Your help and support guarantees expenses will be met.

The Impact

Past Festivals have included artists from Japan, Thailand, Viet Nam, China, Sweden, United States, Columbia, Canada, Hungary, Finland, Greece, Spain, France, Australia, Israel, Netherlands, Latvia, Korea, Hong Kong, Malaysia, Mexico, Brazil, and Italy. The objectives of the project are to:  1) Educate the public about the Butoh art form in an international format. 2) Showcase works by Thai, Japanese, and International artists. 3) Create an international Butoh community and network of artists. 4) Encourage a cultural exchange relating to Butoh and Butoh influenced work. BUTOH FEVER: THE 9th INTERNATIONAL BUTOH FESTIVAL THAILAND 2014 will provide Butoh dance workshops, Butoh performances, and photo exhibition with installation hosted by B-Floor Theatre and Butoh Co-Op Thailand. B-Floor Theatre and Butoh Co-Op Thailand will host up to six international Butoh artists to collaborate with Thai artists.

BUTOH FEVER: THE 9th INTERNATIONAL BUTOH FESTIVAL THAILAND 2014 will take place in the capital of Thailand, Bangkok, December 4-21, 2014. The featured artists for this year’s event are Takita Takayuki (Japan),  B-Floor Theatre (Thailand), Salome Nieto (Mexico / Canada) of pataSola Dance supported in part by the British Columbia Arts Council, Butoh Co-Op Thailand, Valeria Geremia (Italy) of Sicula Butoh, Valentin Tszin of PoemaTheatre (Russia),  and Paul Ibey (Canada) featuring Butoh performances and workshops. Exhibition and installation by Boaz Zippor (Israel), Tawit Keitprapai (Thailand), and Stephen Funke (Finland). Also featuring a Butoh symposium, Film Screening: “Rite of Passage” by Juliette Yu-Ming (France/Malaysia) and Solstice Butoh Jam featuring all artists with guest musicians.

Why Butoh Fever, you may ask. There is a saying in Japanese, "If you sit on a rock long enough it will get hot." This is the 9th festival and it is steadily getting hotter. Also, in Japanese culture the word for the number 9 is similar to the sound for the word that  means "pain" or "distress". Butoh artist and Thailand's Butoh pioneer, Katsura Kan has often likened Butoh as an illness that once infected, people's lives change. In other Asian cultures, the number 9 symbolizes completion of the three realms of existence; Mind, Body, and Spirit. Butoh is currently being practiced as a healing therapy as well. Butoh Fever may be your cure or your disease.

Your contribution helps Thai artists get exposure from outside of Thailand. Many Thai artists have gone on to work internationally in the USA, Korea, Japan, Denmark, UK, Germany, and Italy as of a result of connections they made during the Festival. Any support you can offer is a blessing for future events.

Risks & Challenges

50% of our audience are tourists that just happen upon the exhibition and come back to view the performances. 25% of our audiences are expats living in Thailand and the other 25% of our audience are Thai artists working in the performing arts. Currently Thailand is under a coup d’état and will not have a new government in place until September 2015. Therefore, embassies have been discouraging people from taking their vacations in Thailand. If tourism is down we would potentially lose half of our audience which helps us to cover our expenses. Therefore, I am asking for your help and support. Also, we are applying for a grant from the Japan Foundation in Bangkok and seeking local sponsors. B-Floor Theatre and Ray of Light Productions are main contributors with some in kind donations from Democrazy Studio. BACC offers us the space to work and gives the festival a high profile in the international community to attract audiences.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you cannot contribute at this time, please spread the word by using the indieggo share tools. Plus like or comment on our indiegogo and facebook page. You can also donate frequent flyer miles to support artist’s airfare by contacting me at bkkbutoh@yahoo.com.

    Many Thanks and Blessings for your support in keeping this Festival alive!
