B-Floor Theatre and Butoh Co-Op Thailand will host up to six international Butoh artists to collaborate with Thai artists.
BUTOH FEVER: THE 9th INTERNATIONAL BUTOH FESTIVAL THAILAND 2014 will take place in the capital of Thailand, Bangkok, December 4-21, 2014. The featured artists for this year’s event are Takita Takayuki (Japan),  B-Floor Theatre (Thailand), Salome Nieto (Mexico / Canada) of pataSola Dance supported in part by the British Columbia Arts Council, Butoh Co-Op Thailand, Valeria Geremia (Italy) of Sicula Butoh, Valentin Tszin of PoemaTheatre (Russia),  and Paul Ibey (Canada) featuring Butoh performances and workshops. Exhibition and installation by Boaz Zippor (Israel), Tawit Keitprapai (Thailand), and Stephen Funke (Finland). Also featuring
a Butoh symposium, Film Screening: “Rite of Passage” by Juliette Yu-Ming (France/Malaysia) and
Solstice Butoh Jam featuring all artists with guest musicians.
Why Butoh Fever, you may ask. There is a saying in Japanese, "If you sit on a rock long enough it will get hot." This is the 9th festival and it is steadily getting hotter. Also, in Japanese culture the word for the number 9 is similar to the sound for the word that  means "pain" or "distress". Butoh artist and Thailand's Butoh pioneer, Katsura Kan has often likened Butoh as an illness that once infected, people's lives change. In other Asian cultures, the number 9 symbolizes completion of the three realms of existence; Mind, Body, and Spirit. Butoh
is currently being practiced as a healing therapy as well. Butoh Fever may be
your cure or your disease.
Your contribution helps Thai artists get exposure from outside of Thailand. Many Thai artists have gone on to work internationally in the USA, Korea, Japan, Denmark, UK, Germany, and Italy as of a result of connections they made during the Festival. Any support you can offer is a blessing for future events.
  Risks & Challenges 50% of our audience are tourists that just happen upon the exhibition and come back to view the performances. 25% of our audiences are expats living in Thailand and the other 25% of our audience are Thai artists working in the performing arts. Currently Thailand is under a coup d’état and will not have a new government in place until September 2015. Therefore, embassies have been discouraging people from taking their vacations in Thailand. If tourism is down we would potentially lose half of our audience which helps us to cover our expenses. Therefore, I am asking for your help and support. Also, we are applying for a grant from the Japan Foundation in Bangkok and seeking local sponsors. B-Floor Theatre and Ray of Light Productions are main contributors with some in kind donations from Democrazy Studio. BACC offers us the space to work and gives the festival a high profile in the international community to attract audiences.

  Other Ways You Can Help 
If you cannot contribute at this time,
please spread the word by using the indieggo share tools. Plus like or comment on our indiegogo and facebook page. You can also donate
frequent flyer miles to support artist’s airfare by contacting me at bkkbutoh@yahoo.com.Many Thanks and Blessings for your support in keeping this Festival alive!

story:
Art should plant the seed of mystery
for the soul to be awaken back to life.
         Simone Weil

Prologue is a mixed-media performance created as a composition of moments – snapshots into the life and thought of French philosopher, activist, and mystic, Simone Weil (1909 – 1943.)  Two performers, a man playing an actor preparing to interpret Simone Weil, and a woman embodying Weil herself as per the actor’s invocation, meet in this full-length production. Through the actor’s meditations, the piece also reflects on the mystical and artistic processes, and the indispensable role of “the other” in the construction of meaning.

Conceived almost as a live poem, Prologue draws on a multitude of languages (historical, biographical, allegorical, philosophical…) and mediums (theatre, dance, visual arts, video projections, music) to create a stimulating experience for the audience, both at a sensorial and intellectual levels.

Simone Weil, described by Albert Camus as “the only great spirit of our times” and by Susan Sontag as “one of the most uncompromising and troubling witnesses to the modern travail of the spirit.”  Weil’s empathy for the suffering of others, especially for the socially oppressed, would lead her into an active political life. She marched with the working class, confronted Trotsky, fought in the Spanish Civil War, participated in the French Resistance, and, sacrificing her privileged condition, she took a job in a factory in order to fully understand the reality of the proletariat. But even more unusual for a leftist intellectual of her time, after having a mystical experience, Weil increasingly focused her thought on religion and mysticism. Weil died at the age of 34, in exile in London, of tuberculosis possibly exacerbated by her refusal to eat more than the rations she thought were available to the people in occupied France. 

There is room for contradiction and controversy in Weil’s world, and Prologue does not try to resolve it; rather, it stays with her words and her laborious commitment to being, above anything else, attentive. For Weil, the capacity to pay attention is something very rare - almost a miracle, - and capable of reawakening the souls of those whom violence has turned into stone.  The piece intends to transpire the vulnerability and beauty that result from such a state of attentiveness. 


THE TEAM

Maria Litvan - writer, director

Maria's work questions perception and lives at the border between reality and allegory. It ponders on existential themes, but within the rhythm and non-structure of playtime. Her plays often combine complex topics with minimal language and absurd situations that heighten a reality other than what first meets the eye.  Her full-length theatre works include: Borderline (Loewe theatre);  Obsessions (Loewe theatre, and Galapos Art Space);  Psyche (Context Studios). She is the recipient of the John Golden Award for Excellence in Playwriting, the John Gassner Award, and in Catalonia, the Josep Robrenyo Award, among others. Maria holds an MA from Gallatin School of Individualized Study, NYU, with a concentration in performing arts, perception, and mysticism. 

Catherine Correa - Simone Weil

Born in Colombia, Catherine began training in classical ballet at the age of four in her natal country, and later on in San Petersburg Ballet Academy. By the age of 17, she was already performing professionally in Bogota. In 1998 she moved to New York City where she broadened her style to include modern dance and tango, performing with renowned dancers and choreographers.  She joined Buglisi Dance Theater Company in 2010 and is a current member of New Stage Theater Company where she was nominated for an IT award as best actress in a featured role in The Round of Pleasure.

Francisco Reyes – Actor

Francisco is a graduate from Madrid's Royal Academy of Drama (RESAD). His theater credits include Life is a Dream, Carrots (Zanahorias), Nocturnal Creatures, and El Quijote at the Spanish Repertory Theater. In 2009 he played The Commandant in the US and NYC premieres of NYTimes' Critic's Pick Way To Heaven (Himmelweg). He has received the HOLA (Hispanic Organization of Latin Actors) Award for Best Actor in 2010 and 2011. A resident of NYC, he also works in Spain regularly.

Laia Cabrera & Co. - video projections

Laia Cabrera & Co. is a company based in New York, co-founded by Spanish filmmaker and video artist Laia Cabrera and French animator and visual designer Isabelle Duverger, producing a wide range of multimedia projects, from traditional and experimental filmmaking, to the use of film and video streams in live performance, multimedia theater, video-mapped projection design and site-specific installation.
Laia Cabrera & Co. is an awarded creative team searching for new ways of using the space and visual imaginary as a tool for narrative storytelling and audience connection, driven by both scenographic and dramaturgical aspects. Their body of work that has been commissioned and presented in Europe, the USA and Latin America. Laia Cabrera & Co. is the recipient of the Telly Awards 2014 for best Art Direction, the AVA Awards 2013 and Telly Awards 2013 for best Animation and best Documentary. Laia Cabrera and Isabelle Duverger have also twice been nominated for Outstanding Innovative Design (Projection Design, Video-Art and Animations) for The New Stage Theatre Company's productions ofGarden of Delights by Fernando Arrabal at the New York Innovative Theater Awards 2013, and Cosmicomics by Italo Calvino at the NYIT 2014.

Nana Simopoulos – music and sound design

Nana is considered one of the foremost composers of world fusion music.  She artfully blends sounds and textures from around the world.  The late Indian sarangi master Ustad Sultan Khan accompanied her on two releases, After The Moon, 1997 and Daughters Of The Sun, 2001, which was #1 on the NAV New Age and World radio charts. She has written numerous commissions for dance companies such as Dance Theatre of Harlem with former Pilobolus choreographer Peter Pucci, the Joffrey Ballet, The American Dance Festival, Ballet Hispanico, North Carolina Dance Theater and LiquidBody.

story:
Background

Hello Everyone - 

My name is Marcus May and I'm teaming up with Caleb Nunez again and were excited to be using indiegogo to get people equally excited about our project. Every project we do we want to do the next one bigger and better!!! Guess what, this project is the next one! All the donations and support will go towards a production team that will create a DVD of the play.

story:
Hi there!

Thanks for taking the time to check out our campaign to help fund our production of The Whale by Samuel D. Hunter.

We’re Melissa Livingston-Weaver and Shanon Weaver, Co-Artistic Directors of the Austin, TX-based theatre company a chick & a dude productions. We’re celebrating our 11th season in Austin with this magnificent story by one of the hottest young playwrights in America!

The Whale tells the story of Charlie, a 600-pound man in Northern Idaho. Charlie was once married, with a daughter—Ellie—who he loved very much. But that all changed when Charlie met Alan. Alan was a Mormon, the son of a Bishop. They couldn’t stand to be apart. Charlie & Alan fell in love, Charlie left his wife & daughter, and Alan left the church. Some years later, Alan’s father forced him to go to church just one last time. Alan agreed, and came back…changed. Alan gave up on life, and died soon after. Charlie began eating his way to his own grave, with the enabling assistance of his caretaker, Liz. This week, Charlie wants to mend fences. He wants to reconnect with his daughter—who is now quite the terror. A Mormon on his mission, Elder Thomas, arrives in Charlie’s life, and may be able to shed some light on exactly what happened to Alan at the old Mormon Church over by the U-Haul. Charlie knows he’s not long for this world, and will use his last week on earth to make sure he’s done just one thing right with his life. The Whale is a play about love, empathy, family…and much, much more. We’re very excited to bring this Off-Broadway smash to Austin for its Texas premiere!

As you know, funding for the arts is limited and hard to come by. In reaching our campaign goal, we’ll ensure our entire design and artistic team are paid what they’re worth for the amazing talents they provide. We’ve raised about 2/3 of what we need for a successful run, and we hope you see fit to help us reach our goal!

Your donation today helps us pay for the following:

·  Licensing Rights for The Whale

·  Actor fee x4

·  Set Designer fee

·  Set Construction costs

·  Lighting Designer fee

·  Lighting equipment rental

·  Master Electrician fee

·  Costume Design fee

·  “Fat Suit” construction

·  Costumes

·  Props

·  Sound Design Fee

·  Sound equipment rental

·  Graphic Designer fee

·  Poster & Program printing

·  Advertising/Marketing costs

·  Light & Sound Board Operator

·  Concessions

·  Venue rental costs

The director, production manager, and actor playing Charlie are all donating their time and receiving no pay, in order to have more to spread around everyone else.

As you can see, there’s plenty to pay for! All of this comes out to around $12,000, and we’ve got around $8,000 so far thanks to the City of Austin, private donors, and previous fundraising efforts. If we don’t make the goal, we’ll stretch what we do make as far as we can!

We know times are tight. We know high-dollar donations aren’t an option for everyone. That’s why we’re setting our increments rather low! We’re operating under the idea that if we can get a lot of people to give a little, we’ll reach our goal faster than asking a few people to give a lot.

We’ve got some great rewards, too! Your donation today can earn things like a personal “thank-you” email from the director, a show poster signed by the cast, free tickets to the show, and more!

Of course, a chick & a dude productions is a Sponsored Project of Austin Creative Alliance, a 501 (C) 3 non-profit organization, so if you’d like to make a bigger donation or would like your donation to be tax-deductible, please visit our website here.

Theatre is one of the last storytelling art forms that can’t be downloaded, streamed or digitally shared. It is one of the few remaining live experiences, and it’s important to support new work from talented storytellers. From the deepest parts of our souls, we thank you for taking a moment to read about our campaign, and we hope you decide to help in any way you can!

For more information about a chick & a dude productions, please visit us online at www.achickandadude.com.

Thanks!

The Whale, by Samuel D. Hunter

Starring:

Erin Barlow as Liz

Jon Cook as Elder Thomas

Elizabeth Mason as Mary

Kayla Newman as Ellie

Shanon Weaver as Charlie

Directed by Melissa Livingston-Weaver

Scenic Design by Michael B. Raiford

Lighting Design by Jason Amato

Costume Design by Katy Billik-Hogge

Fat Suit by Kelly Ruiz

Graphic Design by Dan Price

story:
My name is Olivia Ward and I am sixteen years old. I have been dancing since I was three and I can't imagine my life without it. I live with my wonderful parents, who are always there for me and support me in everything I do. I currently dance at the BalletMet Dance Academy. Part of a dancer's development is having the opportunity to learn from new teachers in a fresh and challenging environment. Participating in a summer intensive provides dancers with this opportunity. I've dedicated the past thirteen years of my life to dance and I finally realize that my goal is to become a professional jazz/contemporary dancer and performer. I know that trying to make it in the dance world is difficult and is certainly no small task. That is why I ask for your support in helping my goal become a reality, by attending the Joffrey Jazz and Contemporary Summer Intensive in New York City, this summer, from July 28 through August 15, 2014. I attended a competitive audition in Cincinnati in early January to be considered for the program and found out two weeks later that I was accepted. I was thrilled. Attending this program in the heart of New York City has always been a dream of mine as a dancer. I plan to continue my dance training at BalletMet for my senior year of high school, and then go on to study dance and acting in college in preparation for my career. I look forward to sharing this exciting journey with all of my family, friends and sponsors. I will be sure to update you all frequently as my journey progresses. I would appreciate any donations that you are willing to make to help me get to Joffrey NYC this summer. Thank you for your help and consideration in sending me on my way. 


Many blessings to everyone! 


~Olivia Taylor Ward~

story:
Who We Are

Theatre of NOTE's final play of our 30th Anniversary Season is the ambitious and evocative HAVE YOU SEEN ALICE?, written by Jacqueline Wright and Directed by Adrian Alex Cruz.


What We Do

 Theatre of NOTE is a non-profit democratic company that stage-dives the arena of the theater arts.  Founded in 1981, our ensemble based organization is dedicated to providing a creative environment in which to collaborate on and develop maverick theater. NOTE produces an average of four mainstage shows a year, focusing on World, West-Coast and Los Angeles premieres.  In addition we also produce, NOTEworthy, to develop new plays and community outreach with The Young Writer's Project.


HAVE YOU SEEN ALICE? is a whimsical thriller. Alice struggles against her own ennui -- stuck in a complacent marriage quickly losing all sense of love and connection -- she becomes drawn into a worldwide gender war. Her sanity hangs in the balance as she is forced to choose between the strained banality of her domestic life and the high wire-drama of a secret conspiracy urging her to sacrifice herself for the greater good. Leaving us to wonder why is Alice, a seemingly inconsequential and utterly average woman, so important? Dripping with surreal and poignant images the drama is a moving allegory for the universal struggle we all feel, caught between the daily battles to get up and go to work, pay bills, plan for the future, and the larger global issues that seem so distant and impossible to resolve.


What We Need

As you know grant money for the Arts is getting harder and harder to come by and it is a shortfall of grant money that we are trying to make up with this campaign. We are $3000 short of our goal, and need to raise it in record time, just FOUR WEEKS!!  If you support Theater, the Arts, local writers, even actors, please make a tax-deductible donation. Any amount you donate is appreciated and will go directly to the operating and design budget for HAVE YOU SEEN ALICE?

We are $3000 short of our goal, and need to raise it in record time, just FOUR WEEKS!!  If you support Theater, the Arts, local writers, even actors, please make a tax-deductible donation. Any amount you donate is appreciated and will go directly to the operating and design budget for HAVE YOU SEEN ALICE?

story:
Our Story

For those who missed it, Wonderland takes the basic concept of an act-by-act variety show, combines it with the narrative story line adapted from Lewis Caroll’s “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland”.  With everything from break-dancing playing cards to a mad tea party who’s sanity is literally hanging by the skin of its back, Wonderland is a modern retelling of a classic tale through music and burlesque. 

Starring International Burlesque star and Miss Exotic World 2010 Roxi DLite, featuring original artwork and illustrations by Theatre Bizarre mastermind John Dunivant, scored by Detroit singer/songwriters Drew Bardo and Rabeah Lteif and performed live by The Glass Orphans, the video production captures the live performance “Wonderfully”. Mastered in Blu-ray HD with 5.1 audio and bonus features. The disc will also include an audio cd of the soundtrack recorded by The Glass Orphans.


The Impact

The release of the show and soundtrack is to help insure the future of Wonderland as a live performance.  We hope to be able to fund future productions of Wonderland, as well as other big shows.     


What We Need & What You Get

The funds we are raising will go towards production and duplication costs.  The people that have put so much time and so much talent into this production deserve to be compensated for their work.  They have been working in good faith because they believe in this project.  As for duplication, the more discs we can order, the less expensive they are per unit.  

The buttons and prints are limited edition.  They will not be available to the public once this campaign has ended.


Other Ways You Can Help

SPREAD THE WORD!  We are very proud of this show and believe that it has something for just about everyone.

story:
There’s something magical about New Orleans. Yes, it’s a beautiful city full of charm and interesting people. But the art is like no other, and one major art form that is in serious risk of disappearing in this great city is performing arts. Usually dancers have to travel outside of the city, and even the state to showcase their unique talents. And getting paid? Well, that’s rare. We have so much talent right here in our backyard, and we want to expose our community to this treasure, and also give our extremely awesome talent pool a chance to perform and get paid to do it. What’s just as important about this project is that there are droves of children who have a deep, overwhelming passion for performing arts, and they too, need a place and an opportunity to feed their creative abilities and to pursue a life in the arts. So proceeds from every performance and anything remaining after the show is paid for will benefit their new, state-of-the-art dance studio being built in the historic neighborhood of Treme (yes, the neighborhood-turned HBO Show).

New Orleans Dance Collective, founded by Janet Andrews, is a 501(c)3 non-profit youth organization (your support is tax-deductible) that actively links dance with social work and seeks to address the overwhelming need for positive, life-affirming, esteem-building cultural activities for inner-city at-risk youth in post-Katrina New Orleans. As you can imagine, most local resources were completey diminished and depleted following what was probably the worst natural disaster in the last 50 years in America. But, we’re done crying about it. Moving on and rebuilding what was once a hub for every art form imaginable is the goal. The Arts-On Fire focuses on all art forms, in hopes to create spectacular events that give the talent of our great country a place to expose their abilities to a diverse audience. It’s also a way to help them earn a living for what they are good at, their special gifts. This campaign will help these local performing artists, and help to groom the performers of the future, through Mrs. Andrew’s dance studio. The kids will be able to work with a professional choreographer, professional dancers, and more importantly, in front of audiences who care about New Orleans and who are hungry to see a show that combines jazz, ballet, burlesque, lyrical dance, aerial and fire, circus arts and theatre all into one. There’s no better place for a show like this.

Thanks to everyone who’s interested in this great campaign. As we continue to grow and provide other opportunities for artists and children to flourish in the world of arts, we hope you will grow with us too. Until the next big thing, we cannot say enough how excited we are for your support. From The Arts-On Fire family to yours, thank you.

About “Enchanted”: Enchanted is unique evening length show featuring a combination of various performing arts. Costume design will play a huge role in bringing each scene to life. The children of New Orleans Dance collective will be opening and closing the show with the performers, in a week long run featuring two shows a day in July 2012.

story:
Last year, my classmate Brennen Johnson and I sat in the basement of Nazareth College with wide eyes and illuminated grins. We were watching something we felt was truly magical. We were watching Nazareth College's production of "Almost, Maine".

Brennen and I were theatre nerds, and we wound up in that basement on a field trip with our IB Theatre class (Like 'AP', but different). We didn't think much of the show as we walked in, but as we walked out, we shared a mutual admiration for the show we had never quite felt for any other show.

Almost immediately after leaving the show, we made a promise to ourselves, we were going to direct our own production of the show, and we would do it within the year.

And so, we took to the interwebs, contacting local theatre companies and pleading our case as convincingly as possible. Meanwhile, we were given the opportunity to direct scenes from John Cariani's "Almost, Maine" along with several other young directors directing separate one-acts as part of our IB Theatre course. We were incredibly excited to excercise our passion and prepare ourselves for the promise we swore we wouldn't let fall through.

It was around this time the lovely folks at Black Sheep Theatre gave us some attention, and allowed us to create a formal Performance Proposal. We jumped through several hoops until finally, we found out that we would finally be able to fufill the promise we made each other.

We are more than excited to be a part of this show, and unbelievably grateful to the board at Black Sheep Theatre for giving us the opportunity to direct such a show. That said, we have a vision, and the vision? Well, that's what we are still trying to fufill, and we need your help.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, and that's totally okay, but that doesn’t mean you can't help!

If you get in contact with one of us, you can help us an assortment of things! Set building, painting, STAGE CREW, all sorts of things!

story:
Hi Beautiful People!

Thank you so much for stopping by at our fundraising page for STANDBYS by Alex Riad, which will be part of the Thespis Theater Festival in New York on August 13th, 16th, and 18th! We have created this page because... well... we need your help to get this project off the ground (some of the play takes place on a plane, so that's funny). All proceeds from the fundraiser go directly to production costs like stipends for the artists, rehearsal space, sets, etc... Please, be an angel and support indie theatre. It takes the power of many to make a vision come together, and this is what the page is all about. 

We appreciate all of your support! 

Neil, Alex, and Phivos

----------------------------------

STANDBYS by Alex Riad

Directed By: Shira-Lee Shalit

Starring: Kathleen O'Neal, Andrew Justin Smith, & Laura Hooper

Produced by: Neil Tyrone Pritchard, Phivos Christofides, & Alex Riad

Video: Alan Rae (http://vimeo.com/user19348995)

Artwork: Sean Kaufman (http://www.skaufdesigns.com)

Lighting: Michael Kalmanowitz

Set-Design: Jonathan Cottle

Sound Design: Andy Cohen

----------------------------------

SYNOPSIS

Set during the London Blizzard of 2010 that grounded planes for days, "Standbys" is the story of Ron and Mary, two ex-coworkers, two ex-friends, two ex-lovers, and current seatmates on the last flight out of Heathrow International Airport. While on the plane and subsequently in a hotel room, they are forced to confront the moment it all went wrong for them as well as their selfish and selflessness, affecting their families back home.

----------------------------------

WHERE/WHEN?

Cabrini Repertory Theater
701 Fort Washington Ave,
New York, NY

Tuesday August 13th, 8pm
Friday August 16th, 9pm
Sunday August 18th, 6pm

The play will be part of the Thespis Theater Festival.

story:
Thank you for visiting my page, even the fact that you made it this far is very much appreciated! As you know I successfully gained a place on the MT course at the RWCMD earlier this year and am due to start this January. I'm so excited to move to Cardiff but still have a few financial issues that I'm trying to iron out before the course starts next month. With total costs approaching £14000 before living costs, I am looking for any support that anyone can give. Ideally I'd like you to come to my fundraising concert on the 13th of December but if you can't make that then please feel free to leave a donation here. I honestly appreciate any help that anyone can give and am grateful for even a small donation. Thanks to all who've got me this far- I know many of you just want me to move away from Scotland! I promise your support will not go unnoticed or be forgotten.

Thanks,

Ronan x

story:
Obscene/Courageous is a non-profit theatre company based in Boulder, Colorado. The H.P. Lovecraft Holiday Special is especially special, because it marks the end of our one year anniversary as a company.

And in celebration of the event five of our esteemed ensemble members have taken on the daunting, but ever-rewarding task of deciphering three Lovecraft classics. We are to present our adaptations of, The Call of Cthulhu, From Beyond and The Dunwich Horror, which are sure to fill you with holiday cheer… or horrify you into madness!

Here’s where Indiegogo comes in.

As a non-profit, it is important the production remains donation-based. Thus, we are asking for your help.

Although our means are often limited, we have a strong commitment to paying our artists.

In order to do so we need $500, which means each of the ten actors will receive $50 for their many hours of exhaustive, though passionately committed labor.

In other words, here's where your money goes:

$500- Actor Honorarium: our ten actors are each paid $50


$700- ‘We are calling this our stretch goal of extra-awesomeness’

Not only do the 10 starving artists get paid, but a production dream becomes reality: our show now features the magic of a puppeteer! The additional $200 will cover expenses required for a professional puppet artisan.

 

And in return, we will put on a thoroughly entertaining and a slightly disturbing  OB/CO show!

Greatest thanks for your help!

Please send any queries to lovecraftobco@gmail.com.

 

"Ph'nglui mglw'nafh Cthulhu R'lyeh wgah'nagl fhtagn"

story:
What?

The Blind Theatre Thailand is

- a full-scaled multi-dimensional theatre in Thailand. 
- a collaboration between blind and regular-sighted people.
- a theatre experience that does not require visual sense.

We want to create a theatre experience that can be enjoyed by both the visually impaired people and the visually able.

The funding will be put into our latest performance "The Story from Fireflies" and to fund our theatre. We hope to put on this performance on every night on 15th -18th May 2014. We want to make this a sustainable theatre, meaning any profit after the performance will be used to fund the next project that will guarantee to hire blind actors. We hope we will be creating stable jobs for blind actors. 

Why ?

  • To create the space where blind and sighted can interact and collaborate in a creative environment. 
  • To allow general public to perceived the blind in 
  • To be a place where blind people can show their potentials, try new things. 
  • To train blind students theatre and acting skills. 
  • To make blind people realize their self-worth. 
  • To established and run as an acting company that actively hire blind people as actors. 

We have worked with blind students before and the experiences are positive for both sides. From the first version of "The Story from Fireflies" the students enjoy themselves immensely. Acting is very empowering and thought provoking for the students. 

How ?

How can a blind go to a theatre when they can’t see what’s happening? Well we want to put together a performance that does not require you to see. We want to tell the story using other senses like hearing, taste, smell, touch and (certain ways of lighting as not every blind person is completely blind). We can’t be very specific here as it will spoil the story! But for example we are taking you to many places, into the deep woods or a part of Bangkok! A tree might pop up near you or you might suddenly feel the rain! 

The audience will be blind folded and led into performing space by our guide. Then "The Story from Firefly" will start. It is a 90 minutes long story which will be told using voices, music, movable props (our props are very active), smells, touches. 


Who ?

As you can see (no pun intended) we want to make this an engaging and fun experience for everyone. In order to do that we have  very capable 50 actors and stage technicians ranging from student actors to profession theatre actor and Thai TV stars involving in the process! 

Our 3 directors are 


Natthawadee Karnjanasoot 
Natthawadee challenged the norm and critically explored the preconceived perceptions that Thai society has towards the blinds. Her piece “The Blind Sighted” (2013) boldly examined the selective and convoluted treatments the blinds received. This was done by imaginatively led dialogue between actors and the audience. “The Blind Sighted” went on to win Innovation for Social Enterprise 2013 held by Thammasart University Service Learning Centre. 


Petcharat Maneenuch 
Her adaptation of “Charlotte’s Web” (“Mangmum Puen Rak” (2013)) was a popular piece amongst young audiences. Her version was tailored especially so that both blind and sighted children can be engaged with the story. 


Kris Sanguanpiyapand
Kris was one of the leaders who devised the first version of “The Story from Fireflies”. The show received positive feedbacks. While volunteering as a companion to the blind, he sees potentials rather than constraints.  



Perks 

We have added international tracks. This is for supporters who can not make it during the performance dates. We unfortunately can not fly you to see our performance so we have set up this track. (We do hope you can come to Thailand though!)

Regarding tickets please email us at blindtheatrethailand@gmail.com 

*Though our perks are name after types of perception this is not in anyway an indication that we think one type of perception is better than another* 

**Speech in the performance will be in Thai BUT we have had audiences who can not speak Thai. The feedback was the story was very relaxing.**


When ?

Performance date from 15-18 May 2014, 7 pm ,
5th Floor, Prof. Dr.SarojBuasri Innovation Building, .
Srinakharinwirot University, Bangkok , Thailand

Make a reservation through (+66)80-444-0023 or (+66)80-586-1525

           

          Close your eyes and touch your mind..... believe in other senses

For further updates, please go to Facebook Page :https://www.facebook.com/theblindtheatre
IG :blindtheatrethailand
 E-mail : blindtheatrethailand@gmail.com


Other Ways You Can Help

·  it's not just "Help us" but you will be the one of our 'Power'.

·  OR.....Share this to your friends!!!! or share this to someone that might be interest in this really incredible new innovation event for our future!!!

Thank you very much....

story:
We've reached our goal BUT don't stop giving! We can still use the funds over our budgeted amount.

THE STORY:

“By their fruits they will be known”. The back yard of 798 Ruby Place is both a fortress and battlefield for the Seed family. Will newfound romance get the best of the beloved matriarch, or will a prophecy left by her late husband be enough to save her little birds from harm? Only the apple tree knows. Ruby Place Nest on the Ground is Part Two of Angelica Chéri’s series, The Prophet’s Cycle, Abraham’s Seed. 

 

DATES:

Ruby Place Nest on the Ground will be performed at Signature Theater in midtown Manhattan for 3 limited performances between May 8th -11th.  

THE CREATIVE TEAM:

Playwright: Angelica Cheri

Director: Reginald L. Douglas

Producer: Jiles R. King, II

Stage Manager: Shanjala Fraizer

Set Designer: Alexander Woodard

Costume Designer: Jerry L. Johnson

 

THE CAST:

David Seed: Larry Powell     

Esther Seed: Simone Leanora            

Thea Seed-McHouse: Bianca LaVerne Jones            

TL McHouse: Willie Teacher            

Jimmy McHouse: Ty King            

Willie Cartwright: Alex Ubokudom            

 

WHAT WE NEED:

Producing a show in New York City is very expensive. We are raising $1000.00 to cover the cost of the production. We have assembled a dynamic cast and creative team for this poignant story. Our costs include printing and distributing of publicity materials, matierals for set and props construction and period costumes from the 1960s.

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP:

By making a donation to this production you are enabling us to provide this story and all the hard work we are putting into it, the production it deserves. Please see our different perk packages below.


If you are unable to help, please spread the word do pass on this campaign to those people who might be interested in helping our cause!
story_txt:
We've reached our goal BUT don't stop giving! We can still use the funds over our budgeted amount. 
THE STORY:
“By their fruits they will be known”. The back yard of 798 Ruby Place is both a fortress and battlefield for the Seed family. Will newfound romance get the best of the beloved matriarch, or will a prophecy left by her late husband be enough to save her little birds from harm? Only the apple tree knows. Ruby Place Nest on the Ground is Part Two of Angelica Chéri’s series, The Prophet’s Cycle, Abraham’s Seed. 
 
DATES:
Ruby Place Nest on the Ground will be performed at Signature Theater in midtown Manhattan for 3 limited performances between May 8th -11th.  
THE CREATIVE TEAM:
Playwright: Angelica Cheri
Director: Reginald L. Douglas
Producer: Jiles R. King, II
Stage Manager: Shanjala Fraizer
Set Designer: Alexander Woodard
Costume Designer: Jerry L. Johnson
 
THE CAST:
David Seed: Larry Powell     
Esther Seed: Simone Leanora            
Thea Seed-McHouse: Bianca LaVerne Jones            
TL McHouse: Willie Teacher            
Jimmy McHouse: Ty King            
Willie Cartwright: Alex Ubokudom

story:
Short Summary

The Open Air Dancers is a group of dancers from the University of North Carolina School of the Arts dedicated to spreading the joy of live dance through improvised performances in public spaces. With our dancing we strive to make modern dance more accessible for everybody, taking the dance out of theaters and integrating it into the parks, colleges, landmarks, and hangouts at which people congregate every day. To make our performances as relevant and interesting for our audiences as possible, we try especially hard to utilize unique aspects of the landscape and sometimes even props to complement our dancing. 

The Open Air Dancers will be in Charlotte, NC from May 24 – 31, 2013, sharing our craft wherever we can. Our performances are generally 15 minutes long and include solo and contact improvisation, choreographed solo work, and a short choreographed group section. We intend to photograph and film the majority of our performances. At the end of the summer, we will edit the media into a short film documenting the entire process, from rehearsals to travel to performance and even some dancer interviews. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our main concern is to make sure our dancers and collaborators are well paid for their work. Even though it is our passion to travel and dance for others, dancing in the hot sun for hours a day is hard work and our dancers cannot perform unless they are fed and well rested. Your contributions will go toward giving our dancers their per diem pay, which will cover their food, gas, and lodging expenses during the week of travel. 

If we are fortunate enough to surpass our goal, the extra funds will go toward hiring another dancer into our group, as well as upgrading our camera and sound equipment. These will significantly improve the quality of our production, and the additional dancer will offset the risk of injury. We have some fun perks we would love to share with you, so give generously if you can. 

Other Ways You Can Help

As starving college students studying to be starving artists, we understand that not everybody can afford to give money. But there are still other ways you can help us reach our goal! Tell your friends, share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, your blog, or anywhere else you think a generous soul might see it.

We are artists above all and love to collaborate! If you are a Charlotte area artist and would be interested in collaborating with us in any way (trust us, we’re up for a lot), please contact us and let us know. Also, if you are the owner or manager of a site in the Charlotte area where you think site specific dancers would be appreciated, we would love to hear from you.

More About Us

The Open Air Dancers is led by Graham Cole and Zoe Warshaw, two students of contemporary dance at the University of North Carolina School of the arts.

A Raleigh, NC native, Graham has been dancing since the age of 6 and has never stopped. Before attending college, Graham trained at North Carolina Dance Theatre in Charlotte, NC, where he was privileged to be a part of NCDT’s Random Acts of Culture outreach program. As a member of this endeavor, funded by the Knight Foundation, Graham gained invaluable experience in improvised public performance. Graham is currently a sophomore at the University of North Carolina School of the Arts, where he has performed in works by Jose Limon, Daniel Gwirtzman, Merce Cunningham, and Brenda Daniels. Graham is also among a select group of UNCSA students who will perform at the Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C. this May as part of a program honoring the accomplishments of Sally Ride. In the rare pockets of time when Graham is not dancing, he enjoys baking, cycling, and listening to stand-up comedy.

Zoe Warshaw was born and raised in New Hampshire. She has had an innate zeal for movement since she was three years old and continues to enjoy all of the opportunities that dance presents. Zoe has trained in ballet, jazz, hip hop, improvisation, acting, and multiple styles of modern dance. Zoe is a high school graduate of the University of North Carolina School of the Arts and a current junior in the school’s Contemporary Dance BFA program. Zoe has had the honor of participating in work’s by Doug Elkins, Jose Limon, Larry Keigwin, Twyla Tharp, and Bill T. Jones. She has also had the privilege of performing in a world premier site specific proformance choreographed by Mark Dendy at the N.C. Museum of Art. Zoe has recently returned from NYC where she and her fellow classmates performed self choreographed solos and a group piece choreographed by Grady Bowman at the Ailey CitiGroup Theater. Zoe is entering her senior year this fall and is extremely excited to delve deep into any possiblities and opportunities that await after graduation.

story:
HZV: HUMAN TO ZOMBIE VIRUS

My name is Aaron Anthony Bonilla, the playwright of "HZV: Human to Zombie Virus" and this play (not porno) has been a project of passion this last year, but this project is more than just the twisted visions of a playwright connecting the adult industry of the 80's, a love for zombie movies (Romero films are the best) and stories of heart break, broken dreams and egotistical apathy.  This project is a group of collegues and friends that have been giving so much of their time and artistic energy to make this play come to life. Our goal is to open in October of this year, perfect for Halloween. We're not only actors, we're producing HZV as a team.

PRODUCTION TEAM:

Aaron A. Bonilla          Director

Rachel Speth              Stage Manager

Robert Benjamin         Technical Director

Sabrina Cavalletto      Costume Designer

Krista Powell              Make-up Desinger

Casey Kooyman          Fight chorographer

 

CAST OF HZV:

Cooper Karn                Thomas Feelgood 

Casey Kooyman           Murray Rogers         

Sabrina Cavalletto        Anita Dichs             

Jorden Angel               Iron Peter               

Alisa Marie Taylor        India Ass

Joe Filippone               Jack Mehov             

Krista Powell               Laura Leach            

Robert Benjamin         Andrew Leach          

So, as you can see we are a team who really wants the chance to fund this play of sexy zombies and scandalous stories.

If you would like to have a sample read of our play "HZV: Human to Zombie Virus" to have a better idea about the nature of our show please contact us at (h2zombievirus@gmail.com)

 

THE OVERALL PICTURE FOR HZV

We're asking for $5500 for the production and this is how we plan to allocate the funds...

$ 3200             Rehearsal and Performance Space (12 performances)

$ 700               Set

$ 400               Media (Posters/Play Bills/Advertising)

$ 400               Indiegogo and Paypal fees

$ 350               Costumes

$ 250               Props

$ 100               Make-Up

$ 100               Script Printing

Total: $5500

 

When you donate to our play you'll receive some fun perks like autographed posters at the $100 level or a unique Zombie Survival Kit from the $150 level or a very special benefactor's reception for all who donate $250 and above as a thank you for making our Zombie dreams come true!

Now let's say the zombie apocalypse is thwarted and we fall short of our goal, the zombie march will carry on and any help that is given will take us further than any undead howler cry echoing in the midnight sky.

 

THE IMPACT OF YOUR SUPPORT FOR OUR SURVIVAL

All the contributions from your amazing support will help us to present new work that of which comes from the heart of this group of artist. We strive to be independent in our art form and tell stories that are built from the ground up. This play was written many years ago but was banished to the "binder-of-forgotten-material" but as we all graduated from our academic and theatrical institutions, we banded together to help each other bring new life to our industry. We truly believe that as working artists, with real jobs to support our bills; when our industry lacks the opportunities for our growth, we must create the work for ourselves and with your support we can make this "nightmare/fantasy" (remember this is a play not a porno) come to life.

OTHER WAYS TO HELP FIGHT FOR HUMANITY

If you are super interested in our show but truly can't contibute, there are plenty of other ways to helps us...tell as many people about our fundraiser, share us on Facebook and Twitter; please use the any and all share tools on Indiegogo to help make as much noise about HZV. If you have any other comments or ideas about support for our campagin please email us at (h2zombievirus@gmail.com)

story:
Thank you so much for visiting my fundraiser campaign!  Let me start off by saying that I greatly appreciate your time and consideration. 

I would like to give you a little background on me as a performer and explain why this festival is so important.  First of all, I am still fairly new to the burlesque world.  I have only been performing professionally since May 2012.  Since that glorious moment when I first took the stage, I have been invited to perform in five festivals, several large shows in Dallas as well as formed my own bi-monthly show, the Plumb Askew Revue.  These are major accomplishments for someone so new to the community.  To be invited to perform internationally is a dream come true!  Your gift will aid me in fullfilling this dream.

My campaign is simple.  Burlesque dancers do not perform because there is lots of money to be made.  They perform burlesque because they love the art and the joy it brings to their soul.  I am no different.  I do not have a surplus of funds to just throw at this trip.  I can fund some of it and I am hopeful to receive the support of my family, friends and fans to help me with the rest.

Performing in Burlesque Festivals is very important to me.  I am constantly approached after shows by plus size women who confide in me and say how much they wish they could be me and how much they envy my strength and confidence.  I am also proud to say that my performances have inspired several of those same women to embrace their own sexy woman within.  I want to continue doing that!  The more festivals I am able to apply to, get accepted into, and perform in, the more people I can reach and inspire with my art form.   To be able to take this mission overseas is a true gift and I simply cannot wait to motivate the lovely and curvy women of Dublin, Ireland!

What Your Gift is Funding:

I am asking for $1375.  This breaks down to:

Round Trip Flight from Dallas to Dublin - $700

Four Nights of Lodging - $315

Five Days of Rental Car - $160

Food and Incidental Allowance - $200

 

Fees Involved with using this service :

The fees are 4% if goal is met and 9% if goal is not met.  I would like to earn a little over my goal so that the actual money that I end up with is what I need.

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you are unable to contribute financially, you can still help by sharing this fundraising campaign on all of your social media outlets and spread the word about this fantastic opportunity I have been given.

THANK YOU VERY MUCH!!

story:
Help us thank Shami McCormick!!

For more than 30 years Shami has made an amazing contribution to the theatre community as the Artistic Director of the Depot Theatre. An outstanding Artistic Director, mentor, and friend who's generosity and passion for theatre knows no bounds. She brought hundreds of productions to life and nurtured thousands of theatre artists during her time at the Depot.  We all know she went above and beyond the call of duty. For all the countless ways Shami has touched our lives, let's come together and give her a gift to show our love and appreciation!

story:
What is CARTOOON?

CARTOOON is a hugely ambitious live-action homage to the animated shorts of the 1940s and 1950s. Four puppeteers, one narrator, a nine person chorus, a ten person pit orchestra and conductor, and three children ranging in age from 7-9 will bring this Tex-Avery and Looney Tunes tweaking masterpiece to life. Life size cardboard replicas of adolescent elephants, bank safes, and pianos will descend from the sky. A giant velvety tongue will cross Lake St. order a taco, consume it, and roll back to the theater. The use of cardboard dynamite sticks will steadily escalate to an explosive climax. 

Where will my dollars go?

We need your help to pay performers, musicians, zipline riggers, lighting technicians! We are also looking for assistance with supplies. Cardboard is cheap but it's not free, and neither is paint. We are using quite a bit of both. Your dollars will all go directly towards making Cartooon a once-in-a-lifetime, immersive, engaging theatrical experience. 

How can I help spread the word? 

It would be amazing if you could share this campaign with your friends and families and casual acquaintances and internet friends and strangers! You can do that through Facebook, Twitter or by emailing the link. 

Thank you!

story:
Poetic Justice Project

Everyone knows Telly was a cold-hearted dude, even by prison standards.  No one was shocked when he turned up dead one morning in the prison mess hall with a carving knife in his back.

The warden needs an answer and Captain Roland has to narrow the list of suspects down and find the killer but who was it?

Alejandro, the former gang member who turns to poetry for redemption?

Conrad, the decorated veteran whose up for parole after almost 40 years in prison?

Or Hughie, the charismatic hustler who mixed up in the wrong poker circle?

The audience decides in Poetic Justice Projects "In the Kitchen with a Knife"  an inter-active prison murder mystery.

Poetic Justice Project is taking the show to Alcatraz, where our cast of formerly incarcerated artists will perform inside the iconic prison walls.

We need your help bringing the cast, crew and sets from Santa Maria, CA to Alcatraz Island for a special performance this Saturday, April 12th.

All we raise goes to lodging, gas and a modest compensation to our incredible team .   Please help us continue our mission of unlocking hearts and minds with bold, original theater,

And send these ex-cons back to Alcatraz!

A program of the William James Association, Poetic Justice Project began in 2009 in Santa Maria, CA with the vision of unlocking hearts and minds with bold, original theatre. We are the only theatre company that features formerly incarcerated actors in original plays that address crime, punishment and redemption. 

We performed WOMEN BEHIND THE WALLS by Claire Braz-Valentine on Alcatraz Island in 2011. We are thrilled to be invited back with our production of IN THE KITCHEN WITH A KNIFE!

What We Need & What You Get

We need help with travel costs! Our shows are at 7 p.m. on Saturday, April 11 at Calvary Episcopal Church in Santa Cruz and on Sunday, April 12, at 2 p.m. on Alcatraz. Donations from this campaign will go to:


--Vehicle Rental for our trip

--Gas

--Food and lodging for our 20 cast and crew members for Saturday, April 11 and Sunday, April 12.

--A small stipend for each actor

 

Everyone who donates $15 or more will receive a gift. If we raise more than our target goal, funds will be used for future Poetic Justice Project performances.

Changing Lives!

Poetic Justice Project is a life-changing theatre company. More than 80 actors have appeared in PJP's productions since we began. Our recidivism rate is under 2%, in a state that averages 65% to 70%.

Audiences also find themselves transformed by our plays. Some responses to local performances of IN THE KITCHEN WITH A KNIFE:

  • Actors were great!
  • It affected me emotionally.
  • Cons R people 2.
  • High level of professionalism—great acting.
  • Surprisingly, I’m more hopeful because these folks are so inspiring.
  • It was wonderful!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us get the word out!

We need your help bringing the cast, crew and sets from Santa Maria, CA to Alcatraz Island for a special performance this Saturday, April 12th.
All we raise goes to lodging, gas and a modest compensation to our incredible team .   Please help us continue our mission of unlocking hearts and minds with bold, original theater,
And send these ex-cons back to Alcatraz!A program of the William James Association, Poetic Justice Project began in 2009 in Santa Maria, CA with the vision of unlocking hearts and minds with bold, original theatre. We are the only theatre company that features formerly incarcerated actors in original plays that address crime, punishment and redemption. We performed WOMEN BEHIND THE WALLS by Claire Braz-Valentine on Alcatraz Island in 2011. We are thrilled to be invited back with our production of IN THE KITCHEN WITH A KNIFE!What We Need & What You GetWe need help with travel costs! Our shows are at 7 p.m. on Saturday, April 11 at Calvary Episcopal Church in Santa Cruz and on Sunday, April 12, at 2 p.m. on Alcatraz. Donations from this campaign will go to:--Vehicle Rental for our trip--Gas--Food and lodging for our 20 cast and crew members for Saturday, April 11 and Sunday, April 12.--A small stipend for each actor Everyone who donates $15 or more will receive a gift. If we raise more than our target goal, funds will be used for future Poetic Justice Project performances.Changing Lives!Poetic Justice Project is a life-changing theatre company. More than 80 actors have appeared in PJP's productions since we began. Our recidivism rate is under 2%, in a state that averages 65% to 70%.Audiences also find themselves transformed by our plays. Some responses to local performances of IN THE KITCHEN WITH A KNIFE:

Actors were great!

It affected me emotionally.

Cons R people 2.

High level of professionalism—great acting.

Surprisingly, I’m more hopeful because these folks are so
inspiring.

It was wonderful!







Other Ways You Can HelpPlease help us get the word out!

story:
Black Button Eyes Productions presents the Midwest Premiere of “Coraline,” a musical by Stephin Merritt and David Greenspan, adapted from the novel by Neil Gaiman, at City Lit Theater in Chicago, at 1020 W Bryn Mawn Ave, August 8 – Sept 6. “Coraline,” directed by Edward Rutherford with music direction from Nick Sula, begins previews August 8, with opening on August 9; the show runs through September 6.

“I’m a tremendous fan of Neil Gaiman’s work,” said Director Edward Rutherford, “and Stephin Merritt and David Greenspan’s adaptation has a spare and story theater-influenced approach that makes it a perfect piece to bring to Chicago’s storefront theater scene. With a dynamite cast and Nick Sula on board to guide us through the show’s unique score, I’m eager for us to begin rehearsals and start tackling this darkly entertaining script. While the story is about a little girl, it’s definitely not children’s theater.”

Adapted from the beloved fantasy novel Coraline by Neil Gaiman, this original musical by Stephin Merritt & David Greenspan tells the story of Coraline Jones, a young girl who has just moved with her parents into a new flat in an old house. Bored by her colorless surroundings and her busy parents, she goes exploring and discovers a door unlike any in the house – a magic door that, when unlocked, reveals  a passage to a strange world like her own, but with one key difference: all the grownups have black buttons for eyes. This new world seems to offer all she wants: parents who are keenly interested in her, toys that sing and dance, neighbors who get her name right. But as this parallel world becomes increasingly unsettling, Coraline must learn the true meaning of bravery to save her parents and herself.

“The score Stephin Merritt composed is singular,” said Music Director Nick Sula, “It’s composed for three different types of piano. Whenever Coraline sings, the score is written for multiple toy pianos, and we also have an upright piano for whenever the grownups sing in the real world. For the Other World, Merritt has written music for a specially ‘prepared’ baby grand piano, with various foreign objects inserted or attached between the piano strings. There’s no other musical quite like it.”

The cast for Coraline includes Sheridan Singleton (Coraline), Ryan Lanning (Other Mother), Kevin Webb (Cat), Kevin Bishop (Miss Forcible), Caitlin Jackson (Miss Spink), Justin Kimrey (Father / Other Father), Jeffrey Bouthiette (Mr. Bobo), Jennifer T. Grubb (Mother).

The creative team for Coraline includes Edward Rutherford (Director), Nick Sula (Music Director), Beth Laske-Miller (Costume Designer), Chazz Malott (Lighting Designer), Ryan Emens (Set Design), Cate Gillespie (Dialect Coach). The team is rounded out by Nathaniel Nesheim-Case (Stage Manager) and Kate Merena (Marketing Director), with additional staff to be announced.

Rehearsals start on July 7, and to make the show a reality we could really use your help! Thanks in advance for any donation you're able to give, and see you at the show!

story:
Tales of Enchantment are a small theatre company with big ideas. A Midsummer Night’s Dream will be our first ever fully public production and we need you to help make it happen. We want to use this classic and often studied play to explore ideas that are absolutely central to the world we live in now – equality, the patriarchy, LGBTQIA+ rights – and also the timeless subjects of love and relationships.

This crowdfunding campaign is just a quarter of our total budget for the show and its primary function is to pay the cast and crew. With all the current debate about minimum wage vs. a living wage, we hope you understand how vitally important it is that we recognise the performers as workers who deserve a decent, living wage. In the theatre industry it is so common to see companies squeezing by in what they offer to pay and we reject that model absolutely.

We have come up with some fun perks which we hope you enjoy but we hope you will agree that promoting and helping to fund the arts is a huge perk in and of itself. We couldn’t do it without you!

Even if you can’t contribute to our campaign, your help is still hugely appreciated!

-  Help us get the word out there by sharing on social media using the Indiegogo share tools.

-  Buy a ticket to come and see the production when we perform at Camden Fringe August 1st-7th http://www.camdenfringe.com/show.php?acts_id=691.

-  Follow us on twitter (@TofEnchantment) or on Facebook (www.facebook.com/talesofenchantment) so we can raise our social media profile and get ourselves out there.

story:
What

Our new piece, The Honey of His Music Vows, has been invited for a workshop at CoHo Productions in Portland this very summer! With poetry, music, language, and a lot of heart... this piece explores love in the age of text messaging, when words fail, the legacy of Shakespeare's Dark Lady, and how to make love stay.  

How You Can Help

CoHo is granting us a space and a small stipend, but it doesn't cover our flights (Maria and Susannah from NY, Avital from Denver, Danielle from San Francisco) or living expenses for our time in Portland. We're hoping to raise $1500, which will take care of the cost of flights, props, and printing materials (for our many, many drafts!) Anything additional will go towards compensating the artists.

We'd also love to have you join us for the performance, itself!  You can reserve your tickets here:  http://www.cohoproductions.org/coming-soon/coho...

*Avital Shira directs The Honey of His Music Vows is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of supporting Avital Shira directs The Honey of His Music Vows must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
