story:
Dear Family,
UNIVERSES just celebrated 21 years of doing this here thing it is we do, and we've loved every moment of it. We do things the way our people taught us to do, unapologetically, adding some of our own brand of secret sauce along the way; theater, music, movement, politics ... always in the DNA. It's not an easy journey, when you don't always conform to creating American Theater by the rule books; but we keep pushing, believing it can continue to evolve. 

We've been here for 21 years already (Drinking Age now), and it's been rough, but we must be doing somethings right. We raise our glass for all who've supported our journey to this date, but once this hangover is over, we have even more work to do.

UNIVERSES just closed our fierce run of "Party People" at The Public Theater a few weeks ago. We are proud to say that this production, spared no one.  Here's what The New York Times said, "In the current political climate, it (Party People) may be the most frightening and exciting piece of theater now up".  What's FRIGHTENING, are the coming four years and the fight we have to take on as a Nation.

Dear Family, Dear America, Party People is needed now more than ever. This is our 1st campaign to bring it back, in more ways than one (an audio book/soundtrack recording, a publication, back on stage); by any means necessary. Please support our ALL POWER TO THE PEOPLE - PARTY PEOPLE Fund. Give whatever you can. Let the Revolution continue. Palante, Siempre Palante  

 

UNIVERSES Poetic Musical Theater Ensemble is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of UNIVERSES Poetic Musical Theater Ensemble must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Camp Str8-N-Arrow Needs YOU!

Savage Umbrella invites YOU to bring Ex-Gays: Not a Str8 Remount to life. 

Set in fictional Camp Str8-N-Arrow, Ex-Gays: Not a Str8 Remount follows Pastor Brian and the rest of the camp staff as they help campers turn off their homosexual feelings and turn on their love of the heterosexual life. Through the lens of satire, Savage Umbrella takes a humorous and thoughtful look at the devastating effects of homophobia and religious zealotry. It's camp. It's satire. It's a camp satire.

Critic Adam Whisner said of the original 2011 production, “The show was wonderful. Hilarious, campy, silly, full of improv and scripted moments, but also packed a punch, revealing the devastating emotional consequences of this kind of thinking and the damage it can do to people who are duped by misguided religious zealotry. It's a solid, well-produced and executed piece of sociopolitical art. I absolutely recommend it.”​

 

 

About Savage Umbrella

Savage Umbrella - a queer-led, Twin Cities-based theater company - creates new works striving to engage artists and audiences in critical conversation. With lust for the uncharted and the unknown; we embrace and dissect the familiar. As we celebrate our 10th anniversary, we've turned our focus even more sharply towards female- and queer-centered stories. We believe that theater is a vehicle for important and complex conversations about who we are, how we are, and how we connect with each other. Together is better. Get under the umbrella.

“Ex-Gays is a well-constructed, adroitly paced evening of theater. [...] it’s a conversation—in both comedy and drama—that we’ll all be better off continuing to have. Highly recommended.” - Matthew Everett, TC Daily Planet

 

 

Money Makes The World Go Around

Okay, here's the deal. We need a mere $2,000 to bring this baby into the world. Your contribution of $5 (the price of 1 coffee), $15 (3 coffees), or $500 (lots of coffees!) can help this merry band of queers and allies to have important and engaging conversation through laughter and art. Every dollar raised goes directly to support the following:

  • A talented (and queer-led!) team of artists to create and update this rollicking romp
  • Space rental at the awesomely inclusive and welcoming SpringHouse Ministries
  • A delicious homemade bundt cake (with a glorious hole in the middle!) for each performance! (Don't get the joke? Come see the show to find out!)
  • ASL Interpretation for 6 performances!

There are a lot of things that go into producing an awesome production, but Savage Umbrella puts people first. The largest percentage of any project's budget goes to paying our incredible artists (performers, directors, designers, stage managers, musicians, etc.) for their work.

We've got some awesome perks to thank you for your support including tickets to see the show, tanks & tees, and gratitude galore! We'll even send some tickets to our biggest fan (maybe??), VP Mike Pence, in your name. If you choose a perk level that comes with a shirt, make sure you check out our three options (extra shirts available for your buds at www.SavageUmbrella.org): 

 

 

Why We Need EX-GAYS

Ex-Gays: Not a Str8 Remount is a goofy, zany ride that examines some actually very serious, scary, and real stuff. Conversion therapy (sometimes known as "reparative therapy" or "pray-the-gay-away") is not a myth; it is a controversial, pseudoscientific, and devastating form of psychotherapy that attempts to change a person's sexual orientation from gay to straight.

The American Psychiatric Association opposes this treatment and considers it harmful and unethical. Yet, in 2011, it came to light that Marcus Bachmann - husband of presidential hopeful Michelle Bachmann - ran a Christian counseling clinic (right here in Minnesota) that engaged in these misguided practices. Marcus Bachmann even referred to members of the LGBTQ+ community as "barbarians" that "need to be educated." Dr. Robert Spitzer, one of the most prominent advocates for conversion therapy, actually apologized for his actions and the damage they inflicted in 2012.

Although we have made some incredible strides over the past few years (such as with the Marriage Amendment), rates of suicide are still four times greater for LGBTQ+ youth and nearly 50% of trans people have considered suicide at some point in their lives. Now, in 2017, we are faced with an Administration that is vocally anti-LGTBQ+ (including the recent military bans of trans people) and consistently devalues our bodies, contributions, and relationships. Conversion therapy is not fiction, or something that has happened in the past. It is happening right now, and it is not okay.

Through Ex-Gays: Not a Str8 Remount, Savage Umbrella seeks to shed light on this important conversation by embracing laughter, illuminating absurdity, and celebrating the contributions of LGBTQ+ artists. Plus, we could all just use a laugh every once in a while, right?

Other Ways You Can Help

Strapped for cash, but still want to get involved? Here are some other ways you can support Savage Umbrella and Ex-Gays:

  • Share this campaign on social media!
  • Tell your friends and lovers how excited you are about it!
  • Reserve your tickets to see the show!
  • Volunteer at the Box Office!

 

 

In Closing...

As a small, independent company, we have always relied on the consistent and amazing support of our audiences and artists. Your contributions help us continue to tell vibrant and transformative stories that engage our community in complex conversations. Together really is better, and we're so much better together with you.

xoxo,
The SU Crew

 

Photos by Carl Atiya Swanson

story:
Hello friends and family-

Our youth theater group has been working on 'Into the Woods' since October and we are ready to go on May 16-17 at the awesome Lobero Theater in Santa Barbara; however, we are still trying to raise enough money to pay for the theater, orchestra, costumes, and playbill. We would really appreciate a contribution of any size.

Please help get this show on the stage!!!

I will be 'the Baker' in the 6pm shows on Sat and Sun if you can come!

You can buy tickets at www.lobero.com

Thanks so much!!

xo Frankie Nieman

PS- If you contribute, I will thank you in the PLAYBILL!

We would really appreciate a contribution of any size. Please help get this show on the stage!!! I will be 'the Baker' in the 6pm shows on Sat and Sun if you can come! You can buy tickets at www.lobero.comThanks so much!! xo Frankie NiemanPS- If you contribute, I will thank you in the PLAYBILL!

story:
Help PlayGround Publications publish this year’s anthology of the season’s best scripts by pre-ordering a copy of The Best of PlayGround-San Francisco (2016).

THE BACKSTORY

Since 1994, the mission of PlayGround has been to support the development of new voices for the theatre. For over two decades, PlayGround has been a leading playwright incubator, providing unique opportunities for the cultivation and development of early-career local playwrights and partnerships with leading professional directors, actors, theatres and theatre lovers. Over that time, PlayGround has developed more than 750 original short plays by 200 Bay Area playwrights and premiered 134 of these as part of the Best of PlayGround series. PlayGround has also commissioned 61 new full-length plays (many adapted from the Best of PlayGround shorts) and supported the premiere of 20 of these at theatres in the Bay Area and across the country.

Through the development of original short (and now full-length) plays, PlayGround creates a microcosm of the greater theatre scene, supporting emerging playwrights' experimentation and risk-taking, while helping them hone their style and technique.

PUBLISH OR PERISH

For the past fifteen years, PlayGround Publications has promoted the work of scores of emerging new playwrights and their short plays through the Best of PlayGround series of anthologies.

This month, PlayGround Publications will print two new Best of PlayGround 2016 anthologies. You can help us in this mission by pre-ordering copies of the Los Angeles book through this Indiegogo funding campaign.

The book contains six scripts as performed at this year’s Best of PlayGround Festival, June 2-19, 2016, at San Francisco’s Thick House theatre. These six plays were selected as the best this season from 175 submissions and thirty-six works developed through the Monday Night PlayGround staged reading series.

Each script is printed in its entirety, creating an historical record of the development of these plays, with dates of first reading and premiere, original casting information and playwright biographies.

Proceeds of this funding campaign will be used exclusively to print and distribute the Best of PlayGround-San Francisco anthology.

The Best of PlayGround anthologies:

  • Celebrate the best short plays of the past season;
  • Provide an economical way to bring high-quality audience-tested scripts to the attention of producers and educators;
  • Promote the work of new generations of talented playwrights;
  • Provide students and new dramatists with models of plays that have proven popular with audiences;
  • Creates an historical record of the development of these plays.

This year PlayGround is expanding the role of these books to help move the work of its talented emerging writers from page and into production.

The 2016 San Francisco anthology contains complete scripts of the following plays:

The River God by Madeleine Butler

I'm Really Sorry About This by Patricia Cotter

Ophy's Apothecary by Karen Macklin

Boys Beware by Kirk Shimano

Digging Ditches in Fresno by Isaac Ontiveros

The Lunatics by Josh Williams

CUT TO THE CHASE

By contributing to our campaign, you can pre-order copies of this year’s anthology which will be available beginning June 2, 2016. This frees PlayGround to invest its working capital in developing and producing the best new plays by the Bay Area’s best new playwrights.

In addition to pre-ordering an anthology, if you are able to contribute more, we’ve lined up some swell perks as our way of saying thank you. If you'd like to pre-order multiple copies, please contact us for special rates.

Even though a great deal of in-kind labor is donated to support this publishing project, there’s no avoiding the need for cold, hard cash.

PlayGround Publications will use proceeds of this campaign to:

  • Print the 2016 Best of PlayGround-San Francisco anthology;
  • Acquire ISBN numbers (yes, they cost money);
  • Market the anthologies to producers, educators, drama students, and fans of the theatre;
  • Create and distribute electronic versions of the anthologies.

Please support our campaign and help us jump-start the careers of some exciting new voices in the theatre community. Thank you!

PlayGround Publications is a fiscally-sponsored project of PlayGround (Federal ID 94-3336399). All gifts to this campaign are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law.

story:
The USSR under Nikita Khrushchev and American boy band culture. Two things that don't seem to have much in common. In From Russia, With Love, composer Fernanda Douglas and lyricist Danielle Smith come together to ask, "What if Premier Khrushchev created a Soviet boy band for the purpose of espionage?" Three young Soviets with nothing in common are thrown together for just that purpose, and almost cause nuclear war.

              From Russia, With Love had its first production at Columbia University's Lerner Black Box Theatre in Spring 2016, and the creative team is excited to bring this new short musical to the Midtown International Theatre Festival this August under the direction of Emilia Lirman.

              Please consider making a donation to support this fun and fast-paced show.  Contributions of all sizes are welcome and vital to ensure our production can pay for rehearsal space, props, set pieces, and costumes. This all-female production team is so excited to bring this show to life, but we can't do it without your help, comrade!

             Thank you so much for your interest and support.


Our Team

Producer: Alex Taylor
Director: Emilia Lirman
Composer: Fernanda Douglas
Book and Lyrics: Danielle Smith
Costume Designer: Nell Simon
Music Director: Sofia Geck

Featuring: Patrick Brady, Gabby Bullard, Maria Diez, Skylar Gottlieb, Robert Poole, Zachary Small

story:
Who the heck are we?

We are Malachi Reid and Jonnie Grant, two recent graduates from Edinburgh Napier University with dreams of working in the theatre industry. Malachi is an actor, singer and the writer/director of the show. Jonnie is a musician and the composer/musical director of the show. We bonded as friends after doing shows together for years and then bonded as creative partners when Malachi realised Jonnie was stupid enough not to run away when he suggested a Tenacious D musical. Speaking of... 

What the heck is The Musical Of Destiny?

The Musical of Destiny is a passion project started by Malachi back in 2013. He has been a fan of Tenacious D since first hearing Tribute and has always had a passion for musical theatre. So after re-watching the 2006 movie The Pick of Destiny he thought why not combine the two. However after a few stumbling blocks (Including a water damaged notebook and laptop motherboard setting itself on fire) the project was shelved. Then in 2017 Malachi brought the idea up to Jonnie and he said he was in. The show was alive once more!

So the show itself is a reinterpretation of the story of Tenacious D forming as a band, and journeying to become rock legends as they search for the pick of destiny! Using elements from all their current studio albums and the original film. With new characters and live music this is not just a simple retelling, it is a new live theatre addition to the legacy of the D!

Why the heck are you here?

We're here on IndieGoGo because this isn't a small project that we want to do just for the concept alone. We want to make this show come to life. We are only able to do this show once and we want to build a show that no one would believe could happen and many might not believe could be possible. But not only that we want to reach out to the fans of Tenacious D and new musical theatre and ask for their help, because we believe that a project like this is made for fans, by fans and can be made even better by fans! And hopefully that's you.

OUR CAMPAIGN! 

What the heck we need!

So, now to the least fun part of new theatre...money.
As we said above, we are recent university graduates so money isn't in a great abundance for us to put on this show. Saying that we are not doing this for profit, that's not why we are asking for money. We are asking for money so that this show can be as good as possible for you the backers and fans! However to do that we need to cover some base costs.

Our goal of £2300 is based on the cost of venue hire and fringe registration fees. Once that is covered then all our money goes straight into the show.

Reaching our goal would mean we could start to upgrade the shows costumes, props, set and any extra things that could help grow the experience for the audience

Saying this our goal is flexible, which means that even if we don't reach or full goal all money will still go to us. This money would still​ go towards helping with venue cost and fringe fees. Our goal is to get this show to the fringe and to you! And we will do that even if we have to do it in minimal costume and with cardboard props!

What the heck you get!

So what do you get for contributing to the show?
Well besides our undying love and thanks, plus the satisfaction of helping a plucky young group of musicians. You will get various pieces of show memorabilia and personal connections to the show.

  • With all perks you will receive a personal thank you on our social media page for everyone one to see, but more importantly you well be added to our official backers page when we publish the script. We believe that if you donated, even on the lowest tier, you deserve to be ingrained into the history of this show.
  • On certain tiers you will receive exclusive show merchandise. This includes show posters, badges and T-shirts. This way you will always have a piece of show to remember us by. Plus it'll be the ultimate talking piece at parties.
  • We have also included with certain perks a ticket to the show itself at that this years Edinburgh Fringe (2018). If you helped contribute that amount of money then we want you to come to our show so you can see what you helped create! Plus you will get the best seats in the house, reserved especially for our backers
  • Since this is kind of a ridiculous show we have also included two ridiculous perks. The "DIO" tier and the "BEELZEBOSS" tier. These are there to one, show that we will go that extra mile to make our contributors feel like the awesome people they are for donating money. And two it's a funny addition to our naming scheme.

Why the heck should you care?

Here's where we get emotional. We understand that there are hundreds of projects out there and even more people that deserve this money more than we do. But by donating to this show you're not just helping us put on a show...

You are helping grow the arts industry. You are helping create jobs for young actors, singers, musicians, stage crew, techies, promoters and more. You are helping show the current art community that new young creators CAN make and produce theatre that people want to see if they just have a lil' financial support. You are helping emerging artist show their talents and skills at one of the biggest arts festivals in the world. You are showing that the musical theatre scene in Scotland is hungry and ready to create some new exciting theatre if you give us the chance...

And on a personal level. You are helping make two young men's dream come true. You are helping them see that they can achieve anything with hard work and some help from good people.

RISKS & CHALLENGES!

What the heck have we got to do?

So now we're gonna let you peek behind the curtain of what risks and challenges come from a show like this and how we know you can trust us to overcome them!

  1. Challenge: Creating a new play is very difficult, and a new musical adds the caveat of well...music. Plus we are only getting one shot at it. No do overs or retakes.
    Solution: Malachi graduated with a degree in Acting for Stage and Screen, a course in which he had to write, direct and workshop new writing regularly; and Jonnie graduated with a degree in Music with composition has his main form of study. Making new theatre is their bread and butter! They're use to pulling things off with only one shot.
  2. Challenge: The Fringe is one of the biggest arts festivals in the world with over 53,232 performances of 3,398 shows in 300 venues (stats from 2017). Which means performing isn't the only job. You have to promote and market your show, or it could be left in the dust.
    Solution: Both Malachi and Jonnie have been performing at the fringe for the past 6 years. So they know what the Fringe is like from personal experience. Not only that but they have been part of a range of shows with different companies, so they have experience working in various environments. They have also been apart of new writing before, so know what it's like to hit the pavement and sell, sell, SELL a new show. With all this knowledge and experience they will be able to handle anything the fringe can throw at them!
  3. Challenge: Creating a show based on an already established bands music means that you not only have an obligation to make the show good in general, but you have an obligation to the music and the fans.
    Solution: WE LOVE MUSIC. Malachi and Jonnie are both huge music fans and have many years of experience in performing music. Not only will they be able to make sure that the original spirit of the music and what made it so engaging for fans before will be upheld. They will be able to boost, highlight and showcase these traits even more!

To summarize, we have the ability and drive to win the race. We just need your help to get to the starting line.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP!

What the heck else can you do?

If you aren't able to contribute financially (we totally understand) or wanna help us even more (you rock!) then you can please share our campaign, like us on facebook, follow us on twitter or just tell your friends about us!

story:
Hi! We're Tiny Box Theater: Sarah, Justin and Joy

Last century, we became friends in a black box theater at Drew University. Fast forward to 2015 when Joy was spring cleaning and suggested that two mailboxes from a past installation become small stages for a new project. Sarah coined the company’s name. Justin revealed the magic of magnets. We all took out our scissors and glue guns. And Tiny Box Theater was born.

(Shout out to fellow Drew alum, Aaron Smith, for designing our logo!)

We make theater out of the box inside of a box.

Tiny Box Theater pieces are for tiny audiences, just one or a few at a time, for just a few minutes each. The boxes are portable, repurposed, and interactive. Original storytelling invites the audience to get close and find themselves part of the piece. 

The experience for both audience and performer is one that pushes us to reimagine what stories look and sound like, and to find theatricality in small moments.

Since 2015, we've annually presented Tiny Box Theater pieces at the Figment Festival on Governors Island to joyous audiences...so we decided to go big by going on an international tour!

4 Cities. 3 Countries.
NYC. Boston. Edinburgh. Toronto.

This summer, we're performing our two newest pieces, THE CURIOSITY SHOP and SEED MONEY in outdoor public spaces during festivals. We'll perform over ten different days for several continuous hours each day. We've been working with friendly and enthusiastic curators in each city.

We're not paid to perform and all of our performances are free, but we can pass the hat for donations in Edinburgh (and hopefully earn a few pounds for chips and a pint at the end of the night). 

What We Need. How You Can Help.

We're incredibly grateful for donations of any size. Some amounts come with crafty perks. Please note donations are not tax-deductible.

  • Our $5,000 goal will help us cover the cost of transportation, housing for 2-3 artists per city as well as the materials that go into designing each of the Tiny Box experiences.
  • Sarah received a Don Quixote Fellowship from the Academy for Teachers, which will help cover her housing and travel in Edinburgh. This means that our $5,000 campaign goal will fully cover all remaining expenses.
  • While each of us aren't able to perform in every city, we will be joined by guest collaborators. As two people work the boxes, the third works the line.
  • Once we meet our expenses, any additional funds will go towards developing future projects including a larger, longer work that incorporates 10 boxes.
  • We currently don't pay ourselves or our contributing artists but this is a goal for the near future.

Additional Collaborators

Thank you to these three amazing women and one stand-up guy for sharing their skills and time with us this summer! 

  • Elizabeth Klett - guest actress/voice artist & fellow Drew alum! You can take her voice on tour with you too by checking out one of the audiobooks she narrates.
  • Maeve O'Sullivan - guest operator in Edinburgh & soon taking on our social media. Longtime friends, Joy & Maeve met at the Edinburgh Fringe last century!
  • Grace Trimble -  design & story contributor, guest operator in Boston. Grace & Justin got hitched this past February!
  • Jason Planitzer - photo & video documentation & general helper. Plus he'll be doing stand-up comedy at the Fringe. Jason and Sarah got hitched 8 years ago this August!
  • Angela Pacini - guest operator & greeter in Toronto. Angela is a longtime friend of Maeve's and met both Joy & Sarah in NYC years ago.

Experience Tiny Box Theater for Yourself.

Tour Dates:

  • NYC Figment was June 24. We didn't get our campaign up sooner as we were too busy creating!
  • Figment Festival in Boston July 28 & 29th Starting at 11am each day. Ending at 6pm on Saturday & 4pm on Sunday. See our tour page for more details.
    The Rose Kennedy Greenway: in the square of Atlantic/Pearl/Purchase/Congress.
  • Edinburgh Fringe, August 8-12: 11:00am-5:15pm (with breaks for lunch and snacks!). We'll perform near the corner of High Street and St. Giles Street.
  • Figment Festival in Toronto's Dufferin Park, August 18 & 19: 1-4pm.
  • New addition NYC! Kids Fest: Stages in the Square, September 15: 11:00am-3:00pm. This free event in Madison Square Park is specifically for ages 0-12 and their families. 

Should you feel compelled to donate in person, you can only do so at the Edinburgh Fringe. Figment doesn't permit donations during the event, but they do encourage their artists to fundraise outside of the festival itself.

Share. Follow. Keep in Touch.

  • Please spread the word and share our fundraising campaign.
  • Have connections? We'd love introductions to curators, venues, and festivals for future performances.
  • Experience our process and audience interactions. Follow us on Instagram.
  • Keep up to date with our latest shows & developments. Sign up for our newsletter on our website. 

Thank You!

We truly appreciate your friendship, encouragement, time and $$. We hope you'll interact with one of our boxes in person soon!

Last century, we became friends in a black box theater at Drew University. Fast forward to 2015 when Joy was spring cleaning and suggested that two mailboxes from a past installation become small stages for a new project. Sarah coined the company’s name. Justin revealed the magic of magnets. We all took out our scissors and glue guns. And Tiny Box Theater was born.
(Shout out to fellow Drew alum, Aaron Smith, for designing our logo!)

We make theater out of the box inside of a box.
Tiny Box Theater pieces are for tiny audiences, just one or a few at a time, for just a few minutes each. The boxes are portable, repurposed, and interactive. Original storytelling invites the audience to get close and find themselves part of the piece. 
The experience for both audience and performer is one that pushes us to reimagine what stories look and sound like, and to find theatricality in small moments.
Since 2015, we've annually presented Tiny Box Theater pieces at the Figment Festival on Governors Island to joyous audiences...so we decided to go big by going on an international tour!

4 Cities. 3 Countries.NYC. Boston. Edinburgh. Toronto.
This summer, we're performing our two newest pieces, THE CURIOSITY SHOP and SEED MONEY in outdoor public spaces during festivals. We'll perform over ten different days for several continuous hours each day. We've been working with friendly and enthusiastic curators in each city.We're not paid to perform and all of our performances are free, but we can pass the hat for donations in Edinburgh (and hopefully earn a few pounds for chips and a pint at the end of the night). 
What We Need. How You Can Help.
We're incredibly grateful for donations of any size. Some amounts come with crafty perks. Please note donations are not tax-deductible.

Our $5,000 goal will help us cover the cost of transportation, housing for 2-3 artists per city as well as the materials that go into designing each of the Tiny Box experiences.
Sarah received a Don Quixote Fellowship from the Academy for Teachers, which will help cover her housing and travel in Edinburgh. This means that our $5,000 campaign goal will fully cover all remaining expenses.
While each of us aren't able to perform in every city, we will be joined by guest collaborators. As two people work the boxes, the third works the line.
Once we meet our expenses, any additional funds will go towards developing future projects including a larger, longer work that incorporates 10 boxes.
We currently don't pay ourselves or our contributing artists but this is a goal for the near future.

Additional Collaborators
Thank you to these three amazing women and one stand-up guy for sharing their skills and time with us this summer! 

Elizabeth Klett - guest actress/voice artist & fellow Drew alum! You can take her voice on tour with you too by checking out one of the audiobooks she narrates.
Maeve O'Sullivan - guest operator in Edinburgh & soon taking on our social media. Longtime friends, Joy & Maeve met at the Edinburgh Fringe last century!
Grace Trimble -  design & story contributor, guest operator in Boston. Grace & Justin got hitched this past February!
Jason Planitzer - photo & video documentation & general helper. Plus he'll be doing stand-up comedy at the Fringe. Jason and Sarah got hitched 8 years ago this August!
Angela Pacini - guest operator & greeter in Toronto. Angela is a longtime friend of Maeve's and met both Joy & Sarah in NYC years ago.


Experience Tiny Box Theater for Yourself.
Tour Dates:

NYC Figment was June 24. We didn't get our campaign up sooner as we were too busy creating!

Figment Festival in Boston July 28 & 29th Starting at 11am each day. Ending at 6pm on Saturday & 4pm on Sunday. See our tour page for more details.The Rose Kennedy Greenway: in the square of Atlantic/Pearl/Purchase/Congress.
Edinburgh Fringe, August 8-12: 11:00am-5:15pm (with breaks for lunch and snacks!). We'll perform near the corner of High Street and St. Giles Street.

Figment Festival in Toronto's Dufferin Park, August 18 & 19: 1-4pm.
New addition NYC! Kids Fest: Stages in the Square, September 15: 11:00am-3:00pm. This free event in Madison Square Park is specifically for ages 0-12 and their families. 

Should you feel compelled to donate in person, you can only do so at the Edinburgh Fringe. Figment doesn't permit donations during the event, but they do encourage their artists to fundraise outside of the festival itself.
Share. Follow. Keep in Touch.

Please spread the word and share our fundraising campaign.
Have connections? We'd love introductions to curators, venues, and festivals for future performances.
Experience our process and audience interactions. Follow us on Instagram.
Keep up to date with our latest shows & developments. Sign up for our newsletter on our website. 

Thank You!
We truly appreciate your friendship, encouragement, time and $$. We hope you'll interact with one of our boxes in person soon!

story:
Hi, we're Betsi Freeman, producer, and Havilah Giannetta, director.

  • This show is a comedy intertwining the real-life adventures of several daring, reluctant heroes, designed to make you laugh, cry and question with us whether God knows what He's doing.
How We'll Get There

    • Budget is $2200.
    • We'll be putting on the show on a Saturday night TBD in October, at Eclectic Company Theater in North Hollywood.
    • If you contribute $50 or more, you'll get a free pair of tickets to see the show.

 

We love hearing these stories, and we think you will too. 
Please help us spread the word about this project!

story:
I am the product of teachers, two parents that loved me unconditionally and instilled the values of education in me early on. And with the good fortune of being raised by such wonderful people, along with the inspiration of too many mentors to mention, it is with the utmost excitement that I have set out to fulfill my lifelong desire to teach, to provide a framework for the development of young people through my experiences in both the performing arts and as a mentor myself.

 

My entire professional life has been leading up to this opportunity. As a professional actor for the past twenty years, I’ve performed in nearly 100 plays, written a dozen more, and enjoyed a relatively busy working life in film, television and commercials. I’ve also been fortunate enough to develop another passion in the form of music, working for the past ten years as a professional musician. I spent a year working as the interim drama instructor at Snipes Academy of Arts and Design and seven years as a Big Buddy. I’ve created numerous original plays for Journey Productions and worked with hundreds of young people, fostering a love for performing in them at an early age. Many have gone on to study acting or writing and a few have burgeoning professional careers of their own.

 

I’ve been blessed with an incredible opportunity by my friend Alisa Harris, thank to her spearheading the construction of a new theater space in downtown Wilmington. Operated as a dinner theater space on weekend evenings, TheatreNOW will also serve as the home for Theatre Network of Wilmington, Inc., the non-profit arm of the organization which I will run as Executive Director. Therefore, our space concerns will be non-existent as we already have a home!

 

A home for what, you may ask? TNOW, Inc. will be an after-school theater instruction program, where area students can receive a theater education at low or no cost. For every two students that pay a nominal fee for classes, one student (likely an at-risk, need-based young person) will be provided a scholarship and receive their classes for free. Also, provided negotiations go as expected with the New Hanover Arts Director, I’ll be providing my services free of charge to area schools that don’t offer theatrical instruction. So if you’re as concerned as I am about the lack of arts education provided by our state and local school systems, here’s your chance to support an artist and a program that’s going to make a difference.

 

Essentially, I’m trying to raise initial start up funds to cover advertising efforts, grant processing, office supplies (laptop, printer, ink, paper, etc.), audio visual equipment (inexpensive cameras, music equipment), costumes, masks, art supplies and other miscellaneous items as well as the initial purchase of snacks and drinks for attendees, among other expenses.

 

If we hope to continue having a strong artistic community, we have to begin with the foundation of that community, our youth, and instill a desire and a passion for performance. I begin this journey as one person determined to make a difference, with goals to grow this organization in to a thriving hub of creativity that flourishes and spills over in to all of the wonderful theater companies that call Wilmington home. So curtain up, dim the lights and let’s get going!

story:
Our Story

Red Shark Productions is a new theatre company dedicated to the re-imagination of the classical theater experience for the modern audience.  


White Rabbit Theatre Company is a diverse, multi-ethnic ensemble committed to creating vibrant productions of literate, challenging plays with the intention of guiding audiences through emotional, psychological and spiritual journeys.  


This Spring, we come together to present this powerful & riveting Shakespeare classic tragedy!  


Inspired by 1930's Universal Horror and Film Noir classics, don't miss our extraordinary production of MACBETH including original music, frightening projections, and unique witches to remember. Follow the deadly duo on their dark, spiraling journey through the occult,  transcendental bloodlust and murder… and ultimately…to madness.


March 2011...  "Something wicked this way comes."  


What We Need & What You Get


As we know some of you are not familiar with the theatrical world, there is so much money required for every little aspect of any production.  Just a few expenses involved are theater rental, rehearsal space, insurance expenses, costumes, designer fees, union fees, scenic expenses, and, in our case, many bloody special effects!   For example, $20 can pay for 1 hr of rehearsal space, $100 for 2 costumes, $250 for postcards, and $700 can pay for all of our programs!   Truly, every single dollar helps and is so deeply appreciated!!


Other Ways You Can Help


Join us for our fundraiser event on January 19, 2011 featuring performances by cast and crew! Visit our Facebook Event page for details.   

http://www.facebook.com/event.php?eid=170639552...


Please "Like" us on Facebook and follow our updates!  

http://www.facebook.com/pages/Macbeth2011/13077...


Feel free to re-post this to all other social networking sites - the more who view the better! 


Thank you in advance for your support. We are so very grateful for anything you can do! 


We hope to see you at the show!!

story:
Our Story

Coffee Black Productions was founded to perform plays simply, focusing on the playwright’s intentions without directorial embellishments that distort the playwright’s work.


Since its founding in 2009, Coffee Black Productions has produced over a dozen staged readings throughout New York City of new works by emerging playwrights, creating new and unique challenges for actors and directors, as well as playwrights. Having developed the stage reading to its furthest potential, we are now prepared to produce fully staged works.


KNEE DEEP IN SNOW

A woman looks back on her estranged mother and the friend who tried to help her cope with her mother’s battle with cancer.


What We Need & What You Get

$500.00 will cover the cost of our casting notice, audition & rehearsal space, publicity (posters, postcards and programs), and hopefully additional funds to compensate the actors and director.


Other Ways You Can Help

If donating isn't possible, just come to the show. Your $5.00 admission fee helps future Coffee Black Productions.

story:
Dogfight by Benj Pasek, Justin Paul, and Peter Duchan

Produced by Alex Wolfe, Directed by Dylan Pager 

It's November 21, 1963. Before heading off to serve in the Vietnam War, three young Marines set out to embrace their last night of freedom, youth, and, debauchery. Their evening takes a turn when Corporal Eddie Birdlace meets Rose, an awkward and idealistic waitress who becomes the target of a cruel bet. Unbeknownst to both Eddie and his fellow recruits, Rose rewrites the rules of the game and teaches him the importance of courtesy and compassion.

Performances will be held in Shanley Pavilion at Northwestern University. The dates and times of the performances are:

  • Thursday: 8 PM
  • Friday: 8 and 11 PM
  • Saturday: 2 and 8 PM

Tickets are only $5 for those with a Northwestern ID and $10 for the general public.

Arts Alliance

Arts Alliance is the largest and oldest of the eight theatre boards in StuCo, Northwestern's student theatre coalition. Each board is fully functional and reflects the models of not-for-profit theatre set by Chicago storefront theatres and Off-Off-Broadway theatres in New York. Arts Alliance is a non-profit student arts organization committed to providing diverse, accessible, and fulfilling artistic experiences to enrich the Northwestern University community. Arts Alliance is rooted in its long-standing traditions and continues to seek out new artistic opportunities. It provides a positive atmosphere in which students can learn and work alongside a committed and supportive board to create exciting, professional-quality productions.

Peter Duchan, who wrote the book of Dogfight, is an alumnus of Northwestern University who also directed the Garden Party slot during his time on campus.

The Regiment

Cast: 

Kyle Sherman, Myrna Conn, Chris Anselmo, Justin Tepper, Charlotte Morris, Charlie Oh, Ryan Martin, Nathan Villa, Anne Martin, Caroline Henry, Benton Bailey

Team:

Alex Wolfe, Alex Gold, Caitlin Medina, Dylan Pager, Rachel Leshin, Emma Horvath, Mari Uchida, Noah Teplin, Zoe Nadal, Nikolaj Sorensen, Nick Raef, Dominick Mugavero, Hale McSharry, Dylan Reyno, Gus Berrizbeitia, Matt Kresch, Matt Cassoli, Emily Wills, Emily Blim, Delaney Burlingame, Michael Fagan, Justin Shannin, Mallory Harrington, Becca Ehlers, Taylor Dabbah, Sara Kase, Jessie Klueter, Kyle Hancher, Janie Dickerson, Justin Connolly, Nate Bartlett, Katherine Nagasawa

How Your Donation Helps

With a budget that is over $5,000, we really appreciate even the smallest of donations. We are putting our money towards elements of the show including:

•  Set: There are five distinct locations in this show, and we are featuring them all in our unit set. Different rooms and settings are portrayed by parts of the overall set that are turned around, pulled away, etc.

•  Lights: In order to portray the dynamics of the setting and content of the show, our lighting design includes multiple moving lights that will infuse the space with color and life

•  Costumes: Marines uniforms, 60s diner dresses, and more -- the costumes are vital in the portrayal of setting and mood

•  Publicity: We are trying to attract as wide of an audience as possible, reaching out to student groups at Northwestern, businesses in the town of Evanston, and theatres and businesses around Chicago

Other Ways to Contribute

 You can support our show in a variety of ways:

•  Share the indiegogo link on social networking sites and with family and friends

•  Come see the show! We'd love to have as many people as possible see this incredible work of art. To reserve seats, email alexandrawolfe2016@u.northwestern.edu.


For more information, please visit the StuCo Wiki: http://nustudenttheatre.org/wiki/index.php?titl...

story:
Who We Are

Dancers Over 40, Inc. was created as a not-for-profit organization to provide a community of and a forum for veteran dancers, choreographers and related artists to share common experiences with their peers. The video above features highlights of some of the many panel discussions and performances we have done.  To promote our mission of passing on this cultural legacy to those dancers about to begin their journey, these events are videotaped and archived at the The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. There is no other regional non-profit arts organization that has gone national (via our popular Facebook page: www.facebook.com/dancersover40) to promote the community of seasoned dancers in all its forms, styles and techniques. 

The Project

Ron Field: APPLAUSE!  will be presented at the St. Luke's Theater, 308 W 46th Street, New York, NY on Monday, October 21, 2013 and is the most ambitious program Dancers Over 40 has endeavored to produce to date.  Ron Field, one of the underappreciated director/choreographers of the Golden Age of Musical Theater in the 20th Century, was a disciple of Jack Cole and danced, choreographed and directed many Broadway shows, television specials and movies.  His breakthrough moment was the original Broadway production of CABARET where he won a Tony Award for choreography.  He also won two Tony Awards for direction and choreography of APPLAUSE! starring Lauren Bacall.  His television specials featured star vehicles for Ben Vereen, Liza Minnelli, Mikhail Baryshnikov and Cheryl Ladd.  The Academy Awards and Tony Awards presentations were both graced by his choreography and he was creative force to be reckoned with until his untimely death in 1989.  Many of the theater’s top performers and DO40 members representing Ron Field’s Broadway productions, television specials and movies will be involved in honoring the man and his impressive body of work. Many, many DO40 members worked for Ron in all of these media and now the world gets to hear about his Life and Legacy directly from the sources. 

The hosts for this event will be Broadway veteran Harvey Evans, Ron Field’s assistant Marianne Selbert and Ron Field Dancer and DO40 Board Member Lawrence Merritt. Many of the original cast members of CABARET will be featured in an opening number staged by Marianne Selbert.  Panelists include Broadway gypsies Rita O’Connor, Carol Hanzel and Lee Roy Reams.  The following performers have voiced their support and we are hoping that scheduling will allow them to participate:  Marge Champion, Joel Grey, Sandy Duncan and Don Correia. Ben Vereen, Debbie Allen and Mikhail Baryshnikov have also been approached to participate in some way. In addition, there will be video appearances by Harold Prince and Lauren Bacall.

Where the Money Goes

We are seeking $6,000.00 to fund this event to help cover the costs of transportation, rehearsal space, marketing and publicity materials, stage crew, videographer, equipment, rentals, insurance and other production-associated costs.  To support and continue DO40’s stated mission of preserving the History, Legacy and Lives of our members and to pay it forward to the next generation, our professional videographer will deliver an archival copy of the evening’s event to the Jerome Robbins Dance Collection at the Lincoln Center Library for the Performing Arts.  Past events have honored Bob Fosse, Gower Champion, Jack Cole, Michael Kidd, Peter Gennaro, Agnes de Mille, Gwen Verdon and many more. These panel discussions and others are available for viewing at the Lincoln Center Library.  (Visit our YouTube site, www.youtube.com/dancersover40 to see the evolution of our panels and performances, from rehearsal studios to the Alvin Ailey Citigroup Theater.)

We Need Your Help

All of our projects, from panel discussions to performances, as well as our internet platforms and hard copy newsletters are done on shoestring budgets, funded solely by membership dues and donations. To expand upon these programs and to help take us to the next level, we need your financial assistance so please…

  • Donate! and,
  • Use the sharing tools found under the video to share our campaign with others and encourage them to donate.

 Thank you!

We are seeking $6,000.00 to fund this event to help cover the costs of transportation, rehearsal space, marketing and publicity materials, stage crew, videographer, equipment, rentals, insurance and other production-associated costs.  To support and continue DO40’s stated mission of preserving the History, Legacy and Lives of our members and to pay it forward to the next generation, our professional videographer will deliver an archival copy of the evening’s event to the Jerome Robbins Dance Collection at the Lincoln Center Library for the Performing Arts.  Past events have honored Bob Fosse, Gower Champion, Jack Cole, Michael Kidd, Peter Gennaro, Agnes de Mille, Gwen Verdon and many more. These panel discussions and others are available for viewing at the Lincoln Center Library.  (Visit our YouTube site, www.youtube.com/dancersover40 to see the evolution of our panels and performances, from rehearsal studios to the Alvin Ailey Citigroup Theater.)
We Need Your Help
All of our projects, from panel discussions to performances, as well as our internet platforms and hard copy newsletters are done on shoestring budgets, funded solely by membership dues and donations. To expand upon these programs and to help take us to the next level, we need your financial assistance so please…

Donate! and,
Use the sharing tools found under the video to share our campaign with others and encourage them to donate.

 Thank you!

story:
THE BRICKS THEATRE, Madison WI

It's quite simple when you think of The Bricks Theatre: entertain your audience, take risks, and be the best at what you do. Founded in 2009, our mission has always been to take live performance to new levels, focus on our audience, and deliver a fresh perspective on how good live shows can be. We produce work that will make people think, laugh, sometimes run for the exits, feel, quiver, but above all, be entertained.  

OATESLAND, by local Madison playwright Sam White, delivers an audience experience that is seldom seen on stage. Set in the indiscriminate cold of the antarctic, where three soldiers struggle to stabilize their mental faculties, the story leads us into a world filled with history, mystery, and the residual energy of a long lost explorer. White has written one of the most intriguing plays we have ever read, filled with an atmosphere that will surely have audiences talking for a long time.

We are a small but tenacious group of creative minds, and are constantly searching for new great projects like OATESLAND. Your contributions for this play are as important as every stitch of costume, every bolt, nail, sound effect, and paint stroke. We have assembled a cast and crew of talented local artists that we hope to share with a vast audience. Your financial support means we can reach wider audiences with nuanced marketing, and present a performance of exceptional value. We here at The Bricks are working hard to make OATESLAND a pretty spectacular performance, but we need you to be a part of that creation. 

While there are benefits at each level of giving, please know that even at $10, you instantly become a part of this show, and if you get the opportunity to see it, you will see your ten-dollar bill transform into every aspect of design and production right in front of you. It's that simple, and we hope you join us in presenting this stellar premiere play of OATESLAND by Sam White from April 17-26 at the Bartell Theatre in Madison.

The Bricks Theatre is working to raise $8000 to cover the cost of production including:

  • Designing the antarctic set
  • Costume design
  • Sound design
  • Lighting design
  • Artistic fees
  • Marketing

OATESLAND is an opportunity to explore new boundaries of theatre, and help original work break through the many, many plays in development throughout the world. 

For the last four years The Bricks has stayed true the mission we mentioned above, and now, we are about to kick it into a new gear with your help. 

And please remember, if you can't send a contribution now, you can always lend a hand by sharing this project, and of course, coming to see the show!

Thank you so much!

Forever grateful,

The Bricks

story:
The Dance of the Hours

Outreach. Performance. Collaboration. This is art for the 21st Century

On February 20th, 2016, local dancers and musicians will join together to perform Dance of the Hours, a short ballet composed by Amilicare Ponchielli in which the hours of the day, from dawn to night, are represented by solo and ensemble dances. Once one of the most performed ballets, today it is best known from the satirical dance of animals in Disney's Fantasia.

Northeastern Wisconsin Dance Organization and Civic Symphony of Green Bay are both long standing performing arts organizations in Green Bay. Operating with nominal budgets as separate organizations, NEWDO and CSGB have provided opportunities for local dancers and musicians of all ages in professional level performances. Through The Dance of the Hours, our partnership will allow our dancers and musicians to work together. Performing with a live symphony is an incredible experience for a dancer, and the opportunity is rare even in large communities. Your donation will allow us to purchase costumes, choreography and rehearsal space to make it a reality for your neighbors and friends to participate or attend this special event. 

Support of this partnership will also facilitate joint outreach programs to local organizations, including Salvation Army and the Boys and Girls Club of Green Bay through onsite educational experience. Both organizations believe the arts embrace and celebrate diversity and must be accessible to all members of the community. We intend to continue these collaborations to foster awareness and visibility of the arts for under-served youth so lacking in the Green Bay community. 

Running a non profit arts organization isn't easy these days. Northeastern Wisconsin Dance Organization and Civic Symphony of Green Bay believe that with your help, we can work together to offer stronger, more vibrant performing arts for EVERYONE in the Green Bay community. 

If you can't make a donation, we hope you'll pass this campaign along to your friends and family. 

Even better...come see the concert on February 20th, 2016 at the Meyer Theater!

Best to you, 

The NE Wisconsin Dance Organization

Civic Symphony of Green Bay

Civic Symphony photos courtesy of Sofia Imagery

story:
Currnetly working on obtaining 501c-3 non-profit status.

The Budget
    Performance Space Rental $3,000
    Lighting and Sound Personnel $250
    Insurance $300
    Costumes $400
    Programs $100
    Marketing materials $200
    Rehearsal Space Rental $1,800
    Dancer Compensation $5,200
    Photographer/Videographer $500
    Festival Fees $500
    Contingency $800

    Total             $13,050

The Plan
    December
        -Fund raising initiated
        -Initial choreography development
        -Initial performance venue and marketing strategy plan developed
  

 January

        -Finalize performance venue
        -Continue developing choreography
        -Continuing marketing and fundraising
  

 February
        -Continue developing choreography
        -Continuing marketing and fundraising
    

March
        -Continue developing choreography
        -Begin to finalize marketing and fundraising
        -Book rehearsal space
        -Procure costumes
  

 April
        -Fundraising ends April 10th
        -Begin choreographing on dancers
        -Open rehearsal night mid-April
  

 May
        -Debut performance beginning of May
        -Submit applications for Fall festivals
        -Begin working on potential company residencies and grant opportunities    


Who I Am
I am a New York City native and began my career at 17 with the Richmond Ballet. I then continued on to  BalletMet in Columbus, Ohio where I had the opportunity to dance soloist roles and was co-recipient of the Violetta Boft award.
    In 2009 after three seasons with BalletMet I moved back to New York to dance with the Metropolitan Opera.  Here I have had the opportunity to dance in the several Metropolitan Opera premiers including Rossini’s Armida; as well as the world premier of Enchanted Island.  In addition, I have done extensive freelance work, performing with Neglia Ballet, Neos Dance Theatre, Syracuse City Ballet, and Gleich Dances.  I have also guested with Ballet Yuma, PA Classical Ballet, and Albany Berkshire Ballet.  Additionally, I performed on Broadway at the Shubert Theatre in Brigadoon.
    As an aspiring choreographer I have choreographed a full scale neoclassical work on Ballet Theatre of Maryland and continue to hone my dance arrangement skills with several of the dance companies I have done freelance work with.


My Vision
    After working as a professional ballerina for almost 10 years and being involved in dance my whole life, I want to make a larger impact on the dance world.   I have watched dance evolve through the years, and so often I see and dance roles that have moved so far away from the pureness of what dance really is.  I am immensely moved to create my first season with pieces that are inspired by the root and beauty of ballet with an added edge of original contemporary movement and music.

story:
Dirt (Part 1)

As part of the HERE Summer Sublet Program, Enthuse Theater is proud to present the first part of an ambitious new play, in which the voicelessness of immigrants becomes literal.  The People come from a country no American has heard of, speaking a language no American can hear, and their neighbors look on as a family struggles to adapt itself to the overwhelming strangeness of Chico, California.  But when a father inflicts a terrible punishment on his straying daughter, neighbors and newcomers clash over the limits of tolerance.  Dirt (Part 1) begins an exploration of the links and fissures between culture, love, and violence.

Dirt (Part 1) creates a whole new culture, in all its depth, beauty, and difficulty.  It utilizes the technology of translation (projected words, voice-overs) to conjure poetry out of silence, and finds beauty and sympathy where political rhetoric finds only savagery.

In order to build an entire imagined culture, we require the talents of designers, and the materials to let them realize their visions.  We need the work of dedicated actors.  We need the technology to meet the demands of the work.  And for that, we need help!

Please take a moment to contribute to our fundraising campaign.  You will be helping us realize our vision and make our voices heard, and letting us treat our artists with the respect they deserve for their hard work.  Even if you can't contribute funds, you can help us by letting people know about our show, and encouraging them to buy tickets.  

We look forward to seeing you at our show!

Dirt (Part 1)

August 3 & 4 -- 7PM
August 5 -- 2PM

HERE
145 6th Ave,
(Enter on Dominick, 1 Block South of Spring)

For tickets: visit here.org or call 212-352-3101
Box Office: open after 5pm on show days or 2 hours before any performance

Written by Samara Weiss
Directed by Ashley Kelly Tata

Stage Managed by Christina Franklin
Anshuman Bhatia, Lighting and Scenic Design
John Kemp, Sound Design
Alexandra Regazzoni, Costume Design
Tuce Yasak, Projection Design

Starring:
Sean Michael Chin
Tom Giordano
Nate Grams
Jenna Hoff
Cecilia Lynn-Jacobs
Leemore Malka
Jensen Olaya
Coco Maria Benoit*
Gwenevere Sisco

Hannah Hessel and Becca Poccia, Dramaturgs

*Appears courtesy of Actors' Equity Association.  Equity Approved Showcase

This production is part of the Summer Sublet within HEREstay, HERE's curated rental program, which provides artists with subsidized space and equipment, as well as technical support.

story:
The LA Diner: April 9-13, 2014 The Dairy Center for the Arts Boulder, Colorado

By: Award Winning Writer Jeremy Palmer and Writer/Producer Ed Mills

Directed by: Award Winning Director Erich Toll

Executive Producers: Ed Mills & Bob Wampler

Help fund the World Premier of this play. Audiences will be transported to Hollywood in 1962 when the world's most famous actress was shooting her final movie!

ABOUT THE SHOW

Hi folks, I'm Ed Mills, writer and executive producer of the exciting new play "The LA Diner". Snappy dialogue, fascinating characters and intriguing content with a side of Americana are all served up in this little Diner as Marilyn Monroe is making her final, and ultimately unfinished, film called "Something's Got to Give". Please help us bring this show to the stage and receive our heartfelt thanks and some wonderful perks.

"I read the play and I love it. Very well written and engaging, and as an actor, really exciting to me. It's beautiful. Tears at the end. I was invested in the characters, especially Em and Evie. Love that it memorializes Marilyn without being another show about Marilyn" -- Chelsie, Company Manager for Theatre Aspen

The L.A. Diner tells the story of people dealing with a changing America. Set against the backdrop of 1960s Hollywood, the denizens of the L.A. Diner literally live and work in the shadow of the 20th Century Fox Studio lot where they see some of the day's most famous faces and cater to the crews and screenwriters that really make the magic happen. These people; two chefs - one black and one white, an aging hostess, a waitress/aspiring actress, a gossip reporter, a stand in for a top screen icon, and a formerly blacklisted writer - learn who they really are as a result of how they react to the changing culture of Hollywood and America during one of the most tumultuous times either has experienced. With original music by Jon Stubbs, Arlene & Russell Kortright and The David Klein Quintet.

"I love your CD 'My Marilyn' and know Marilyn would have gotten a big kick out of hearing it (Maybe she still does)." -- Jane Russell

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

Our goal is to raise $3,600 to help with production costs: theater rental at The Dairy Center for the Arts, music, scenic design, lighting design, costumes, set building, marketing/publicity and printing. Our goal is to engage our audience in a unique and creative theater experience. With your help this World Premier will be just the first of many stagings of The LA Diner.

With extreme gratitude we are offering an array of perks as thank you for your support. Everything from show tickets, official The LA Diner Coffee Mugs, My Marilyn CD's, custom designed The LA Diner T shirts to Producer status and credit. But first and foremost our sincere thanks along with the warm, fuzzy feeling you get for supporting local theater and helping bring this World Premier to the stage.

Other Ways You Can Help

*If you can't make it to a performance but still want to contribute we will donate your ticket(s) to a student, senior or person in need.

*Connect with us on Facebook.

*Spread the word about our campaign.

HIT SONGS OF 1962

I Can't Stop Loving You, Ray Charles
Hey! Baby, Bruce Channel
Breakin' Up is Hard to Do, Neil Sedaka
Sheila, Tommy Roe
The Loco-Motion, Little Eva
Return to Sender, Elvis Presley
Twistin' the Night Away, Sam Cooke

OUR TEAM

Ed Mills – Writer

Jeremy Palmer – Writer

Erich Toll – Director

Danice Crawford – Publicity/Marketing

story:
This is a theatre production you don’t want to miss. This show will be one to remember, filled with drama, music and suspense. It is a must see. Prepare to have a different outlook on “what are friends for”.

Antonio is an up and coming party promoter who is trying to get his big break as a concert promoter by throwing a lot of parties. Antonio thinks that if he throws enough successful parties, he will be able to get his start as the next big concert promoter.

Antonio finds himself in a jam. How are you going to throw a really big concert with no cash? Well the drama starts, Antonio finds out who his friends really are. Between Antonio’s roommates, his two brothers Kevin and Raymond. His brother Raymond who is an up coming rapper an also the ladies man has all kinds of drama in his life. His other roommate Romeo is trying to get his big break in the modeling business, but while living with Antonio he has been having strong feelings for their other roommate Terri. The only problem is Romeo has a really jealous girlfriend that thinks he’s cheating on her all the time.

With all that going on in one house do you think they would have the time or be enthusiastic enough to help out their roommate Antonio? Plus Antonio is having problems with his own girlfriend Tina who wants only to spend his money. With all this taking place and time running out, and little hope of finding the money for the concert. Antonio finds he has to turn to the wrong friends for help and those friends you want to stay far away from …….think again!

At the end of this production Antonio has a new outlook on “What are Friends For” and what they really mean to him!

I am here on Indiegogo to ask for your help and pledges to take this stageplay production on tour to the Williamsburg Players Theatre in Williamburg, VA. This is a production in which I wrote and directed called “What Are Friends For” The funds raised here on Indiegogo will be used to rent out the venue, charter the bus, hotel accommodation, set design and advertisement.

I am asking for your pledge in the amount a $1 on up, with your help and the support of Indiegogo we will be able to take this production to the next level. So I am looking forward to meeting you all at the stageplay of “What Are Friends For” in Williamsburg, VA.

So I am looking forward to meeting you all at the stageplay of “What Are Friends For” in Williamsburg, VA.

story:
Short Summary

Once upon a time a Texas Girl wrote an original TV sitcom pilot because she had an idea to help change the face of Television... (no small feat)  and bring more laughter into the World.

Paramount said 'we'll pass" - which was the BEST thing that ever happened!  Because as good as anything on TV at the time... it really wasn't 'me'.  

Cut To:  Sometime A Few Years Later... (ok, a LOT of years later)

I remembered reading the bio for I Love Lucy, that she and Desi were already on the brink of their relationship end, William Frawley was usually drunk and that Lucy and Vivian Vance were constantly at tug-of-war in ego-land.  (Vivian was forced to gain weight so she would look 'old')    "WHAT a great idea for a behind-the-scenes script?!", I said to myself, I said.  And, the new version of TILL THERE WAS YOU ... was born.

People kept saying it would make a great play.  OK, I give in!  So, the

  Fertile Ground Festival for new works seemed like the perfect place to put it on its feet before a live audience. (Yay)  

Presents:  Till There Was You, Feb 1st @ 2PM
368 S. State Street, Lake Oswego, OR 97034  (503) 635-3901

WHAT'S THE STORY ABOUT?

Glittering Broadway and radio stars Frank and Annie O'Connor are up to their eyeballsin the three-ring-circus of a brand new thing called...LIVE Television. 

It is 1957 and Frank has spent their life savings at the track. The Mob wants to see the fat lady sing. Their very public, and all too frequently dramatic, "All-American" 20-year marriage is suddenly on the rocks with a relationship scandal only a day before Till There Was You airs. 

The LAST thing they want to do is a show — together! 

The ONLY thing they can do ... is a show together. 

Harking back to the day of the classic Screwball Comedy days of Cary Grant and Kate Hepburn, Rosalind Russell, Jimmy Stewart —an homage to that art as this in-the-trenches peek into show biz. 

AWARDS: 

 

*  Semi-Finalist in the National TV Comedy Pilot Division for SCRIPTAPALOOZA
*  Quarter-Finalist in the National NexTV Competition for TV in Hollywood

FUNDING Provided By Your Gracious Help  * * *
Will help this project onto the Phase 2 stage by helping to create a Video of the show for pitching purposes and get it to Producers and Development Executives.

(Please Note:  None of this funding goes to the Lakewood Theatre, they are a non-profit organization and have their own funding.)

What We Need & What You Get

The $1800 we are intending for at this level provides:

*  A Toothpaste Tube Costume  (now you just gotta see the show, right?)  

*  Video Shooting, Editing & Copying onto DVDs for Future Pitches
*  Photography of Rehearsals for future PR & Printing of Photos
*  Graphic Design & Printing of 2,000+ Flyers & PR
*  Invitations to Local Media, Theatre Directors, Development Directors Plus Mailing
*  Travel Expenses for Out-of-Town Participants in the Show
*  Google, Twitter & Facebook Ad Campaigns
*  Thank You Notes for Sponsors, Participants, etc... & Mailing of
*  Office Supplies like extra binders, xerox paper, pens, pencils, highlighters
*  Price of our Sheet Music
*  Incorporation Costs for the Production Company JEM Enterprises
*  Travel Expenses to NY and LA to Pitch the Show
*  Stipends for Office Assistance and PAs

*  Annnddd - Misc. Costumes & Props - oh, like cans of crab- 

and a working 50's flashbulb camera ... (really curious now?)

What will happen after the show is over?  Your gracious donations will go to:
      PR Packet Design & Preparation for Pitching the Show complete with video to go to Equity Theatres in the NWest, LA and NY as well as Television Producers.  We will be targeting places like Seattle Rep, Artists Repertory Theatre & PCS in Portland, Playwrights Horizon in NY, The Geffen in LA and Pasadena Playhouse, Mel Brooks, Billy Crystal and others who love comedy.

AS WE RAISE MORE $$$ OVER OUR GOAL?

We will actually contribute 25% of funds over our goal to:  SLAMNYC.org  
That's Emmy-winning Actress, NY Times Bestseller for GUTS & Star of The Exes,

Kristen Johnston's philanthropic site that is working passionately to raise money for the 1st Sober High School in Manhattan.

You will be a part of helping Teens embrace their sobriety and recovery!  Now, that's a cause worth sharing money with, right?

The Impact

BE AT THE LIFT OFF!
You will be an integral part of the foundation!  You can say, "I knew it when..." and know you helped make some powerful theatrical history happen.  You can get in on a historic moment

(maybe even get a T-shirt all your friends will envy... it could happen!)  Even, perhaps be at the beginning of what becomes a successful TV show.  You will have a piece of Entertainment History in your pocket and the pride of knowing what you did made it possible.

SOooo, Why Is This Valuable in the World?
Well, when is more laughter - not needed and wanted in these times?!  

Do you know it actually CHANGES the neurology in your brain to a better one?
I remember in some of my most difficult times in life, I would turn to comedy.  To put on PHILADELPHIA STORY and never fail to laugh. Watch classic shows like Dyke Van Dyke from the 60's. I watched Eddie Izzard when I was recovering in the hospital several years ago and wow, did the "Do You Have A Flag" bit make a difference.  I smile every time I think about "pretty, pretty, pretty goood" from the pen of Larry David.  Laughter, truly is a miraculous medicine.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Would You Like to Help, But Maybe It Can't Be Dollars?

That's okay - be a great steward of comedy and this project by just:

1.  Sending the page link here to family and friends to help rally others
2.  Use the Indiegogo share tools to send it out over Facebook and Twitter
3.  Write us at dreamwithjulie at gmail and ask for other ways you can help, particularly if you are in Portland.  We have a Wish List for moving forward!

story:
Short Summary

"The Great Guggelhoff Robbery" is the first in our series of musicals, to be developed in Toronto for Toronto, Broadway, and the world.

With a vastly-experienced cast and crew, we intend to produce a high-quality theatrical experience for audience and talent, and build new material into the very best of entertainment.

 Take a look at www.thegreatgugelhupfrobbery.com/ for our most in-depth details.

In Alpendorf, the village we call home, change comes slowly… the days and years go by, the way they always have. Except for one day when I was young; the day the Barinski brothers came…
Our story takes place about 150 years ago in the tiny, remote mountain village of Alpendorf in the Tyrol. It is festival time and all the villagers and visitors are decked out in their best Tirolean finery with the exception of the Russians who are clothed in dark, hooded cloaks and travelling garb.
