story:
Hello!

My name is Jennifer Gwirtz and I direct Right Brain Performancelab, a collaborative troupe specializing in hybrid performance located in San Francisco. Since 1999 we have brought our unique dance-theater to venues, public spaces and alternative sites, and founded a performance salon in our own apartment. 2013 is our 10th Anniversary Season and we are thrilled to be able to share it with you.

We have experimented with alternative spaces since almost our founding. Our very first show, "Not A Step," was created to fit into our friend's Auckland, NZ living room. We have performed in theaters, galleries, up and down Valencia Street, in Golden Gate Park's AIDS Memorial Grove and perched on ruined walls at the Sutro Baths. We have played with the audience-performer relationship by dancing for surveillance cameras over bank machines in the Financial District during the winter holiday rush, and have performed undercover in crowds at art openings. This year's project is the culmination of these ideas about space, place and point of view.

"What Stays" is a touring home-theater extravaganza that will take place from October 18 through November 9 in three private home-theater venues in the Bay Area. It features the tremendous talents of physical performer John Baumann, musical theaterist and dancer Lisa Claybaugh, dancers Laura Marsh and Jennifer Minore and David Samas, musician and instrument inventor who will play live at the event with guest musicians each weekend. I will be performing with the ensemble and there will also be some brand new songs by composer Dave Rodgers. The show takes the form of a performance installation in which the audience can walk through the house to different rooms, hallways and nooks to discover the different sections of the piece. Our brilliant lighting designer, Allen Willner, has been dreaming up transformations using everyday lamps, strings of lights and flashlights.

This project is especially important not only because it is our tenth season, or because it breaks new ground in how space is used and inhabited by theater and dance, but also for its timely and intriguing theme. The piece interweaves ideas about “home” and “time,” exploring how homes are inhabited and cherished in a region where housing is a complex issue.  According to SFist, average July rents for a one-bedroom apartment in San Francisco cost $2,800. SFGate wrote that the average home price in San Francisco topped $1 million in June. For many Bay Area people, home, whether it is rented or owned, is a major part of their budget and their lives. Living spaces loom large in our imaginations and realities. This deep well of metaphor is where we now dip our creative ladle.

The three homes that will be hosting “What Stays” are wonderful, warm spaces with lovely hosts who have generously opened their homes to us and our audiences for this event. Each home is in a different region. The first, called The First Avenue Salon, is in Half Moon Bay. Jane and Ed Hanson purchased the land and built their house in such a way as to be close to the ocean that Jane, a lifelong scuba-diver and a registered nurse who helped to rescue seals for much of her adult life, loved so much. The second, Turquoise Yantra Grotto, is in the Diamond Heights neighborhood of San Francisco, the home of David Samas, Grace Renaud and their four children. David’s grandparents built the house in the 1960s. David returned to raise his children and transformed the home into an alternative theater for new music and performance. The final home, Chez 360, is in the Lake Merritt neighborhood of Oakland, the home of Jennifer Minore and John Hayes. They bought the house after many years of living in a tiny junior one bedroom garden apartment in the same neighborhood.

Over the past few months we've rehearsed in all of the amazing venues where we plan to perform. We have mapped each space, danced in its planes and valleys, and sung so that our voices found the nooks between the rafters. We have read the spines of beloved books, walked backwards on treadmills, climbed up to the roof, played with puppies, talked and squawked with pet birds, stayed out of the most private spaces and folded the hand towel after using it. We have discovered places where our character creations can play, figured out where audience members will be most comfortable and other ways to express the terrain that we have explored.

More importantly, we have listened. We met partners, children and grandparents, each of whom carry stories that live in each space. They have shared their tales and dreams in and about their spaces...the loneliness of a house for family that is far away, the multifaceted chaos of many children and the echoes of ancestors, the love of the nearby Pacific Ocean and its seals as a shared dream by two people who love each other.

Our virtual partner in London, Apryl Renee Pipe, has met each host while in her home on another continent, bridging over five thousand miles and shortening the distance to the small span between two sets of eyes and each voice, aided by technology.

What we need...

What we are attempting is difficult - three entirely different shows that bring alive the metaphorical realities of each space. While we are not renting the venues we are investing deeply in the people who are making this happen, performers, designers, hosts. Think about it...three shows, three weekends, three sites. Three load-ins, three tech rehearsals, three opening nights. All of these require more travel and more child care. These commitments are in addition to our regular studio rehearsals. Last, but not least, Allen Willner will be building a portable light and effects kit that will have to be set up differently for each home-theater space.

Here are the details.

We have budgeted $800.00 for each of our three regular performers for a total of $2,400.00. Our London collaborator will receive $500.00.
The lighting designer, Allen Willner, will earn $1,750.00.
These salaries, totaling $4,350.00, are due by the first performance on October 18th.

Here is what we are proposing.

Our initial goal is $2,100.00 to first pay our three performers, Lisa Claybaugh, Laura Marsh and Jennifer Minore - beautiful and professional artists all. They have been performing with us for the last decade, attending rehearsals at least once a week for most of the year. Lisa and Laura are both mothers of small children. Lisa is also expecting her second child soon after our show closes. While we are aware that their time and effort cost much more than what we have budgeted, this is what we can do this year. We are so lucky to have them as co-conspirators and would be incredibly thankful to be able to raise the proposed funds to pay them. If we can make our initial goal this year, it will be a first step towards paying them something close to a living wage in years to come.

If we can raise $500 more, that will go to Apryl Renee Pipe, who has doggedly attended rehearsals once and sometimes twice a week over video-conferencing from London for the last few months and will be performing with us at 4:00am GMT each weekend in full makeup and costume. Wow.

We are also spending extra on Allen’s lighting work this year because of the unusual circumstances and extra travel on his part while he and his wife juggle the commitments of jobs and their newborn son. Therefore, anything above and beyond the first $2,800.00 will go towards Allen's salary.

We have some great perks, too.

We're giving away great stuff - VIP tickets (only available through this Indiegogo campaign!), a gluten-free recipe booklet made up of recipes served as snacks at our past home-theater shows, a valuable retrospective photo book and our iconic company tee shirts. So that you can get a better idea, here is a picture of the shirt. It comes in women's or men's fitted medium, large and extra large sizes. We can do kids sizes, too.

  • Here's amazing photographer and friend of RBP, Lance Huntley looking awfully cool in his RBP tee.

The Impact

This show is a multifaceted look at living in the Bay Area and in the U.S. in general. It is about the poetics of politics, a revised American Dream, how we live and raise our families. It is a metaphorical pairing of internal dreams and external realities, at least for three homes and their inhabitants. There are many more stories to tell that we can't encompass here...but it is a beginning. See below for how you can help to write the story of how we live now.

While we have a long track record of using alternative sites and home-theaters to make work, “What Stays” is a giant step for Right Brain Performancelab as we take a leap into producing a full season in alternative venues, mapping out new ways to make work, to get to know our Bay Area cities and towns and our neighbors.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t afford to donate money, there are ways that you can help.

  • Please get the word out and make some noise for us. We have a Facebook page and we are @rightbrainplab on Twitter. We even have a special hashtag for the occasion: #WhatStays. Our regular web site has lots of fun stuff on it at http://performancelab.org. There are also Indiegogo share tools. Spread it around and let folks know.
  • We would love to hear your stories about your living space (or lack of one) and what it means to you. We would then share and/or retweet your musings (with your permission, of course). This is for everyone, not just folks in the Bay Area. 
  • We are also interested in taking this show around to other homes and apartments as a sort of extended tour. If you know of someone who might be interested in hosting “What Stays,” please lead them to our page!

Other Ways You Can HelpEven if you can’t afford to donate money, there are ways that you can help. 
Please get the word out and make some noise for us. We have a Facebook page and we are @rightbrainplab on Twitter. We even have a special hashtag for the occasion: #WhatStays. Our regular web site has lots of fun stuff on it at http://performancelab.org. There are also Indiegogo share tools. Spread it around and let folks know.
We would love to hear your stories about your living space (or lack of one) and what it means to you. We would then share and/or retweet your musings (with your permission, of course). This is for everyone, not just folks in the Bay Area. 
We are also interested in taking this show around to other homes and apartments as a sort of extended tour. If you know of someone who might be interested in hosting “What Stays,” please lead them to our page!

story:
Gotta Van Productions is a not-for-profit  independent theater company dedicated to the development and presentation of the solo play with a purpose.

2012 Award winners Ann Morrison and Blake Walton return home to the 2013 United Solo Theatre Festival to premiere 2 new solo plays!

We need your help.

Both of our new plays are selections of the 2013 United Solo Festival on Theater Row in New York City. Leading Men will play October 13th at 7:30 pm and Word Painting will play November 10th at 4:00 pm. We are required to produce BOTH plays. Therefore, we are looking for your support to make this happen.

What your donation will do? Your support will help us to produce TWO plays at the United Solo Theatre Festival in New York, offsetting the cost of:

*  Festival Fees

*  Travel (Annie to NY, Blake to FL)

*  Technical Assistance

*  Publicity

*  Production Costs: Set, Costumes, Props, Projector

Thank You, Thank You, Thank You, in advance for your support!


About the plays:

Blake Walton tells the truth in his poignant and funny evolution to manhood as he and his father find an understanding and acceptance of, and finally a profound admiration for each other after he becomes a father himself. “One cannot be what one is naturally, born to be, at the core, not. It ain’t something that comes and goes. It is in the atoms of our being, it is something essential.”

2012 United Solo Best Premiere Award Winner.

Director: Ann Morrison. Company Manager: David Coyle.


Inspired by her own experience as a model for art students, Broadway veteran Ann Morrison takes a profound look at her late mother, an artist and true "Renaissance Woman", through the personalities around an art easel: the Model, the Student Artist, the Critic and the Art itself, leading her audience through a poetic, lyrical dance.

2012 United Solo Best Actress Award Winner.

Director: Blake Walton. Choreography Consultant: Garfield Lemonius. Artwork Created By: Karle H. Murdock. Company Manager: David Coyle.


Who we are:

ANN MORRISON a director, writer and professional theater actress for over 35years, was honored with the “Best Actress” Award for her performance in her play Linda Lovely Goes To Broadway at the 2012 United Solo Festival in New York. Ann has starred on Broadway in Lovemusik and Merrily We Roll Along (1982 Theatre World Award), London’s West End in Peg, Off Broadway in Forbidden Broadway and  Goblin Market (Drama Desk Award Nomination). In Regional Theaters across the country she played major musical theater roles from Peter Pan and Sally Bowles to Norma Desmond, and starred in musical versions of Shakespeare as Titania/Hippolyta in A Midsummer Night’s Dream, Rosaline in Love’s Labour’s Lost and Feste in Twelfth Night. Her cabaret acts have filled rooms throughout the U.S., most recently at 54 Below in New York and she is featured on over a dozen recordings. On TV she starred in an original musical Keystone for NJ Public Television as well as appearing on Night Court and singing on both Merv! and Dinah and Friends. She stars in the short Indie film See Rock City and has completed interviews as herself for Our Time: A Documentary About Growing Up, which charts the lives of the original Merrily We Roll Along Broadway cast. Directing credits include: her solo play Trevor’s Fire performed by Blake Walton for the 2012 United Solo Festival and the musicals The Secret Garden, On A Clear Day, Merrily We Roll Along, Smoke On The Mountain and Hair. She was Creator and Artistic Director for KALEIDOSCOPE and RANDOM PLAY, theater programs for persons with intellectual disabilities. She wrote the “Living Room Theater” pieces Aimee and The Xymox and A Grail Knight Named Christopher, and solo plays Discourse of A Maid, Movements of A Modron, Annie’s Celtic Kitchen, Out of A Three-Legged Pot as well as Linda Lovely Goes To Broadway and Trevor’s Fire both of which are published through indietheatrenow.com. More info at: http://www.annmorrison.net

BLAKE WALTON most recently performed Ann Morrison’s solo play Trevor’s Fire to sold out houses at the 2012 United Solo Festival for which he was honored with the “Best Premiere” Award. A sold out three-night stint followed in February at Home Resource in Sarasota, Florida. Since returning to New York, he has played Felix in My Three Angels (Hampton Theater Company) and Elfin/Father Duncan in Jon Spano’s Family Comes First (Emerging Artists’ EAT Fest). As a young actor he moved to New York to study at the Neighborhood Playhouse with Bill Esper and Sanford Meisner, then originated roles in Ham, Songs and Ceremonies, Rain Kisses and "Mark" in the historic, ground-breaking production of Doric Wilson’s The West Street Gang. In Regional Theater he has starred in the musicals Into The Woods, Sweeny Todd, Stop The World I Want To Get Off, Anything Goes, A Funny Thing Happened On the Way To The Forum, I Do, I Do! (Sarasota Magazine Award), City Of Angels and plays Jeffrey, Snakebit, Kiss of The Spider Woman, Dirty Blonde, The Sum Of Us, Don’t Dress For Dinner, and as Bette Davis at 77 in Me & Jezebel (SAMMY Award). His directing credits include Singin’ In The Rain, Big River, Babes In Arms, You’re A Good Man Charlie Brown, 42nd Street, Marvin’s Room,  Jest A Second and most recently Ann Morrison in her solo play Linda Lovely Goes To Broadway for the 2012 United Solo Festival and Jeffrey Helgeson’s In The Moment for Variations Theater Group. Also in New York he directed Amy Whitman’s solo performance piece Malibu Mornings for The Farrington Company and created, wrote, directed and edited the web series The misAdventures of Wendell Burke. In Chicago he directed his play Out Of My Mind for the Bailiwick and a staged concert of son Huck Walton’s musical The Charm at The Theater Building. He has taught play writing and many levels of acting as well as coached acting privately. More info at: http://www.blakewalton.net

History of the plays: 

After a very successful debut with sold out houses for both Ann Morrison and Blake Walton in the 2012 United Solo Theatre festival, winning awards for both plays and being welcomed as members of the Solo Academy, they were invited back to do encore performances for the 2013 Festival either repeating the plays they performed in 2012 or introducing new works, which is the option they chose.

Blake as a playwright had never written a solo play but had some ideas for an original autobiographical piece stewing in his head over the course of the past year. Once he opened the floodgates, the words came charging out until he had a 70 minute narrative monologue. Ann had also been harvesting ideas for a new play and she too found the words came easily. There was a parallel in their separate processes in that they thought they were writing about one thing and the journey took them to a perspective they were not expecting.

Ann began to discover she was revisiting her mother in a profound way, as an art student in 1942, a painter, dancer, poet, lyricist, playwright, and director. Her play was now incorporating dance and poetry at times to tell the story as well. Word Painting: Soliloquies Around An Easel became a loving tribute to her creative role model, her mother as a Renaissance woman.

Blake thought he was only writing about what it is to be a “real man” in this society, but as he began filtering his definition through stories about his father, his own fatherhood and stories of his son, he found a demonstration of “manhood” through “fatherhood” and his own evolution into an adult son. His surprise came with the tremendous empowerment he experienced through the honest telling in Leading Men, a tale that had not been voiced before, of the road he has taken with these two most influential men in his life.

Blake and Ann have a vital working relationship and as they have in the past, they will each direct the other’s play. There are plans to present both plays as a pre-festival workshop showcase at Home  Resource, a venue in Sarasota, Florida, specializing in Indie and Fringe Theatre. David Coyle joined them as they formed the company GOTTA VAN PRODUCTIONS, with the purpose of developing more solo plays, performances and workshops and bringing them to various venues around the country.

Future: 

We would like to further the life of all of our solo plays with productions and tours. We are passionate about helping others find their unique voices and sharing their own stories through writing and performance. We see in others and know from our own work that it takes a great courage and willingness to be vulnerable and tell the stories of ones life, but the process can be profound. Therefore we have created Workshops and Master Classes to nurture this growth. These workshops and classes might be done in conjunction with or separate from performances.

Fractured Atlas:

Gotta Van Productions is now sponsored by Fractured Atlas. Contributions for the purposes of Gotta Van Productions must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. Go to our GOTTA VAN PRODUCTIONS page at Fractures Atlas to find out more: https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/profile?id=9099

story:
The 411

We are 4 artists and friends that met at The University of Texas at Austin. After graduating, we moved to Los Angeles in search of perpetual sun and screen time.  We created the Mixtape Theatre Company to do work that challenges us and moves, inspires and provokes our audiences. We are premiering our first project, a new play for the Hollywood Fringe Festival in June 2013. Come join us and be a part of making art! Feel free to visit our website www.mixtapetheatre.com to learn more about us.  Don't hesitate to contact us with any questions, comments or if you want to discuss anything under the sun.

What We Need & What You Get

Our expenses:

Space. Not the final frontier this time.  We have several performances throughout the festival along with tech rehearsal in the venue.  

Advertising. Postcards to posters and everything else you can imagine.  We don't want to answer the question "if a play happens in the woods and no one is around to see it, does it make a sound?"

Registration Fees and Insurance for the festival.  Yawn.

Flights.  Our writer lives in Louisville.  Our director in Austin.  If they start walking now they still wouldn't make it in time.  

In all likelihood there may be expenses beyond the $3000.  Every little bit helps.  Thanks in advance!

We have some amazing perks:

- Pre-sale Tickets

- T-Shirts (coming soon)

- Signed Posters (coming soon)

- Dr. Propescu's 10 step pocket guide to finding Your Authentic Self (coming soon)

- and the all too fun Double Dare section...we will take the physical challenge!!

Not all the perks are active yet, check back soon for pictures and more details!

The Impact

We believe that art teaches us how to live, live better and connect with each other on a deeply human level.

Los Angeles is like no other city in the world.  It is the home of so many diverse people, cultures and ways of living. What better way to create community and explore the humanity in us all than theatre?

We need that real life connection now more than ever in the digital world. Please be a part of this journey and make it possible.  Did I mention there will be laughs on the way? Lots of them :) So come explore "Your Authentic Self" and make art with us.

Ways You Can Help

Thank you for your contribution. We could not do this without your support! 

If you cannot help financially, your voice is a wonderful gift!  Please help us spread the word about our campaign and project! Feel free to post on Facebook, Twitter, and email friends about this wonderful adventure! 

We hope to see you at the Hollywood Fringe Festival!

story:
We are Launching Part Two of our Season 12 Fundraising Campaign!

Our Original Campaign Goal was $10,000 and in just 21 days we hit half of our goal! Which is amazing and wonderful! We have raised funds to cover the cost of our Fall Repertory Venue, but we still have a long way to go! 
But we still need to raise another $5,000 to keep our season going!

3 Productions this fall and 3 more next spring! We have a ambitious goal and know with your help we can make it happen! 

This fall Rising Sun Performance Company hits a significant landmark in our history, one that few indie theatre companies in NYC will ever reach. We celebrate 12 years of making our signature raw, evocative, engaging and authentic theatrical experiences.

As we embark on Season 12, we put an emphasis on new works created from within the ensemble, including  The world premiere of Ice Age from resident playwright Mike Aguirre, Original Devised work that we will present as guests at festivals and special events, a return to the work in progress “Henry’s Wives” along with two revivals of published works: Brilliant Traces by Cindy Lou Johnson and the Remount of RSP’s inaugural production Hellcab by Will Kern. The next 4 months promises to be filled with many exciting moments on and off stage featuring the work of our talented ensemble, playwrights, directors  and an immensely talented design and support team.  Our Fall/Winter Season will run from October 30th thru December 20th.  

We have existed this long by working in the most cost effective and innovative ways possible. By the grace of donors and grants, donated space, in kind costumes, and with the exceptionally hard work of a 100% volunteer run staff and ensemble we have presented over 55 productions & events.  However, as cost effective as we run our company, we still need a significant amount of funding in order to function as a viable company in NYC. 

IN ORDER FOR SEASON 12 TO HAPPEN, 
WE MUST RAISE an additional $5,000 WITHIN THE NEXT MONTH

What we have in place:
Exciting New Works By Talented Playwrights
Killer Innovative Designers
Top Notch Directors
Breathtaking Actors
Stellar Stage Managers
& Wonderful Spaces to Rehearse in 

Here is the short list of what we need to accomplish our 12th season
$5,000 for our fall Rep Venue <<< RAISED! ACCOMPLISHED

We still need this:
$1,200 for our Hellcab Venue
$1,600 for Royalty Rights for Brilliant Traces & Hellcab
$1,950 for Festival Fees for Henry’s Wives, Ice Age & Erik (If accepted into festivals) 
$3,500 to pay our 3 Stage Managers, Publicist & Designers
$2,000 for our Set, Props & Costumes
$1,500 for rehearsal space
$700 for Postcards & Posters 
$500 for Liability & Event Insurance 
$1,000 for sound, lighting & Audio Visual technology

Be a part of our collective history and give Season 12 a chance to succeed! Donate today!

After the success of last year’s Hotel Suite, we look to return to a non-traditional venue to provide our audiences with an up-close and unforgettable theatrical experience. 

So, almost all of the pieces have fallen into place – we have an amazing group of directors, playwrights, actors and collaborators. THIS IS the team to make our season happen, BUT WE NEED YOUR HELP to get there!  We are in negotiations with a great venue, but we need to pay for the space in order to move forward! 

Here is where you get to be a part of the show!  Every donation goes a long way to making this season and our future seasons a reality. AND with ongoing updates on this campaign, fun hands on perks including backstage access, walk on roles and meet & greet opportunities, we make sure that you aren’t just in the audience but in on the action.

DONATIONS WILL UNLOCK UPDATES AND CHALLENGES FOR CHANCES TO WIN PRIZES

Help us continue our legacy of bold, exciting and uncompromising theatre just for you.

See the sidebar for the AWESOME PERKS starting with just a $10 DONATION!

The most important element besides the cool perks is the impact of having your money support local independent theatre in a very real way. You could be a direct part of an exciting theatrical event and a leader in supporting art on a grassroots level.

Rising Sun Performance Company is a vital part of the Off-Off Broadway landscape; being one of the longest running ensemble companies at our producing level in NYC.  Established in 2001, we are a small but prolific non-profit theatre company, having produced over 55 productions and events both locally and nationally. Check out our website www.risinsunnyc.com for more information about us.

We bring to this project our long history of collaboration, existing audience, established reputation, enthusiastic energy and exciting award nominated work.  We feel confident that when we hit our IndieGoGo Campaign Goal, our 12th Season will be our best yet!  BUT it’s still A LONG WAY off from happening. 

If we don’t reach our goal, we will have to postpone our planned productions. 

Please be aware that contributions to the Indie Go Go Campaign are NOT tax deductible. However! If you would like to make a tax deductible donation you can do so HERE at our fiscal sponsor the Field. 


PLEASE HELP OUR ARTISTS BRING THEIR WORK TO LIFE!
$10,000 is just the first step, and that will only cover the very basics towards our seasons needs

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute financially right now? That’s OK, just by visiting our page you have already helped! Here are some BIG ways that you can make a difference in our campaign and season! 

  • Help us go viral!  Spread the word about our campaign, share it on Facebook and Twitter, invite your friends to view our campaign and ask them to share it too! Be an online cheerleader for RSP.
  • Every time our campaign is shared and viewed it brings us up higher in our category and helps get potential donors outside our network! IT REALLY DOES HELP! And don’t forget Indie Go Go has made sharing and promoting our campaign super easy! USE THESE TOOLS TO GET STARTED!
  • Want to help in other ways? WOW! Thanks you rock! Handy with a needle & thread? Like to paint or bang nails? Drive a large car or van? Want to be hands on in the making of our season? Sign up to volunteer with us! Email staff@risingsunnyc.com and we’ll put you to work!

THANK YOU FOR READING OUR CAMPAIGN  & THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

The Rising Sun Performance Company:

Ensemble:  Andrea Cordaro ,Andres Pina,Ashleigh Herndon, Carl Fengler, Christina  Germaine, Christina Williams, Cristina M Ramos, Christopher Sanchez, Elizabeth Burke, Hanna Sender, Isaac Dean, Jason LeMaster, Joe Beaudin, Kelley Evans,  Kelsey Lidsky, Kervin Peralta, Kimberly DiPersia, Larry Phillips, Lauren Tyrell, Maggie Kissinger, Marquis Wilson, Michael Aguirre, Meg Dowling, Peter Buck Dettman, Phoebe Leonard, RJ Verchaud, Ryan Dusek, Samantha Coppola, Samantha DeSimone, Toby Macdonald & Yvonne Cole

The Staff: Akia, Tiffini Minatel, Jak Prince, Jenna Rafferty, Tim Butterfield & Nzinga Williams

Interns:  Alex Scordato, Cassidy Graves, Kimberly Lin,Ted Gu, Gianfranco Lentini & Megan Bandelt

Extended Family/Associated Artists:

David Anthony, John Patrick Bray, Jeff Woodbridge, Tim Errickson, Samantha Cooper, Mike Burns, Mia Anderson,  Louisa Pough & Kate Foster

We are Launching Part Two of our Season 12 Fundraising Campaign!
Our Original Campaign Goal was $10,000 and in just 21 days we hit half of our goal! Which is amazing and wonderful! We have raised funds to cover the cost of our Fall Repertory Venue, but we still have a long way to go! But we still need to raise another $5,000 to keep our season going!3 Productions this fall and 3 more next spring! We have a ambitious goal and know with your help we can make it happen! 
This fall Rising Sun Performance Company hits a significant landmark in our history, one that few indie theatre companies in NYC will ever reach. We celebrate 12 years of making our signature raw, evocative, engaging and authentic theatrical experiences.
As we embark on Season 12, we put an emphasis on new works created from within the ensemble, including  The world premiere of Ice Age from resident playwright Mike Aguirre, Original Devised work that we will present as guests at festivals and special events, a return to the work in progress “Henry’s Wives” along with two revivals of published works: Brilliant Traces by Cindy Lou Johnson and the Remount of RSP’s inaugural production Hellcab by Will Kern. The next 4 months promises to be filled with many exciting moments on and off stage featuring the work of our talented ensemble, playwrights, directors  and an immensely talented design and support team.  Our Fall/Winter Season will run from October 30th thru December 20th.  
We have existed this long by working in the most cost effective and innovative ways possible. By the grace of donors and grants, donated space, in kind costumes, and with the exceptionally hard work of a 100% volunteer run staff and ensemble we have presented over 55 productions & events.  However, as cost effective as we run our company, we still need a significant amount of funding in order to function as a viable company in NYC. 
IN ORDER FOR SEASON 12 TO HAPPEN, WE MUST RAISE an additional $5,000 WITHIN THE NEXT MONTH
What we have in place:Exciting New Works By Talented PlaywrightsKiller Innovative DesignersTop Notch DirectorsBreathtaking ActorsStellar Stage Managers& Wonderful Spaces to Rehearse in 
Here is the short list of what we need to accomplish our 12th season$5,000 for our fall Rep Venue <<< RAISED! ACCOMPLISHED
We still need this:$1,200 for our Hellcab Venue$1,600 for Royalty Rights for Brilliant Traces & Hellcab$1,950 for Festival Fees for Henry’s Wives, Ice Age & Erik (If accepted into festivals) $3,500 to pay our 3 Stage Managers, Publicist & Designers$2,000 for our Set, Props & Costumes$1,500 for rehearsal space$700 for Postcards & Posters $500 for Liability & Event Insurance $1,000 for sound, lighting & Audio Visual technologyBe a part of our collective history and give Season 12 a chance to succeed! Donate today!
After the success of last year’s Hotel Suite, we look to return to a non-traditional venue to provide our audiences with an up-close and unforgettable theatrical experience. So, almost all of the pieces have fallen into place – we have an amazing group of directors, playwrights, actors and collaborators. THIS IS the team to make our season happen, BUT WE NEED YOUR HELP to get there!  We are in negotiations with a great venue, but we need to pay for the space in order to move forward! 
Here is where you get to be a part of the show!  Every donation goes a long way to making this season and our future seasons a reality. AND with ongoing updates on this campaign, fun hands on perks including backstage access, walk on roles and meet & greet opportunities, we make sure that you aren’t just in the audience but in on the action.
DONATIONS WILL UNLOCK UPDATES AND CHALLENGES FOR CHANCES TO WIN PRIZES
Help us continue our legacy of bold, exciting and uncompromising theatre just for you.
See the sidebar for the AWESOME PERKS starting with just a $10 DONATION!The most important element besides the cool perks is the impact of having your money support local independent theatre in a very real way. You could be a direct part of an exciting theatrical event and a leader in supporting art on a grassroots level.Rising Sun Performance Company is a vital part of the Off-Off Broadway landscape; being one of the longest running ensemble companies at our producing level in NYC.  Established in 2001, we are a small but prolific non-profit theatre company, having produced over 55 productions and events both locally and nationally. Check out our website www.risinsunnyc.com for more information about us.We bring to this project our long history of collaboration, existing audience, established reputation, enthusiastic energy and exciting award nominated work.  We feel confident that when we hit our IndieGoGo Campaign Goal, our 12th Season will be our best yet!  BUT it’s still A LONG WAY off from happening. 
If we don’t reach our goal, we will have to postpone our planned productions. 
Please be aware that contributions to the Indie Go Go Campaign are NOT tax deductible. However! If you would like to make a tax deductible donation you can do so HERE at our fiscal sponsor the Field. 
PLEASE HELP OUR ARTISTS BRING THEIR WORK TO LIFE!$10,000 is just the first step, and that will only cover the very basics towards our seasons needs
Other Ways You Can Help
Can’t contribute financially right now? That’s OK, just by visiting our page you have already helped! Here are some BIG ways that you can make a difference in our campaign and season! 
Help us go viral!  Spread the word about our campaign, share it on Facebook and Twitter, invite your friends to view our campaign and ask them to share it too! Be an online cheerleader for RSP.
Every time our campaign is shared and viewed it brings us up higher in our category and helps get potential donors outside our network! IT REALLY DOES HELP! And don’t forget Indie Go Go has made sharing and promoting our campaign super easy! USE THESE TOOLS TO GET STARTED!
Want to help in other ways? WOW! Thanks you rock! Handy with a needle & thread? Like to paint or bang nails? Drive a large car or van? Want to be hands on in the making of our season? Sign up to volunteer with us! Email staff@risingsunnyc.com and we’ll put you to work!
THANK YOU FOR READING OUR CAMPAIGN  & THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!
The Rising Sun Performance Company:Ensemble:  Andrea Cordaro ,Andres Pina,Ashleigh Herndon, Carl Fengler, Christina  Germaine, Christina Williams, Cristina M Ramos, Christopher Sanchez, Elizabeth Burke, Hanna Sender, Isaac Dean, Jason LeMaster, Joe Beaudin, Kelley Evans,  Kelsey Lidsky, Kervin Peralta, Kimberly DiPersia, Larry Phillips, Lauren Tyrell, Maggie Kissinger, Marquis Wilson, Michael Aguirre, Meg Dowling, Peter Buck Dettman, Phoebe Leonard, RJ Verchaud, Ryan Dusek, Samantha Coppola, Samantha DeSimone, Toby Macdonald & Yvonne Cole
The Staff: Akia, Tiffini Minatel, Jak Prince, Jenna Rafferty, Tim Butterfield & Nzinga WilliamsInterns:  Alex Scordato, Cassidy Graves, Kimberly Lin,Ted Gu, Gianfranco Lentini & Megan BandeltExtended Family/Associated Artists:
David Anthony, John Patrick Bray, Jeff Woodbridge, Tim Errickson, Samantha Cooper, Mike Burns, Mia Anderson,  Louisa Pough & Kate Foster

story:
In 2014, the world ended. Three men survived by hiding out in a Generic Underground Shelter. This is their story... and it is entirely improvised.


Starting as part of The Factory's Cabaret, G.U.S. has since made its home at the People's Improv Theater in NYC. The show stars three veteran improvisers, Langston Belton, Nick Carrillo, and Devin Heater. And now, we're taking our show to the New York International Fringe Festival. Huzzah! 

The New York International Fringe Festival (FringeNYC) is the largest multi-arts festival in North America, with more than 200 companies from all over the world performing for 16 days in more than 20 venues.

We got into the Fringe and boy-oh-boy are we excited about it. But it turns out being in the Fringe costs money. Even more money if you want people to come see your show. We would like people to come see our show. 

  • 40% of the budget is going to Fringe related costs
  • 30% of the budget is going to insurance and production elements
  • 20% is going to any and all marketing material -- including t-shirts!
  • 10% is for any other expenses we might encounter

                               

Show times:

Su. 8/16@6:15p
We. 8/19@3:45p
Th. 8/20@7:45p
Su. 8/23@9:30p

Th. 8/27@2p

Venue:

Spectrum @ 121 Ludlow Street (spectrumnyc.com)

Tickets can be purchased at FringeNYC.org

story:
"Bloody thou art, bloody will be thy end."

Ten actors take on 48 roles in William Shakespeare's epic tale of power, ambition, and curses. Though England thinks its civil war has finally come to an end under the reign of King Edward IV, his youngest brother, Richard, feels differently. Born a cripple and raised an outcast, Richard determines to make the crown his own. As Richard's campaign of violence spins out of control, the powerless are left to pick up the pieces. One of Shakespeare's earliest plays, Richard III contains impressive language and the theatrical boldness of a young playwright.

Brave Spirits Theatre, founded in 2011, is a professional theatre company dedicated to bringing fresh, energetic productions of the works of William Shakespeare and other early modern playwrights to the Washington, D.C. region. We have a triangular focus: text, actor, and audience.

 

Richard III

June 21 - July 7
Thursdays at 8pm
Fridays at 8pm
Saturdays at 2pm
Saturdays at 8pm

Atlas Performing Arts Center
Lab I Theatre
1333 H Street, NE
Washington, DC 20002
http://atlasarts.org/

 

Your donation will help support this production cover all of its associated costs, including space rental, marketing, costumes, props, supplies, and actor and production staff stipends. Thank you so much.

story:
Our Story

Judith: The Other Shakespeare was a dream of my friend and colleague, Mr. Kevin Stackhouse and, like many of his dreams, he likes to see them become a reality. Judith, however, is very special as compared to previous projects such as After Carpathia since it is one of Kevin's first full-length, immensely involved, and absolutely brilliant MUSICAL complete with more than twenty musical numbers spanning two hours. It is a spectacle to see and appreciate!

The play is based on the essay by Virginia Woolf, "A Room of One's Own" and follows the legendary writer through her own thoughts as she paints a picture of her life and her stream of consciousness on many layers including: who REALLY wrote the plays of William Shakespeare, what inspired her to do so, and how this extraordinary tale of love, loss, failure, triumph, and the path of an artist directly mirrors Virginia's own life.

Next to the play itself, the most important part of this entire production is the cast. In fact, this cast has been one of the greatest I  have ever had to work with in my entire life and, following some financial trouble, I do not want to be forced to shut this play down and risk the hard work of my beloved cast members. They are good at what they do and have given their all this entire time and, if we are not able to pay one of the two composers before ticket sales we cannot use his music...If we cannot use his music I cannot show you what these amazing actors and actresses have to offer to you and how they will honor Kevin' work.

For as generous a donation as you can afford, please help us raise $1000 to get this show back on track so that I can sign a worthy paycheck for my more-than-worthy actors. 

We need your help so that we can entertain you and help bring the aspirations of Kevin, the cast, my crew, and this wonderful play to life as many of these actors and actresses are looking to make headway in the theatre world and this could be the beginning of their big break!

Come see us at the Rotunda Theater on March 11th and 18th at 7:30 and a possible matinee performance on the 18th at 3:00pm and come to my Carnevale Masquerade Ball in February for a night of music, dancing, games of chance, and unparalleled entertainment (including magic, juggling, comedy and a sneak preview of Judith)


The Impact

In short, if this campaign does  not occur one of our composers will not allow us to use his FOUR songs and, becasue of that, the show will not go on! All of my actors will have rehearsed in vain, a year's worth of time, effort, love, and dedication will disappear, and Kevin's 2 years of writing will never see light.


What We Need & What You Get

If you help us the money will go DIRECTLY to the composer so that our show can continue. In addition to this we are holding a bake sale, looking for sponsors and backers, and selling messages for a message board for our actors ALL in an attempt to get these guys a paycheck and get this show on the road. I am not going to lie, we have a lot of expenses to tackle in addition to the composer's but, with your help, we can focus on more applicable goals and use our other fundraisers to achieve them


For your help you will get the following:

Pledge $1 or more

For AT LEAST $1 (and for ANY dollar amount following it) you will receive a hand written letter expressing our most heart-felt thanks as well as a signed picture of the entire cast as well as honorable mention at each show both verbally and on our board of benefactors for the public to see!

Pledge $15 or more

One complimentary ticket to see Judith on March 11th or 18th at 7:30pm

Pledge $25 or more

One ticket to the Carnevale Masquerade Ball provided that you pledge before Feb 17th

Pledge $35 or more

One ticket to the see Judith on March 11th or 18th and one ticket to the Masquerade if pledge is received before Feb 17th

Pledge $50 or more

TWO Complimentary Tickets to see Judith on March 11th or 18th at 7:30 and one ticket to the Masquerade if received before Feb 17th


Other Ways You Can Help

Let everyone know about this mission I am running here!

Come see the play on March 18th at 7:30pm or March 11th at 3pm and 7:30pm!

Let everyone know about the play and how AMAZING it will be! I didn't invest all of my time into this to give you somehting less than spectacular.

story:
LETTERS TO LAURA IS A SHORT GIRL PRODUCTION


LETTERS TO LAURA

What happens when your entire relationship is based on perception? Have we been honest with each other, or is who we are just a projection of the perfect version of us? In this image that we have created, there are no flaws, no mistakes, and no substance. What happens when you change parts of yourself, just to feel loved? Is it real, or are we lonelier than ever? What is hidden behind the words?In Letters to Laura, we will follow two people in love with each other, as they try to find the answers to the questions everyone is asking. The hard part? They live in two different countries.

We now have the wonderful opportunity to not only take this play to the world renowned Edmonton International Fringe Festival in August, but we have recently received some very wonderful news. Letters To Laura has been chosen to be performed in the San Diego Fringe Festival in July! This means our deadline is much closer than anticipated and we have a few more expenses that we weren't planning on.

What happens to the money?

The funds raised for this project will go to the production costs themselves and the cost of getting the show to San Diego. This means:

Set Design and Construction: $500.00

Costumes: $200.00

Flights : $2500.000

Accommodation: $2000.00

Car Rentals: $900.00

Festival Fees: $600.00

Marketing (poster's and hand bills): $300.00


Total of Projected Cost $7000.00

Anything raised from funding is going directly into getting the show to the stage and most importantly to the festival. So you know your money will be used to finish bringing this story to life. 


THE PERK?

We will also be at the Edmonton International Fringe Festival in August! So just because we need help getting to San Diego, you will still be able to see where all of your support went, and maybe even get to meet to the Cast and Crew involved.

This is my first International performance therefore I really want it to be the best it can be. With a little bit extra, I can fly the actors, set us up, build an awesome set, get some great marketing, and and blow it out of the water. So please help me.  

About San Diego Fringe

San Diego International Fringe Festival is a project of Contact Arts, a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization founded in 2003 along with Actors Alliance of San Diego with the purpose building a network of creativity & communication. Contact Arts & AASD aim to connect ideas with social action through progressive performance & community engaged projects.

Letters To Laura needs YOUR help to take it international! Your contributions will help pay for expenses and production costs that will be needed to make this show as great as it deserves to be. And will help bring the local artists involved to the United States, and showcase the talent that we have in Edmonton.


GET TO KNOW THE ARTISTS INVOLVED!!

Perry Gratton – Director / Set Designer / Graphic Design

Perry is an actor, director, and graphic designer from Edmonton, AB, Canada. He graduated with a BFA in Acting as well as most of a BA in Drama from the University of Alberta. Selected credits include Don Pedro in Much Ado About Nothing, Guiderius in Cymbeline, Limping Man in Fuddy Meers, Sebastien in Twelfth Night, Sam in Drunk Enough to Say I Love You?, and Oberon/Theseus in Midsummer Night’s Dream. He has appeared in numerous plays at the Edmonton International Fringe Festival and Nextfest Next Generation Arts Festival. He recently opened his first exhibition of design and art work entitled Gratitude, and some of his work was featured as the festival image for Nextfest this year. Perry is an actor, director, and graphic designer from Edmonton, AB, Canada. He graduated with a Bachelor of Fine arts as well as a Bachelor of Arts from the University of Alberta. His credits include Don Pedro in Much Ado About Nothing, Guideris in Cymbeline and Sam in Drunk Enough to Say I Love You? Perry has also appeared in numerous plays at the Edmonton International Fringe Festival throughout his extensive career. He is also proud to have opened his first exhibition of design and art work entitled Gratitude, with his work being featured as the festival image of the Nextfest Next Generatoin Arts Festival in Edmonton.

Elisa Benzer – Writer / Producer / Actor

As a bilingual actor, Elisa has been building her career for a number of years and performed across the country including Vancouver, Edmonton, and Saskatchewan. She has also had the pleasure of performing in Victoria Australia in 2012. Her theatre successes include Real (Gone) Girl; a movement based one woman show which premiered at the Edmonton International Fringe Festival. Her other acting credits include playing a stream of multiple characters in An Adult Evening with Shell Silverstein as well as HONK! A Musical Tale of the Ugly Duckling. She was also on the writing panel for the French production of Les Echos with L’Uni Theatre in 2013. This will be Elisa’s first production as the sole playwright and will also be touring the show to Canada at the Edmonton International Fringe Festival in August.

Evan Hall – Actor

Evan is a Canadian actor, dancer, performer and a graduate of the Bachelor of Fine Arts at the University of Alberta. He has performed in several cities across Canada including Vancouver BC, Winnipeg MB, as well as all over Alberta. Select acting credits include Kenneth in Clybourne Park, MacDuff in Macbeth andCharlie in Mary’s Wedding. He also helped create Murielle with Blarney/Promise Productions, which went on to win two Elizabeth Sterling Haynes Awards for Best Independent Production and Best TYA Production. Evan was also named as one of the handful of actors to watch for outstanding performances in the 2012 Edmonton International Fringe Festival for his productions of Gruesome Playground Injuries as well as Notes from a Zombie Apocalypse alongside Director Perry Gratton. 


If you aren't able to donate, SHARE SHARE SHARE!! Pass this onto someone you think might like to help. If anything, make sure to keep your eyes open for Letters To Laura at the Edmonton International Fringe Festival in august and see what all the fuss is about.

Thanks for everything! And I hope to see you at the show!

Kenneth in Clybourne Park, MacDuff in
Macbeth andCharlie in Mary’s Wedding.
He also helped create Murielle with
Blarney/Promise Productions, which went on to win two Elizabeth Sterling Haynes
Awards for Best Independent Production and Best TYA Production. Evan was also
named as one of the handful of actors to watch for outstanding performances in
the 2012 Edmonton International Fringe Festival for his productions of Gruesome Playground Injuries as well as Notes from a Zombie Apocalypse alongside
Director Perry Gratton.  

If you
aren't able to donate, SHARE SHARE SHARE!! Pass this onto someone you think
might like to help. If anything, make sure to keep your eyes open for Letters
To Laura at the Edmonton International Fringe Festival in august and see what
all the fuss is about.
Thanks
for everything! And I hope to see you at the show!

story:
Who We Are

Wildwood Summer Theatre is a nonprofit theatre company in the Washington, D.C. metropolitan area that has been involved in the vibrant local arts scene since 1965.  Through the work of 60 volunteer company members and the generosity of many corporate and community sponsors, WST stages a full-scale musical production each season.  By design, WST is similar to most major arts organizations of its kind except for one key aspect: we are entirely youth-run!  We seek to provide a real-world training environment for D.C. area professional and pre-professional artists between the ages of 14 and 25 where company members can refine their skills in a safe, supportive environment. All company members work as volunteers.  This allows us to accomplish high-quality art at less than half the investment cost of a typical production, all while improving community access to live theatre. 


"This sounds great, but why do you need my help?"

This year is WST's 50th season, an event that will culminate with our production of Stephen Sondheim's musical, Into the Woods.  Consistent with past productions, we plan to produce 6 nights of shows over the last two weekends in July.  The majority of our expenses accrue during the planning and rehearsal stages, meaning that we rely heavily on outside support to raise the bulk of our $30,000 budget. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our fundraising goal for this campaign is $6,000.  When broken down in to itemized expenditures,

  • $25 provides water for the performers for one night
  • $200 pays for one 12 ft long wig for Rapunzel
  • $250 covers the cost of cleaning the costumes for one performance
  • $350 buys microphone batteries for the run of the show
  • $2,000 pays for the rental of rehearsal space
  • $8,000 covers the rights, royalties, and rental of materials for the show
  • $12,000 covers the cost of renting the performance space

This campaign occurs in conjunction with several smaller fundraising activities, which is why our total costs substantially exceed our IndieGogo goal.  Any funds raised through this campaign will go towards the current season.  Since no company members receive payment, your contributions will ONLY be used to fund WST's shows.  Staff members complete all technical and administrative functions, so no company money will be used to pay for contracted services.

As a way of saying "Thank you" for your help, we're offering an exciting list of donor perks.  Our donor levels are as follows!

JOURNEYER ($1-25)

o  Personalized message from the WST Twitter account

o  Acknowledgement in the Playbill and on WST.org

WISHER ($25-50)

o  JOURNEYER level perks

o  Show poster signed by the cast

STORYTELLER ($50-$99)

o  WISHER level perks

o  25% off your first pair of tickets to Into the Woods

GUEST AT THE FESTIVAL ($100-$249)

o  STORYTELLER level perks

o  2 complimentary tickets to Into the Woods

VERY NICE PRINCE/PRINCESS ($250-$349)

o  GUEST AT THE FESTIVAL level perks

o  WST T-shirt

PURE AS GOLD ($350-$499)

o  VERY NICE PRINCE/PRINCESS level perks

o  4 complimentary tickets to Into the Woods

o  Opportunity to attend a pre-show talkback with the directors and cast

GIANT IN THE SKY ($500+)

o  PURE AS GOLD level perks

o  2 WST T-shirts

o  Recognition on donor board in the lobby of the theater



The Impact

If successfully funded, we'll be equipped to create a production of Into the Woods that honors the captivating, enchanting world that Sondheim and Lapine imagined 28 years ago.  You will have helped WST accomplish yet another showcase of DC's best young talent, providing artistic enrichment for the greater community. 

If you're skeptical about the value of your contribution in the short-term, have no doubts about your ability to make a lasting impact on WST and the talented individuals it employs.  Over 50 seasons, WST has earned a reputation as the training ground for many of the theatrical world's brightest!  Take a look at the following alumni:

  • Michael Mayer, Tony Award winning director of Thoroughly Modern Millie, Spring Awakening, and American Idiot among many other shows
  • Richard Scanlan, Tony-nominated lyricist of Thoroughly Modern Millie and book author of Everyday Rapture
  • Jonathan Hadary, Helen Hayes Award winning actor whose film credits include Intolerable Cruelty and Bait
  • Michael Bobbitt, Artistic Director of Adventure Theatre MTC and award winning writer, director, and choreographer
  • Brad Watkins, Director of Theatre Services at Theatre Washington and former Producing Director of the Olney Theatre Center


Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to contribute at this time, you can still help us out in other ways!

  • Share our page to the theatre lovers you know, and help us make some noise about our 50th Season campaign!  IndieGogo has easy share tools conveniently located on this page!
  • If you're in the area, show dates and ticket info can be found on our website, WST.org.  We'll be running our annual silent auction after each show!

If you want to contribute in other ways, visit our website or email the Director of Fundraising at fundraising@wst.org.  Checks can be sent to:

Attn: Fundraising
Wildwood Summer Theatre
PO Box 30022
Bethesda, MD 20824

Thank you, and we hope you'll join us on our journey into the woods!

Check out some photos from past shows!

Pit Orchestra for A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum (2012)

Pit Orchestra rehearsal for A Chorus Line (2013)

A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum (2012)

A Chorus Line (2013)

See many more on our Facebook page!

story:
Sweetie Maude is the brainchild of Sabrina Harper. Like most of Sabrina’s brainchildren, once it lodged itself in her head, she couldn’t, WOULDN’T rest until she could see it realized.

 

Sweetie Maude is the lesbian version of Sweeney Todd set in  Chicago. Sweetie Maude is a woman scorned. When Sweetie was young she was forced to leave Chicago because of her forbidden love with a closeted pregnant lesbian madame. Local magistrate, Judge Turpin, saw the love Sweetie had for the Madame and was jealous, for he too loved the Madame, and could not bear to see the two woman raise the madame's bastard child, Savannah. The judge sent Sweetie away, drove the madame to certain death and is now planning on marrying his the now orphaned daughter, Savannah.

Twenty years later, Sweetie has come back to exact her revenge.

Sweetie Maude is the all-female, lesbian version of Sweeney Todd. Set in Chicago in a timeless age, Sweetie Maude is the story of jealousy, cruelty and ultimately, of revenge.  Although this musical is a pastiche (a work of art that closely and lovingly imitates the original work) of Sweeney Todd, Sweetie Maude finds it’s own voice. Maude resonates as an all-female story: manipulation, jealousy and revenge find their home in our anti-hero Sweetie, but we also see strength, and power.


When Sabrina got the idea for Maude, she brought in her very best friend, fellow improviser Margaret Hicks. Margaret had her own passion for Sondheim and together, the two of them fully realized the idea of Sweetie Maude.

 

The cast is culled from people the two have worked with at Second City, The Annoyance and The Playground for the past 15 years. Sweetie will run at Studio Be starting September 26, 2013 and will run through October 31, ending with a Halloween finale the likes of which have never been seen before!

 

Sabrina and Margaret are looking for help to produce the show. The biggest expense of course, is the theater. We also will need help with sets, costumes, etc.

 

AND NOW THE CAST!!

 

Please welcome new cast members Denise Swindell and Amy Thompson!!! Denise  will be angry and sarcastic playing the part of BEAVER. Amy will be rolling around on skates and singing sweet tunes as the role of TOOTIE!

 

Erica Reid-Choreographer

 

Erica Reid has been choreographing in Chicago for the last 13 years. Productions include Boobs of the Dead: A Walking Dead Burlesque with Gorilla Tango Burlesque, The Kiss Kiss Cabaret, Belmont Burlesque Revue, Blewt! Productions's Impress These Apes!, Hot and Heavy Burlesque's Tribute to the Wall, Greek with Chicago Opera Vanguard, Peek-a-boo: The Ooky Spooky Halloween Burlesque Revue, Kerpatty, Breakfast Club: the Totally 80s Musical and Friday the Halloweenth at the IO Theatre, Yellow! and Horry Cow-Thats's Lacist! with Stir Friday Night, Paper Spaceship at the ComedySportz Theatre, Little House on the Parody with Single Box Turn Productions and many more. She's also a producer with Blewt! Productions and has a web series with Jen Ellison called Drunk Monkeys.

 

Lisa McQueen – Musical Director and Musical Score

Lisa McQueen is originally from Tennessee and is the Ensemble Member/Musical Director at Annoyance Theater for 21 years, has composed music for Tippi: Portrait of a Virgin, President Bush is a Great Man, The Invention Show, Kink, 40 Whacks, Swear Jar, and most recently Tiny Fascists, a musical about the Boy Scouts of America.  Second City Musical Director credits include three years with The National Touring Company and revues in Atlanta, Denver, Rochester, Barbados, and Amsterdam.  Lisa also plays with the Jeannie Tanner Jazz Quartet, and The Rolling Clones, a band dedicated to the music of the Rolling Stones, the greatest rock band in all of history.

 

Dori Goldman will play the lovely and sexy Ms. Lickett.

Dori has been a performer in Chicago for a long, LONG time. She has acted in original musicals, sketch and improv shows galore at The Annoyance, IO, The Playground, Comedy Sportz, The Theatre Building, Bailiwick, Live Bait, WNEP, Candlelight Forum, Donny's Skybox, Royal George and Victory Gardens/Body Politic theaters. She has also performed Off-Broadway, New York and at many comedy and fringe festivals around North America and in London. She is an original cast member of School House Rock Live! which is celebrating its 20th year this August. Her voice over demo can be found here: www.dorigoldman.com– please have a listen.

LICKETT
Welcome to my pie shop!
Not a dollar to my name
But trust me I don’t feel no parts of shame 
Catching pus- cows is just a game (meow)
This is probably the worst shit on state street
The crust is like concrete
The inside is shifty and purrs like a kitty
It’s only just me, can’t sell ‘em for free, the worst shit on State Street!

story:
New York is a mecca for the arts, but as one of the largest cultural centers of the world space is limited and expensive. That is why Mercury Glass Theatre is asking you to help us raise the money we need to house and produce our show as we return to Teatro LATEA at the Clemente Soto Velez Center. 

The performing space for our 3 week run of Edward II by Christopher Marlowe will cost us 11,700. Our production will run is Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday in New York City. That means each day we perform the space costs $835.

We also need money for:

    • Costumes
    • Set Pieces
    • Props
    • Rehearsal Space
    • Paying our Artistic Collaborators

All of this will go towards the first show of our exciting second season!

About the Show

The play uses the tumultuous history of 14th century England to tell a more intimate tale of Edward II's rise and fall. Marlowe asks, when the allure of power is calling, which should guide us most: family, love, or political gain? He challenges us to consider whether such distinctions are even possible. I think we're up to the task. 

Support Mercury Glass and Join Us as a Collaborator

One of the things we love about theatre is the ability to collaborate with artists, designers, and audiences. We want to expand our collaboration beyond the four walls of the theatre to you. With your contribution, you can become one of our collaborators.

If you can’t contribute, but still want to help, share our message with your friends and family on Facebook, Twitter, and other social media outlets. Or take our message offline and share it via carrier pigeon, postcard, letter, and word of mouth.

Even though we are serious about our craft, we still like to put a little bit of fun back into fundraising.

Who are we exactly?

Mercury Glass Theatre Company was founded in order to give young up and coming artists, who were interested in created through provoking theatre that highlight socially progressive themes an opportunity forge a new path into the our theatre scene. This isn’t just an opportunity for our artists, it’s a chance for the audience to experience a fresh take on classic and contemporary works. Our inspired eyes can present a new mirror with which to view the world.

Our fresh outlook is a gift we are trying to give New York and we can’t do that without a space in which to create our craft. And so we ask you, friends, to help us acquired that space by giving what you can. New York is an exceedingly expensive place to put up a production.  We can’t put on our production without your help, any donation is appreciated. Give whatever you can. Help us expand our theatre, become a part of our theatre family and see what our eyes can offer the world. 

Our Official Mission

The Mercury Glass Theatre Company embraces the traditional edifying role of the arts in society by illuminating the world through presentist examination and cultivation of classical and contemporary creations in order to impact and influence its audience towards a more progressive, socially responsible future.

    We seek to:

  1. Produce classic and contemporary works performed in an intimate setting exposing the audience to the themes of the play through naked truth, creative interpretation, and honest storytelling.
  2. Challenge the ways in which people view the world by developing productions that highlight sociologically progressive themes.
  3. Work with young artists, students and educators to help craft the next generation of Americans who recognize the social and cultural potency of theatre.
  4. Provide broader audiences access to provoking, engaging performances through the development of a variable pricing structure.
  5. Educate, enrich and engage local schools and the bourgeoning artistic community around us through a series of focused outreach programs designed to bring our artistic endeavors to other's spaces as well as bring them into our own.
  6. Breaking the mold for emerging artists by rejecting the conventional career paths and opportunities pre-designed to guide our careers.

To learn more about The Mercury Glass Theatre Company and our projects, visit our website http://www.mercuryglasstheatre.org/.

If you can't contribute money but would like to donate goods or services like free printing or supplies, please email us at fundraising@mercuryglasstheatre.org or call (646) 829-9093.

If your going to be in NYC, come to the show! 


You can buy tickets online at: http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/825243


September 25, 2014 through October 12, 2014 at Teatro LATEA at the Clemente, 107 Suffolk Street. 

Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday 7:30 PM and Sunday 2 PM


The final way you can help is by spreading the word. Help us create buzz, tell you friends and family about the show and direct them to our website, social media channels or here. Here are the link: 

    FACEBOOK: www.facebook.com/MercuryGlassTheatreCompany
    TWITTER: www.twitter.com/Mercury_Glass

    THANK YOU FOR BELIEVING IN US!

story:
Lost Land is a play set in a poorly conceived theme park in Massachusetts. It takes place in 1959, 2010, and 2150. Designed by people who fled Disney, the park centered on the great white whale, Moby Dick. In 1959, Ruth gets a job working as Mortimer, a wharf rat and the park’s mascot. There she meets her first love. Neither the job, nor the love are at all what she expects.

In 2010, Lucy is a developer, turning the derelict park into an office park. She is also dealing with a baby, unplanned, who is in the NICU (also unplanned).

In 2150, Minder discovers Brown Bear living in the wrecks of the office buildings and the amusement park. They are some of the few survivors of a world wide Diphtheria related plague. They live in a world where a fancy meal is Vatmeat.

The play is about love, finding it and losing it. It is also about a giant fiberglass whale, built to terrify and delight, and left to rot in a lake. Moby has been there a long time and seen a lot of things. And he has opinions about it all.

I am planning on producing the the play for the 2011 Frontera Fringe festival here in Austin. The fee is $450. I hope to raise at least that amount as a starting point. I hope to use this play as a launch pad for a theatre company, that focuses on strong female characters, seeks to ask big philosophical questions about life, and is environmentally sustainable (all set materials and others recycled and reused).
story_txt:
Lost Land is a play set in a poorly conceived theme park in Massachusetts. It takes place in 1959, 2010, and 2150. Designed by people who fled Disney, the park centered on the great white whale, Moby Dick. In 1959, Ruth gets a job working as Mortimer, a wharf rat and the park’s mascot. There she meets her first love. Neither the job, nor the love are at all what she expects.
In 2010, Lucy is a developer, turning the derelict park into an office park. She is also dealing with a baby, unplanned, who is in the NICU (also unplanned).
In 2150, Minder discovers Brown Bear living in the wrecks of the office buildings and the amusement park. They are some of the few survivors of a world wide Diphtheria related plague. They live in a world where a fancy meal is Vatmeat.
The play is about love, finding it and losing it. It is also about a giant fiberglass whale, built to terrify and delight, and left to rot in a lake. Moby has been there a long time and seen a lot of things. And he has opinions about it all.
I am planning on producing the the play for the 2011 Frontera Fringe festival here in Austin. The fee is $450. I hope to raise at least that amount as a starting point. I hope to use this play as a launch pad for a theatre company, that focuses on strong female characters, seeks to ask big philosophical questions about life, and is environmentally sustainable (all set materials and others recycled and reused).

story:
Please note - for donors after June 27, you will receive an official show program (program mention no longer available due to printing deadlines).

UPDATE - We would like to send a heartfelt thank you to everyone who has contributed to our campaign so far. We'll take the stage this July in large part because of you and your generosity. The $2,500 goal was a portion of the overall cost of doing the show, so if you have not contributed just yet but would like to, we welcome and appreciate every dollar. Thank you again for your support!

Our Story

I grew up in the swamplands of south Louisiana. Both of my parents (pictured, right), in fact my entire family, are the hardest workers I've ever known. My father is the definition of a "blue-collar" worker, someone who has worked with his hands his whole life, almost entirely under the scorching Louisiana sun. My mother and father both worked hard at two jobs to send me to Louisiana State University, and it was there that I first saw Cat on a Hot Tin Roof. It was set in a southern culture, where football heroes ruled the day and the facade of southern grace and manners hid much darker themes of truth. I grew up in that culture and knew it well, and the play's writing has stayed with me since then, for nearly 20 years.


I was home visiting my family while working on a scene from the play for an acting class. My father saw the play in my hands and said "'Cat on a Hot Tin Roof?' That's the play about 'mendacity,' isn't it?" I was an athlete in high school, initially studied journalism at LSU, and was headed for a career in sports broadcasting. That was until I took an acting class, and every other color faded but that one. My father and I had never shared a conversation about a play until that moment. We talked about the play and its characters, Big Daddy and Brick, and of course, Maggie the Cat. And I knew that one day I would have to speak Williams' lines on stage, in honor of that moment and my own roots.


So that's why I decided to produce this show and do just that - play Brick - to honor the brilliant work of Tennessee Williams, and to honor how the written word and theater itself can create moments that truly do bring two people together in unexpected ways.

Depending on the kindness of strangers, friends and family

To make this dream a reality, we're going to need your help, or it simply won't happen. With the rights unavailable in the Los Angeles area, we're taking the show up the coast to beautiful Santa Barbara. That also means the added expenses of housing the cast and crew, and so many more costs that come with producing a show.


Your donation to us will be the difference. If you can't join us for our performances on July 14-17, then perhaps you can help us in another way. We've created what we feel are fun tokens of our appreciation to you for your donations to us. Any amount helps, as I am not producing this show with an already existing theater company, but rather doing it on my own financially. We are asking you, our supporters, to help us raise the funds to cover a portion of the overall costs of doing a play out of town, since those involved in the production live in the Los Angeles area.


This is truly a passion project, and if you have ever had a dream of your own, one that needed the help of others to see it through, then I hope you will be able to do the same for us. As Williams himself once wrote in another one of his classics, "I have always depended on the kindness of strangers." Now we depend on that kindness from you, our friends, families, and supporters, to help us realize this dream. Thank you.

The Impact

There is a reason Cat on a Hot Tin Roof is as popular today as ever. The themes that Williams wrote about (family, truth, greed, sexuality, alcoholism, deception) are just as vivid and present in people's everyday lives in one form or another as they were in 1955. Every audience member can see some part of their own lives or their own families onstage while watching this play, and most have only seen the film version, which had to edit much of the story Williams wanted to tell due to Motion Picture Association codes that were in place at the time. We have a chance to show new audiences a play that perhaps they know of, but have never actually seen.

What We Need and What You Get

These are just a few of the ways in which your donations will help us:

  • Housing in Santa Barbara for our cast/crew for 6 nights: $1750
  • Wardrobe costs: $250
  • Materials to build our set and truck rentals: $500


There are many more costs that we're not listing here (theater rental, posters, postcards, website costs, royalty fees), but covering this $2,500 of the show's costs will do so much to help us get the production through.


As a very special thank you for your contributions, we have created several levels of gifts that we'd like to share with you. You'll see these levels and the gift included with each on the right side of our page. They include items such as show tickets and posters, and even your very own Maggie the Cat!

Other Ways You Can Help

Our greatest wish is that you join us during our production at the Center Stage Theater in Santa Barbara, CA on July 14-17, 2011, and share in this experience with us. You can find out more information and purchase tickets through the show's website: www.catoncenterstage.com. If you can't be with us, then please help us spread the word about the show and why we're doing it, and share this page with anyone you know. Every bit of support helps!

story:
THE WAY, FAR, FUTURE, A.D. 2010, NEW MALDEN: a time of techno-studded blechhiness.  Lonely human freedom fighter Kate Brick plans a last stand against the oppressive Artas, artificial life forms who control humankind through torture, brainwashing, and Facebook.  But judging by the complacence of her lover Dehnise Compuserve and the complacence of her former humans, it may be too late.

This play is the only cyberpunk musical comedy we know.  It has grown out of small theater groups in Boston, Cambridge, and Somerville, and we are pleasantly surprised at the support it has gotten from our community.  We would like to take it on tour to more cities over the next few months, starting with Club Oberon in Cambridge, MA, and including venues in New York and Provincetown.

Your donations will pay for gearing up our production for touring, which include paying for food, lodging, and transportation; theater and rehearsal-room rental fees; postcards and other promotional materials. 

To hear more news about us, the show, and the campaign, check out our tumblr blog at http://ourhideousfuture.tumblr.com
