story:
One Night Only!

Playlab NYC and Coffee Black Productions will present

 

Intellectual Property

An evening of mash-ups, fan-fiction, and parody.

 

May 19th 2012 

Bar 82, 136 2nd Avenue, New York, NY (9th & 10th Streets)

 

Playlab NYC and Coffee Black Productions are excited to team up this spring to present Intellectual Property.  Intellectual Property is an evening of mash-ups, fan-fiction, and parody. 

Since the summer of 2008, Playlab NYC has wanted to produce an energetic and fun show created out of derivative works relating to pop culture.  In 2010, we invited the team from Coffee Black Productions to a table reading of a variety of short plays, and last year they offered the opportunity for us to pool our resources perform at their favorite venue, Bar 82.  

Of Intellectual Property, Playlab NYC Artistic Director, Kevin P. Hale said, “I’m a student of the Off-Off Broadway movement.  And it is my desire to capture some of the energy of Caffe Cino, which was one of the birthplaces of Off-Off Broadway.  One night when a show was cancelled on short notice at Caffe Cino, they staged a work based on whatever comic book they could find the most issues of.  It is precisely that collision of Independent theater and popular culture that I wanted to explore.”

 

But we need your help!!

Even though we have some great writers and directors, this project is going to need some rehearsal space.  For about $500 we'll be able to cover the rehearsal studio rental costs for our directors and actors.  The average cost for one hour of rehearsal space is $20/hr.

 

Playlab NYC was founded in 2008 by Artistic Director Kevin P. Hale and Managing Director Jennifer Linn Wilcox.  They concoct, unleash and support enjoyably absurd and absurdly enjoyable amusements that engage artists and audiences in the spirit of play.  Past works include: Poe-Dunk: A Matchbox Entertainment (FRIGID New York 2012, FringeNYC 2011) Goldilocks and the Three Polar Bears, a co-production with Wide Eyed Productions (FringeNYC 2011); The Altoona Dada Society Presents: The Velvet Gentleman, presenting the unusual life of composer Erik Satie (FringeNYC 2010); Professor Ralph’s Loss of Breath, based on a short story by Edgar Allan Poe (FringeNYC 2009); Perfectly Natural, four fables from a different perspective (Midtown International Theater Festival 2009); and The Tempest, Shakespeare’s tale of magic, forgiveness, and fathers (Socrates Sculpture Park 2008). For more info visit www.playlabnyc.org.

 

Coffee Black Productions was founded in 2009 by Artistic Director Michael Bloom and Managing Director/Resident Playwright Carrie Boehm in order to perform plays simply, focusing on the playwright’s intentions without directorial embellishments that distort the playwright’s work. In the past two and half years, they have produced 18 evenings of performances ranging from full lengths to series of monologues and collections on one-acts. Throughout all of this, they have collected a core of dedicated playwrights, directors, and actors who keep coming back for more. For more info visit http://coffeeblackproductions.wordpress.com/

 

Intellectual Property will perform for one night only May 19th 2012 at 6:00 PM.  Bar 82 is located in the Lower East Side at 136 Second Avenue, New York, NY (9th & 10th Streets) - - accessible from the N,R (8 St-NYU) or 4, 6, 6x (Bleecker) stop.  Tickets are $5 and will be available at the door.

 

Spread the word and thanks for pledging!  See you at the show!!

 

Meet our creative team:

Writers: Diana Bedoya, Carrie Boehm, Dan Fiorella, Harshman Grevelis, Ethan Kanfer, Mike Poblete, William Ponder, Ted Wenskus

Directors:  Kevin P. Hale, John Pieza, Sarah Anne Simmons

Actors:  Kelsey Arlen, Dylan Digel, Megan Hildebrand, Seth Koprowski, Hank Lin, J.J. Mehren,, Adam Leong, James McDowell, Alex Carmine, Julie Drummond, Sean Behrens, Meg Grujon, Equiano Mosieri

Sound:  Christopher Lee Schardin

Intellectual Property Logo: Robert Ullman

story:
A King of Infinite Beginnings

So, when I was 9 my father passed away in November. By January, there was a new man in the house and to say that it shook me was an understatement. A year later, I was introduced to Hamlet. Now, I didn't understand the language fully but understood the fear and the rage in Hamlet's heart. And, in my pre-adolescent mind, I plotted ways to kill my stepfather. Needless to say, Hamlet was my all time favorite play.

During college, I was offered a job in Austin, TX. I was on my way to the first day of training from San Antonio. Along the way, I ran into a lot of traffic just outside of San Marcos. I pulled over and asked a guy what was going on. He said that Pearl Jam was playing. I said, "Fuck it. How much for a ticket?" I ended up one row from the stage and it was my first ever concert. I fell in love with Eddie Vedder and from then on, Pearl Jam was my all time favorite band.

Thank God, Freedome and Jerry agreed to try and meld the two into a project that would later come to be A King of Infinite Space. After our weekends in the Bronx, we will be offered an opportunity to run for a week at Here Art Center. In order to run the production, we need funding which brings us to you.

What We Need

We are looking to raise $3500 for our week run at Here. Funding will be used to pay a week salary for:

  • Actors
  • Designers
  • Running Crew

Other Ways You Can Help

I know times our tight and we understand if you're unable to contribute at this time, but, there are other ways you can help:

  • Help us get the word out!
  • Purchase a ticket!
  • Post it on your facebook or tweet about it!
Thanks!
Mando, Bernardo, and Jerry

story:
WHEN 

Gonne hits the New Theatre Stage Dublin May 28th - June 8th

ABOUT THE PLAY

Maud Gonne has taken to the stage to tell the story of her life. For the sake of ‘balance’, W.B. Yeats has also taken to the stage to tell the story of her life. You can decide for yourselves which version you believe, but Yeats’ has more romance and alliteration. Also, he has a Nobel Prize, so…

Join Maud as she takes you through the momentous events of her life - her affair with a French republican, leading protests against the British Empire, dabbling in the occult and a short but significant acting career - to weave a complex portrait of a woman fighting for the right to fight. There may be some interruptions from Yeats, who doesn’t feel their one-sided romance gets the attention it deserves in Maud’s script, and Lady Gregory, who just wants everyone to get along. Expect poetry, protests, and a slight deviation from historical fact, as Maud challenges her legacy as an artistic muse.


WHY WE NEED HELP
In order to fund this show we need to pay our venue, artists and build a rather kick ass set the materials of which don't come cheap. We'll also put the money towards the most effective marketing possible to make sure we sell out and put the money to good use

Your money will help keep us afloat through the rest of the process and make sure everyone is fairly paid at the end too! 

WHO EVEN ARE WE?
The Unamused Theatre team come from an eclectic mix of arts background and together have sold out our Dublin Fringe show 'Down the Drain' in 2018. 

The biggest fear is always selling tickets. We know that our collective experience will ensure tickets are sold and audiences are entertained! Simples 

As a team we have been to a lot of quizzes and open mics recently and sometimes people are sick of these. Using online funding allows us to target people interested in our project and offer them rewards without restricting them to time constraints. 

THANK YOU! 
WE BELIEVE IN OUR PROJECT AND CANNOT DO IT WITHOUT THE CONTINUED SUPPORT OF OUR FUNDERS AND AUDIENCES!

story:
aniima mundii

director - ODie Mers

w/ Lucie Allouche, JD Askin, AYA, Yuna Chen, Max Chidzero, Jackie Colquitt, Katie DeBari, Maya Hendricks, KyungHyun Kim, and Bre Tomey

Documentarian: Tyaela Nieves

Lighting Designer: Cati Kalinoski

Set Designer: Nell Heidinger

 

everything counts!

We're asking for a lot of money. This is to pay for rehearsal space that can accommodate our large cast of 12 and to pay our incredible artists! They deserve to be paid for their 200+ hours of time in rehearsal, not to mention the research and preparation they do on their own time. Theatre artists are already hugely underpaid, and rehearsal space in NYC is expensive!

Please help us reach our goal! Check out our perks over to the side there and get some delightful prizes for your generosity.

We need all the help we can get. Every dollar, share, and good word helps!

here's a breakdown of our funds:

the impact of this project

Our last go of this project: "ANIMA MUNDI" premiered at The Experimental Theatre Wing of NYU's Tisch School of The Arts. In that production each member of the cast felt a new connection to the nonhuman animal they performed as and to the earth's ecology as a whole.

This show brings the environmental into the personal and reveals how personal our ecology is.

In this production, we intend to use Movement Generation's "Just Transition", their framework for a fair shift to an economy that is ecologically sustainable, as a guide to how environmental theatre and environmental justice can be relevant to all our lives' complexities.

You can read more about Movement Generation and Just Transition  here: https://movementgeneration.org/ and here: https://climatejusticealliance.org/just-transition/

 

other ways YOU can help!

Please share this campaign! Get the word out even if you can't donate. It goes a long way and really helps us out.

If you have any questions about the campaign, the show, or all else, we'd love to hear from you.

 

Thank you!

aniimndii

w/ Lucie Allouche, JD Askin, AYA, Yuna Chen, Max Chidzero, Jackie Colquitt, Katie DeBari, Maya Hendricks, KyungHyun Kim, and Bre Tomey

story:
Alyce/Donna on Tour on Shanghai, China


 After many years working in dance companies and learning from amazing choreographers from all over the world, I've started to pursue my own choreographic work. My recent solo, Alyce/Donna (composed of two existing works and modified into a solo) has been selected to be performed in the first Shanghai International Contemporary Dance Festival.  I need financial support to be able to cover airfare for me and my tour manager to be able to perform in this incredible event. 

As an independent female American artist, with no company structure or grants facilitating my projects, being selected to represent the US and the local dance scene, is truly a milestone for me. I want to honor this opportunity not only to be presented there, but to also broaden my audience, and have the opportunity to exchange knowledge, artistry and nurture the creative evolution of dance with my peers from all over the world.

 I am asking for your support for my first international tour to China. Your generosity will be what makes this possible. THANK YOU!

What I Need & What You Get

  • The Festival Organizers are providing accommodations during the festival, meals and ground transportation for my tour manager and myself.  
  • I need to be able to cover airfare, (2 tickets roundtrip DC/Shanghai) and one extra night of hotel accomodations. 

The Impact

In this era for artists, we can showcase our work, our experiences and how we create work, using our social media platforms. I will be creating a short documentary film about the festival, the performance of Alyce/Donna and all the cultural exchange happening within the event with colleagues for many countries. The film will be shared online and I will send blu-ray copies to selected backers. 

Other Ways You Can Help
  • If you can not contribute with money now, it's all good! You can simply share my campaign on your social media pages and with your friends.

story:
The Story

You know how we sometimes say to a friend, “We should totally go for a coffee together!” or in the arts, we tend to say, “We should see if we can work on something sometime” and it never happens? Well, this is one of those examples, one that’s taken 11 years to happen. And it’s happening in one of the most magical places on Earth at one of the most prestigious international arts festival of them all, the Edinburgh Fringe Festival.

The friends in question are our Creative Director, Amin and Producer, Shai who’ve been friends for years and embarked on their dance and theatre journeys respectively at about the same time about 12 years ago. Since then, they’ve talked about working together but this has never happened until the fateful day Amin informed him that he would be in London (where Shai was at the time in December 2015) soon and this was the spark that started this journey to make bhumi a reality. It wasn’t long after when the pieces fell into place and a solid team of artists was assembled. When we started on the project, we had 3 clear objectives in mind:

1. Subverting existing perceptions about Malay dance by marrying it with western contemporary  dance

When one pictures Malay dance, the image conjured is one that is filled with colourful costumes and headgear, exotic-looking traditional props and stories about life in the yesteryears, living in a kampong (village). Plus, the form itself is instructional and structured and we wanted to challenge what we understand Malay dance to be. We decided to pair it with contemporary dance, which is more abstract and fluid and see what each can form can learn from and give to each other. Of the 6 dancers, only 2 have had any background in Malay dance.

2. Creating a platform for emerging Singaporean & British artists based in the UK to showcase their practice

We wanted to provide a platform for practicing Singaporean & British artists pursuing their postgraduate and undergraduate studies in the UK to expand on their work and practice in an overseas market while also providing a platform for emerging  artists pursuing their undergraduate studies to have opportunities to develop their practice outside of the school context.

3. Cultural exchange

We wanted to introduce, showcase and exchange the Malay arts with collaborators and audiences who may be less familiar with the Malay arts or the unique cultural offering from Singapore or the region. This would be an opportunity for non-Malays and/or non-Singaporeans to learn a new dance form and gain cultural insight into the Malay culture and at the same time, being at the Edinburgh Fringe means we get to present something we love to an international audience.

Photography by Stanley Lin

Our producer, Shai spoke about the show at the launch of the Anglo-Asiatic Arts & Heritage Alliance (AAAHA) at SOAS, University of London recently.

The members of our multicultural and multinational team come from some of the best schools in the United Kingdom.

London Contemporary Dance School
Zunnur Zhafirah Binte Sazali
Venetia Lim
Heather Birley
Jimmy Adams
Onyx Hinds

Royal Central School of Speech and Drama
Mohamad Shaifulbahri (Shai)
Grace Khoo
Stella Cheung
Nicholas Tee

Royal College of Music
Nabillah Jalal

University of Roehampton/CHOREOMUNDUS
Soultari Amin Farid

Look Ma, We're in the Papers!

The Straits Times, Singapore, 31st May 2016

Berita Harian, Singapore, 24th July 2016

The Truth

If you think this sounds like an ambitious undertaking, the truth is, it is. However, we’ve gone into this thinking, we can “go big and go home” or we could end up failing miserably but we’ll know that we’ve given it a shot. We could have spent our time here in the UK, just focusing on our studies, submit our work on time and graduate with our respective degrees but we’ve chosen to push ourselves to fly the Singapore flag as cultural ambassadors at the biggest arts festival in the world - showcasing to the world the unique Singapore value of multiculturalism which has led to this Singaporean-British collaboration. Some dreams remain dreams forever but we’re really humbled we’re mere steps closer to achieving an artist’s dream by being at the Edinburgh Fringe and we hope you’ll be willing to support us on this journey.

So, where will your contribution be going to?

The Budget
*all conversions to Singapore Dollar projected at exchange rate of 1.80.

Venue Hire - £2,800/$5,040
Fringe Registration Fee - £300/$540
Accommodation - £4,320/$7,776
Per Diems (£25 per team member daily) = £3,350/$5,940
Transport (2-way train tickets between London & Edinburgh) - £1,320/$2,376
Costumes/Props - £300/$540
Consumables - £180/$324
Preview Performance Rental (The Drayton Arms in London in July) - £80/$144
Marketing Costs - £1,000/$1,800
Production Photographer/Videographer - £300/$540
Token/Honorarium (£100 per participant) - £1,200/$2,160
Public Liability & Company Insurance - £150/$270

Projected Total - £15,300/$27,540

Income

To date, we’ve raised 39% of our projected budget from the National Arts Council of Singapore, Singapore International Foundation and 2 private donors. We’re still hopeful of hearing from another private donor or two. Meanwhile, we project our income to be at 35-40% of our projected capacity (as advised by Edinburgh Fringe, for realistic purposes) which is around £3,000-£3,500($6000).

Update 4th August: We are extremely proud to be the 4th recipient of the NINJA! Arts Grant ($SGD $800).

Income Streams
Funding Bodies - £6,000 (89% of £6,000 raised so far)
Private Donors - £3,000 (40% of £3,000 raised so far)
Projected Box Office Income - £3,000
Crowdfunding - £5,000

Your Support

Your support is crucial to the success of our production and we hope you can spread the word to your family and friends who you think will believe in us just as you do. To find out more about us, here are the respective social media channels:

Facebook: www.facebook.com/thebhumicollective
Twitter: www.twitter.com/BhumiCollective

Thank you!

Love,
The bhumi Team

story:
We’re so excited to bring you All’s Faire this 2016-2017 season at Action/Adventure Theatre! All’s Faire is a passion project, a story written and created by us about the ridiculous misadventures of the quirky staff at "Medieval Fun Park Portland", a corporate Renaissance Faire. It follows the Action/Adventure signature format of serialized comedies; a “theatre for TV people” format with an overarching story told over the course of 4 episodes, with a different episode performed every weekend. 

Initially conceived as a workshop piece on improvised theatre during Isinglass' summer theatre leadership education program, the play quickly took on a life of its own. It was submitted to and then selected for performance in Action/Adventure's 2016 Pilot Season. After a full production of the first episode, and a sold-out Pilot Season run, All’s Faire was selected by audience votes to be renewed for a full season!

The show is full of slap-stick humor, sword-based innuendos, magic, madness, young love, old love, middle of the road love, wizards, magic cups, sorceresses, jousts, and a mysteriously insightful goat. 

Since our first writing process this story has grown into something large and exciting, bringing in a variety of collaborators beyond our team of students, including our marvelous cast, crew and writers. This show has been a joy to work on, and we couldn’t be more thrilled to get it out to you!

This is our first professional theatrical endeavor as a group of creators and we’re so excited to be working on this project, but as a small group of practitioners we don’t have the same resources that a more established group might. To that end, we are trying to raise $2,000 to help offset the cost of tickets, pay for critical elements like costumes and set pieces, and MOST critically - to compensate our delightful cast, who have already invested huge amounts of their time to bring this show to fruition. Any amount will help us with our goal to create better, more interesting theatre for you- the audience member!

Thanks!

The All's Faire team

story:
Well Hello!

We are the 2016 Williamstown Theatre Festival Non-Equity Company, and we're having a showcase. 

Tell me more about the WTF Non-Eq company.

Here's what the WTF website says:

"The Non-Equity Company is a nationally recognized, highly competitive group of young actors who have committed themselves to a career as professional actors. This company is drawn in large part from the top graduate programs in the country, and also through our extensive submission and audition process in NYC each spring.  [...] Members of the Non-Equity Company (or, “Non-Eqs”) supplement the Equity Company in Main Stage and Nikos Stage productions, and play principal roles in the Community Engagement and Fellowship productions."

Okay great! So what's a showcase and why are you having one?

A showcase is an hour-long show when members of the Non Equity Company will perform for industry professionals. Each Non-Eq is in two scenes with another Non-Eq, showing off what they do best. It's an opportunity for us to show off the hard work we did this summer and make important business connections that can take us to the next step in our careers. 

What's the money going towards? 

WTF graciously covers half the cost of showcase, and the other half comes from the Non-Eqs personally. We are fundraising to help defray those costs. As we've mentioned, we're early career actors, and there are only so many cater-waitering shifts in a week. Your donation will go towards: 

The rental cost of the theatre for our performance space
Publicity materials and invitations for the Showcase (postcards, stamps, mailing labels, etc.)
Headshot and Resume printing 
IndieGoGo’s Support Fee

Any donation you can make - no matter how large or small - will make a big difference. 

What's in it for me?

We're sending everyone who donates a handwritten thank you card. Also, Ryan Haddad has promised to thank each and every one of you in his 2021 Best Actor Oscar Speech.**

**Ryan has promised to do no such thing. That's a joke. However, we feel pretty good about the odds of him winning an Oscar in 2021.

If I can't donate, how else can I support the 2016 Non Eq showcase?

Post about us on social media! Facebook, twitter, snapchat, myspace, friendster--whatever you're on, share our campaign and spread the love. 

THANK YOU FOR ALL OF YOUR HELP!

xoxo, The 2016 Non Eqs
Angelica, Ellen, Hannah, Lauren, Matt, Mike, Ned, Ryan, and Sarah

story:
Soul Nativity is a joyous dance-musical, celebrating the Christmas season through rhythm and blues, gospel, funk and Motown music. Tracy Jack and Alfred Preisser began partnering on the show in the year 2000 at The Harlem School of the Arts.  Since its inception the show has run several times in prestigous theatres throughout New York City to rave reviews like:

"Let’s begin by pointing out the unmistakable spirit of joy at the heart of this production."

- The New York Times

"Religious fervor… The performers raise theroof with dynamic singing and dancing." 

- The New York Post

"Pure Technicolor gospel fantasy…deliciously over-the-top."

- The New Yorker

"The show's highlights are too numerous to mention"

-The New York Sun

"Boundless enthusiasm and enough dazzling sets of pipes to shame a church organ…the actors convey a contagious ecstasy."

- Variety

There are many shows that celebrate the holiday season in New York's theatre district, but NONE with the unique perspective and, well, soul of SOUL NATIVITY.  We're aiming to raise funds to bring the show back, BIGGER AND BETTER than ever for the 2013 Holiday Season and need YOU to help us do it.  With your support, we know that this show that has already touched so many hearts with its inspired celebration, dance and music, will go on to be an annual event that moves audiences this year and for years to come. 

We are seeking to raise a total of $90,000.00 through this campaign, and will use the money as follows:

-$40,000 dollars will pay half of the salary for the entire run of the show for our actors, dancers and musicians, a hard-working company of 18 who pour their hearts into the show every night

-$20,000 will create all of the costumes and scenery for our production

-$15,000 puts a deposit on the rental of our theatre and guarantees SOUL NATIVITY a place in the theatre district during the holiday season

-$10,000 will provide mics and sound equipment 

-$5,000 will allow us to conduct an extensive grassroots outreach program to local churches, schools and community groups to make them a part of our performance event, audience and extended family

When you join Soul Nativity you become a part of our production family, no matter at what level you join,  You will receive our production updates, casting announcements and press releases.  Those joining us at hgher levels will become part of our audience and team of producers, duly credited in our program and production materials.  Best of all everyone who supports Soul Nativity becomes an original angel behind the creation of a show unique to the New York holiday scene and destined to become an annual treasure.

The Impact

New York during the holiday season is a frenetic and exciting place, particularly in the Times Square area.  Tourists from all over the world, shoppers, theatre lovers and people hustling their day jobs create one of the most intense scenes anywhere in the city of New York and beyond.  And although New York features a number of attractions geared toward family and fun, there is not currently a show of SOUL NATIVITY's profile celebrating the holidays from an African American standpoint.

Featuring music and dance rooted in the black church, incorporating great American music & dance forms including but not limited too blues, jazz, rock and gospel, Soul Nativity sets itself apart from all the rest. 

SOUL NATIVITY aims at nothing less than becoming a signiture annual event, like the tree lighting and Radio City Music Hall Spectacular, a family show for all people, every year.

We need your support and your voice:

-please tell a friend,

-a neighbor,

-people you work with,

-organizations that may see the value we detailed here

Any and all forms of support are helpful. Share the link, or direct them to the Indiegogo Soul Nativity page.  

There's plenty of Soul in the holiday season, we just want to share that feeling with everyone. We appreciate you and your efforts. God bless you all.

"The show's highlights are too numerous to mention"
-The New York Sun
"Boundless enthusiasm and enough dazzling sets of pipes to shame a church organ…the actors convey a contagious ecstasy."
- Variety
There are many shows that celebrate the holiday season in New York's theatre district, but NONE with the unique perspective and, well, soul of SOUL NATIVITY.  We're aiming to raise funds to bring the show back, BIGGER AND BETTER than ever for the 2013 Holiday Season and need YOU to help us do it.  With your support, we know that this show that has already touched so many hearts with its inspired celebration, dance and music, will go on to be an annual event that moves audiences this year and for years to come. 
We are seeking to raise a total of $90,000.00 through this campaign, and will use the money as follows:
-$40,000 dollars will pay half of the salary for the entire run of the show for our actors, dancers and musicians, a hard-working company of 18 who pour their hearts into the show every night
-$20,000 will create all of the costumes and scenery for our production
-$15,000 puts a deposit on the rental of our theatre and guarantees SOUL NATIVITY a place in the theatre district during the holiday season
-$10,000 will provide mics and sound equipment 
-$5,000 will allow us to conduct an extensive grassroots outreach program to local churches, schools and community groups to make them a part of our performance event, audience and extended family
When you join Soul Nativity you become a part of our production family, no matter at what level you join,  You will receive our production updates, casting announcements and press releases.  Those joining us at hgher levels will become part of our audience and team of producers, duly credited in our program and production materials.  Best of all everyone who supports Soul Nativity becomes an original angel behind the creation of a show unique to the New York holiday scene and destined to become an annual treasure.


The Impact
New York during the holiday season is a frenetic and exciting place, particularly in the Times Square area.  Tourists from all over the world, shoppers, theatre lovers and people hustling their day jobs create one of the most intense scenes anywhere in the city of New York and beyond.  And although New York features a number of attractions geared toward family and fun, there is not currently a show of SOUL NATIVITY's profile celebrating the holidays from an African American standpoint.
Featuring music and dance rooted in the black church, incorporating great American music & dance forms including but not limited too blues, jazz, rock and gospel, Soul Nativity sets itself apart from all the rest. 
SOUL NATIVITY aims at nothing less than becoming a signiture annual event, like the tree lighting and Radio City Music Hall Spectacular, a family show for all people, every year.
We need your support and your voice:
-please tell a friend,
-a neighbor,
-people you work with,
-organizations that may see the value we detailed here
Any and all forms of support are helpful. Share the link, or direct them to the Indiegogo Soul Nativity page.  
There's plenty of Soul in the holiday season, we just want to share that feeling with everyone. We appreciate you and your efforts. God bless you all.

story:
Short Summary

We have established the first ever, formal alumni association, Alumni & Friends. We have an ambitious first year planned and are in the process of finalizing our database, which spans the school's 26 years, scheduling events and publishing our goals and mission statement.

What We Need 

We need additional monies ASAP to enable us to pay for the outreach and events necessary to achieve our fundraising goal for the year!

The Impact

As the school currently does not receive the much-needed additional funds for academics, the launch plan for Alumni & Friends hinges on a commitment to academic excellence. This will include academic improvements, merit-based scholarships, special programming, summer study, master classes, etc. We are incredibly excited to have the opportunity to provide these critical benefits to PPAS! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word to all PPAS alumni and their families! Also, please post the link for this campaign to your social media! Boundless thanks for your support!

story:
We are NitThèâtre, a community-oriented Senegalese theater group based in Dakar. For the past five years, we have produced theater and organized community arts workshops, all with the goal to:

  • Create and share artistic projects
  • Encourage the participation of children and young people in development work
  • Work for the protection of children and young people across cultures.

Working in collaboration with the children’s rights group “Collectif des Structures d’Appui aux Enfants et Jeunes en Difficulte (COSAED),” Nit Thèâtre is creating an exciting new project: a political flash-mob performance entitled “Coup d’Eclat Xalée Yi.” The project is designed to protest and raise awareness for the conditions of many Talibé children in Senegal. This is a grave and pernicious problem: thousands of children, removed from their families and support structures, are exploited daily and reduced to begging in the streets of Dakar. 

Our objective is to assemble as many people as possible at the Place de la Nation (Place de l’Obélisque) on November 20, the UN declared ‘Universal Children’s Day,’ at 6:30PM. Working with the people assembled, we will:

  • Form the image of a giant spider-web with our bodies, and use fluorescent arm bands to make our image visible as night falls. 
  • Create an artistic installation of a human figure composed of the tin pots which many talibé children use to collect money.
  • Install six large screens on which we will project videos featuring politicians' declarations, promises, and testimonies regarding the problem of child exploitation; these videos will serve to show the gravity of the talibé problem as well as the hypocrisy of the politicians who have failed to solve it. 

The idea, in essence, is to create a visual representation of the situation faced daily by Talibé children: trapped in a vicious system that continues to grow day by day.

We hope you find this idea as exciting as we do. “Coup d’Eclat Xalèe Yi” is the first project of its kind in Senegal, and it could empower youth and send a necessary message to the Senegalese government. And the word is already out: we have been working hard to spread the news about “Coup d’Eclat Xalèe Yi” so that our collective numbers on November 20 will be impossible to ignore.

But now we need your help. In order for this exciting project to work, we have a number of necessary expenses. We are hoping to raise $2500 (1,527,400 CFA) to cover these expenses. Please help us bring this exciting and vital project to fruition. Donate anything you possibly can (any amount helps!) and tell your friends to donate as well.

“Coup d’Eclat Xalèe Yi” is a project with huge potential. As art and as activism, it has the ability to make a powerful and necessary statement. And the cause of “Coup d’Eclat Xalèe Yi” is not merely local; we all have the responsibility to engage with and solve the problem facing many talibé children, regardless of where we live. 

So join us for a #CoupdÈclaT #XalèeYi. The moment is now.


**********


NitThèâtre est une association artistique et communautaire qui à pour but de:

  • Créer et diffuser des projets artistiques

  • Encourager la participation des enfants et des jeunes au développement communautaire par l’animation culturelle.
  • S’activer pour la protection des enfants et des jeunes a travers la culture
Notre association, en collaboration avec l'organisation Collectif des Structures d’Appui aux Enfants et Jeunes en Difficulté (COSAED) travaille sur un projet innovant : une performance ‘flash-mob’ qui s’appelle « Coup d’Eclat Xalée Yi. » Le projet est né d’un besoin de donner coup d’alerte fort aux gouvernants, décideurs, et le grand public sur la situation des enfants de la rue en Afrique, et particulièrement au Sénégal. Cette situation est très grave : il y a beaucoup d’enfants, qui sont exploités et qui mendient tout les jours dans les rues de Dakar.

Notre objectif est de rassembler le maximum des personnes INDIGNÈES (au moins 750 personnes) à la Place de la Nation (Place de l’Obélisque) le 20 Novembre 2015, la Journée Internationale de la Convention Internationale des Droits de l’Enfant, à 18:30h. Avec votre participation, nous allons:

  • Reproduire la forme d’une grande toile d’araignée, en apposant des bandes fluorescentes sur les bras des participants pour obtenir l’image d’une toile d’araignée en éclat après le coucher du soleil.
  • Créer à l’entrée de la place, une installation de bonhommes (en pots de tomates et pots de lait vides) pris en piège dans une toile d’araignée- labyrinthe. 
  • Projeter des vidéos de témoignages, plaidoyers et déclarations sur 6 écrans géants positionnés en arc autour cette toile.

La toile d’araignée est une représentation visuelle de la situation des enfants de la rue (talibés): piégés dans un système qui continue de grandir de jour en jour.

« Coup d’Eclat Xalée Yi » est un projet important pour les enfants du pays et pour le développement du Sénégal. Nous comptons rassembler le maximum de participants pour envoyer un message fort.

Pour le succès de « Coup d’Eclat Xalèe Yi, » nous avons besoin de récolter $2500 (1,527,400 CFA) afin de couvrir les dépenses liées à la logistique.

Votre soutien est tres important pour la réalisation de ce projet innovant. Participez autant que possible, et parlez du « Coup d’Eclat Xalèe Yi » avec vos amis.

Ce projet a un grand potentiel, et son impact n’est pas seulement locale ; nous avons tous la responsabilité de trouver une solution sur le problème des enfants de la rue. 

Rejoignez-nous pour un #CoupdÈclaT #XalèeYi.
